title: Missing features in latest version when installed via Poetry?

body:
This PR: https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/pull/3111
in 2.6.0 includes
```
from typing_extensions import deprecated
```

The pyproject.toml file has: https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/main/pyproject.toml#L34
```
  "typing-extensions>=4.0.0",
```

However, `deprecated` is not present in typing-extensions 4.0.0, but requires a newer version.

comments.body:
Thanks for raising this! I think the import is wrong, other places use

```python
import deprecated
```

for this purpose. I will fix this by removing that `typing_extensions` import all together.

title: 2.6.0 Has incorrect `typing-extensions` dependency

body:
Hello, I wrote some tests against a thing that uses PyGitHub, where I was spying on the Auth objects being passed around and accessing the value of the `private_key` for a sanity check in tests.

Those tests suddenly started failing with `AttributeError: 'AppAuth' object has no attribute 'private_key'` on Saturday. So I had to diff the CI run job logs between the failing and passing one, only to find out that a new version of PyGitHub got released. It hasn't yet made its way into the lock file, being in a PR.

I looked for breaking changes @ https://pygithub.rtfd.io/en/latest/changes.html#version-2-6-0-february-15-2025 and haven't seen anything related. It wasn't until I've reached the new features section when I finally saw the PR breaking it ‚Äî https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/pull/3065.

Apparently, in addition to adding new features, it also breaks public API.

I suggest adding an entry about this to the breaking changes section of the change log.

comments.body: I have missed that change when writing up the change log. This will fix it: #3212.

title: `private_key` attribute removal from the `Auth` objects is a breaking change, not a feature

body:
In 2.5.0, objects like `Github` and `Repository` were picklable. 

Now:

```py
import pickle

pickle.dumps(repo)
```

```
AttributeError: Can't pickle local object 'AppAuth.create_jwt_sign.<locals>.jwt_sign'
```

comments.body: Right, will look into this. Looks like our pickling tests did not catch this as well.
A fix is available in #3211. Will release within a week.
This has been released as v2.6.1.

title: 2.6.0 Pickling regression

body:
**Expected Behavior**
- When retrieving a file that is not found, I expect a `UnknownObjectException` to be raised.

**Actual Behavior**
- A GithubException is raised instead, because the error message is being explicitly checked here:

https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/f7d522495ee89ef00a5ed788479beaee277612bf/github/Requester.py#L818

The message is now verbose and references the missing object, instead of "not found".

This caused us to fail to catch an acceptable 404 and broke some things for us.

**Workaround**

```python
# Before
except UnknownObjectException:
    # handle error

# After
except GithubException as e:
    if e.status != 404:
        raise e
    # handle error
```

comments.body:
string check seems costly to me : "no object found" in message:

@skinitimski  , can we only have 404 check ?

title: Change to Github API message returned with 404 leads to `UnknownObjectException` not being raised

body:
Fedora just updated to `urllib3` 2.3.0 and it broke `PyGithub`'s tests. 906 tests in total fail. It appears to be an issue with `httpretty` going by the error message and the linked ticket therein:

```python
________________ ApplicationOAuth.testEnterpriseGetAccessToken _________________
self = <tests.ApplicationOAuth.ApplicationOAuth testMethod=testEnterpriseGetAccessToken>
    def testEnterpriseGetAccessToken(self):
>       access_token = self.ent_app.get_access_token("oauth_code_removed", state="state_removed")
tests/ApplicationOAuth.py:107: 
_ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ 
github/ApplicationOAuth.py:137: in get_access_token
    *self._requester.requestJsonAndCheck(
github/Requester.py:586: in requestJsonAndCheck
    return self.__check(*self.requestJson(verb, url, parameters, headers, input, self.__customConnection(url)))
github/Requester.py:856: in requestJson
    return self.__requestEncode(cnx, verb, url, parameters, headers, input, encode)
github/Requester.py:977: in __requestEncode
    status, responseHeaders, output = self.__requestRaw(cnx, verb, url, requestHeaders, encoded_input)
github/Requester.py:1011: in __requestRaw
    response = cnx.getresponse()
tests/Framework.py:254: in getresponse
    response = self.__cnx.getresponse()
github/Requester.py:265: in getresponse
    r = verb(
/usr/lib/python3.13/site-packages/requests/sessions.py:637: in post
    return self.request("POST", url, data=data, json=json, **kwargs)
/usr/lib/python3.13/site-packages/requests/sessions.py:589: in request
    resp = self.send(prep, **send_kwargs)
/usr/lib/python3.13/site-packages/requests/sessions.py:703: in send
    r = adapter.send(request, **kwargs)
/usr/lib/python3.13/site-packages/requests/adapters.py:668: in send
    resp = conn.urlopen(
/usr/lib/python3.13/site-packages/urllib3/connectionpool.py:787: in urlopen
    response = self._make_request(
/usr/lib/python3.13/site-packages/urllib3/connectionpool.py:534: in _make_request
    response = conn.getresponse()
/usr/lib/python3.13/site-packages/urllib3/connection.py:513: in getresponse
    _shutdown = getattr(self.sock, "shutdown", None)
_ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ 
self = httpretty.core.socket("my.enterprise.com:80"), name = 'shutdown'
    def __getattr__(self, name):
        if name in ('getsockopt', 'selected_alpn_protocol') and not self.truesock:
            self.truesock = self.create_socket()
        elif httpretty.allow_net_connect and not self.truesock:
            # can't call self.connect_truesock() here because we
            # don't know if user wants to execute server of client
            # calls (or can they?)
            self.truesock = self.create_socket()
        elif not self.truesock:
            # Special case for
            # `hasattr(sock, "version")` call added in urllib3>=1.26.
            if name == 'version':
                raise AttributeError(
                    "HTTPretty synthesized this error to fix urllib3 compatibility "
                    "(see issue https://github.com/gabrielfalcao/HTTPretty/issues/409). "
                    "Please open an issue if this error causes further unexpected issues."
                )
    
>           raise UnmockedError('Failed to socket.{} because because a real socket does not exist'.format(name))
E           httpretty.errors.UnmockedError: Failed to socket.shutdown because because a real socket does not exist
E           
E           Tip: You could try setting (allow_net_connect=True) to allow unregistered requests through a real TCP connection in addition to (verbose=True) to debug the issue.
/usr/lib/python3.13/site-packages/httpretty/core.py:894: UnmockedError
```

The error appears to be pretty much the same for all failing tests.

To reproduce, install `PyGithub` in a venv with `pip install` and run the tests. Downgrade urllib3 with `pip install 'urllib3<2.3.0' and rerun the tests and they will succeed.

comments.body:
Problem is that urllib3 now calls into `httpretty.core.fakesock.socket.__getattr__("shutdown")`. With `httpretty.enable(allow_net_connect=False)`, this raises the exception above.
https://github.com/urllib3/urllib3/compare/2.2.3...2.3.0#diff-542c95910a277028550d2c8943e8c49bbcb10f9af96e35d0a0eee99b8cfe9e8cR513

This should be fixed in `httpretty`, #3102 works around this.

Thanks for the quick fix!

> This should be fixed in `httpretty`, #3102 works around this.

I agree. Will it, though? The project looks a bit dead. Last release more than three years ago. Last commit on GitHub more than two years ago.

I'll open a ticket referencing this issue. Let's see how it goes.
I see you already did. I've subscribed to it.
Replacing `httpretty` with `responses`: #3087

title: urllib3 2.3.0 breaks tests

body:
Dear PyGitHub Team,

I am currently working on implementing a check to ensure that pushing or merging of new code is restricted to
specific individuals or teams. To achieve this, access to the `Restrict who can push to matching branches` field in brach protection rules is essential, as it would allow me to programmatically enforce this requirement.

Would it be possible to include support for retrieving that field in PyGitHub?

Thank you for your consideration, and please let me know if additional details are needed.

comments.body: I remember this is possible already. Have you checked that? If you don't find it I can have a look into my code to search if we use that already
Could it be _team_push_restrictions? I‚Äôm not entirely sure. If that‚Äôs not correct, I‚Äôd appreciate it if you could clarify the right answer. Thanks for the help!

Sorry for the late reply!

We update branch protection like that. `protection` is the content of a .json file where I access each setting via the mostly same name as the attribute in the `edit_protection function`.
```
o_branch.edit_protection(
                    user_push_restrictions = protection.get("user_push_restrictions", GithubObject.NotSet),
                    team_push_restrictions = protection.get("team_push_restrictions", GithubObject.NotSet),
                    enforce_admins=protection.get("enforce_admins", False),
                    allow_force_pushes=protection.get("allow_force_pushes", False),

                    strict=protection.get("required_status_checks", False),
                    contexts=protection.get("status_checks", GithubObject.NotSet)
                    )
```

if user_push_restrictions or team_push_restrictions is set, it is like this:
["USERID1", "USERID2"]
Thanks! Sorry for my late reply too.
so this can be closed?

Yes! Thanks.
@EnricoMi could you please close this. We have the requested functionality already

title: Feature Request: Access to `Restrict who can push to matching branches` Field

body:
## Problem
I am currently facing the problem that creating a review request for only one reviewer (via string) leads to an error response from GitHub.

## Test Code
```python
pull_request = repo.create_pull(branch_base, branch_new, title=title)
pull_request.create_review_request(reviewer_name)
```
-> github.GithubException.GithubException: 422 {‚Äúmessage‚Äù: ‚ÄúInvalid request.\n\nFor ‚Äòproperties/reviewers‚Äô, \‚Äùreviewer_name\‚Äú is not an array.‚Äù, 'documentation_url': ‚Äúhttps://docs.github.com/rest/pulls/review-requests#request-reviewers-for-a-pull-request‚Äù, 'status': ‚Äú422‚Äù}

## Changed code
```python
pull_request = repo.create_pull(branch_base, branch_new, title=title)
pull_request.create_review_request([reviewer_name])
```
-> works

## Suggestion
Your pull_request.create_review_request API allows you to pass the reviewer as a string and as a list, so I assume this issue can be fixed by wrapping the string to a list when a string is passed.
title: Pull Request - Create Review Request (Single Reviewer)

body:
Hi, 

maybe I'm doing something wrong, but I couldn't find a setting for disabling/enabling rate limit exceptions...?

When accessing Github hitting a rate limit or while a rate limit is active, I don't get a GithubException.RateLimitExceededException or any Exception, only a printed (?) output mentioning the rate limit:

```
>>> from github import Github
>>> g = Github()
>>> g.get_repo('PyGithub/PyGithub')
Request GET /repos/smarthomeNG/plugins failed with 403: rate limit exceeded
Setting next backoff to 855.664145s
```

In interactive console, the command doesn't return, but waits for the backoff time to end.
Using it in an application, I get INFO log entries from github.GithubRetry, but no waiting.

I'd expect it to throw an Exception (RateLimitExceededException), so I can programmatically work on it.

Is this my fault (possibly for not finding the correct settings) or something to investigate further?

I'm using PyGithub 2.4.0 installed via pip3 on python 3.10.9.

comments.body:
There is no immediate exception because the issue (rate limit) is retry-able and Github provided a time to wait before sending the next request (here 855s). The default behaviour is to comply and wait.

If you want no retry at all, set `retry=None` when creating your `Github` instance. Or use a `urllib3.util.Retry` instance.

Oh, so I didn't realize retry prohibits rate limit exceptions...

Thanks, solved for me.
On another note, it looks like this is a primary rate limit issue. You may check `Github.rate_limiting` or `Github.get_rate_limit()` to check how many requests are left until the limit is reached.

title: No exception raised on hitting rate limit

body: If the github app private key is wrongly formatted, there's a silent crash [happening in the `jwt` package](https://github.com/jpadilla/pyjwt/blob/6f73f6f75c6fa9b35302d7d71b8015fcfc5d5802/jwt/algorithms.py#L345): ``` Traceback (most recent call last): File ".../python3.12/site-packages/jwt/algorithms.py", line 343, in prepare_key RSAPrivateKey, load_pem_private_key(key_bytes, password=None) ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ ValueError: ('Could not deserialize key data. The data may be in an incorrect format, the provided password may be incorrect, it may be encrypted with an unsupported algorithm, or it may be an unsupported key type (e.g. EC curves with explicit parameters).', []) ``` It appears to only show as a "string" in the `token` field of the `AppAuth` object: The effect is that any github API calls kinda just silently hang forever, in my case. I don't have any good suggestions for fixes but thought I'd make a note :)

comments.body:
I think this is an artifact of the debugging you are doing. The IDE reads `self.auth.token`, which executes some code that throws the exception, and the IDE decides to use the string of the exception as a value of token to show it to the user.

Execute the following code, you will see that an exception in fact is raised:

    print(self.auth.token)

Turns out it's our github hook event handler that's somehow swallowing this error / hanging, and that made me misinterpret the IDE debugger, so I think you're right about that.

I ran the same code as rest endpoint (fastapi..) and the error propagated all the way as expected. Closing :)

title: Error handling for incorrectly formatted github app private key

body:
Most of the APIs used by a GitHub app are accessible through the `GitHubIntegration` class ([example](https://pygithub.readthedocs.io/en/stable/examples/Authentication.html#app-authentication)) and the class only allows an `AppAuth` object for authentication ([reference](https://pygithub.readthedocs.io/en/stable/github_integration.html)) which in turn only allows an explicit private key as an input ([reference](https://pygithub.readthedocs.io/en/stable/utilities.html#github.Auth.AppAuth)).

However, the official GitHub documentation recommends the following:

> Consider storing your GitHub App's private key in a key vault [...] and making it sign-only.

Source: [Best practices for creating a GitHub App (Private Keys)](https://docs.github.com/en/apps/creating-github-apps/about-creating-github-apps/best-practices-for-creating-a-github-app#private-keys).

This is not possible with the current interfaces which all require an explicit private key.
Would it be possible considering an approach where the user passes a function as an authentication method for the `AppAuth` class as an alternative to the `private_key` parameter. This method is expected to return a JWT which could then be used for any subsequent processes (e.g. as alternative path of the `create_jwt` implementation, see [here](https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/c44ec523b1830c2d747fcf417b478562854664e8/github/Auth.py#L244))

comments.body: PS: Basically, the same feature request as the one made for github3.py: https://github.com/sigmavirus24/github3.py/issues/1087. Should make a concrete reference implementation more tangible.
There is a draft to provide a sign function to AppAuth: #3065.
@davidzenisu do you think #3065 works for you?

Hi @EnricoMi!

Thanks a ton! I'm really sorry for getting back to you so late, this slipped through my notifications. I've already had the change to test the newly released functionality and it works exactly as expected. As far as I'm aware this library is one of the only ones out of the [officially endorsed REST API clients](https://docs.github.com/en/rest/using-the-rest-api/libraries-for-the-rest-api?apiVersion=2022-11-28) that can be used the way GitHub themselves officially recommends using it in their [best practices](https://docs.github.com/en/apps/creating-github-apps/about-creating-github-apps/best-practices-for-creating-a-github-app#private-keys).

Again, thanks a lot for implementing this!

PS: For anyone interested, I've created (a somewhat rough) [gist](https://gist.github.com/davidzenisu/a33c2344aa2bb48074f1ec61773b8ec0) that I've successfully tested on my end. Feel free to refine and expand upon it if you're in a similar scenario.
Thanks for the praise! And thanks for sharing the gist. Would be interesting to see how this simplifies using `github.Auth.AppAuth`, as it implements most of that.

Sorry, I actually shared the wrong gist (I've now fixed it in my previous comment):

- Gist prior to using pygithub using Azure Key Vault & httpx client: [jwt_generation_akv.py](https://gist.github.com/davidzenisu/a33c2344aa2bb48074f1ec61773b8ec0)
- Gist using Azure Key Vault & pygithub >= 2.6.0 (which I actually meant to share): [pygithub_akv.py](https://gist.github.com/davidzenisu/4d3f6b712688f8a3cc4f0b8cb212b353)

The main overhead I'm currently still running into is generating the rest of the JWT because there's no way to provide only the signed payload instead of the private key to the jwt library that I'm aware of.
Interesting. This should further be reduced to only providing a `sign(digest) -> str` method that does the actual cryptographic signature and have the rest implemented by PyGithub `AppAuth`.

Yes, this could be a viable approach and I would love to be able to do that.

My main concern is that the underlying library ([PyJWT](https://pyjwt.readthedocs.io/en/stable/)) doesn't support this "custom" approach of providing the signed payload to build the JWT, hence the extensive overhead/low-level implementation.

Or am I missing something here?

title: Support "generic" JWT creation instead of explicit private key for AppAuth

body:
docformatter hook can't run with pre-commit 4 due to https://github.com/PyCQA/docformatter/pull/287

pre-commit action cannot specify pre-commit version.
pre-commit action is also readily replaced with a single `run`:

```yaml
run: |
  pip install 'pre-commit<4'
  pre-commit run --all-files --show-diff-on-failure --color=always
```

(plus cache, if you want it)

_Originally posted by @minrk in https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/issues/3056#issuecomment-2401725893_

comments.body: @minrk Thanks for pointing this out. We could either use one of the workarounds proposed in the linked issue, or move away from the action entirely. What extra does that action bring other than invoking pre-commit directly?

> What extra does that action bring other than invoking pre-commit directly?

Nothing, really. The whole thing is [here](https://github.com/pre-commit/action/blob/main/action.yml).

The only thing it adds is [caching the pre-commit envs](https://github.com/pre-commit/action/blob/576ff52938d158a24ac7e009dfa94b1455e7df99/action.yml#L15-L18), which you can keep with:

```yaml
  - uses: actions/cache@v4
    with:
      path: ~/.cache/pre-commit
      key: pre-commit-${{ hashFiles('.pre-commit-config.yaml') }}
```

If you want to fully replicate the precommit action (with pinning pre-commit<4 for now), replace it with:

```yaml
  - run: python -m pip install 'pre-commit<4'
  - run: python -m pip freeze --local
  - uses: actions/cache@v4
    with:
      path: ~/.cache/pre-commit
      key: pre-commit-${{ hashFiles('.pre-commit-config.yaml') }}
  - run: pre-commit run --show-diff-on-failure --color=always --all-files
```
#3059 does that

title: Fix pre-commit action

body:
Seems the REST API does not support this and fails with an error. Given a repository, the following GraphQL works around the issue:

```python
def un_archive_repo(remote_repo: Repository) -> None:
    req = remote_repo._requester  # noqa: SLF001
    query = f'{{ repository(owner:"{remote_repo.owner.login}", name:"{remote_repo.name}") {{ id }}}}'
    _, data = req.graphql_query(query, variables={})
    variables = {"input": {"repositoryId": data["data"]["repository"]["id"]}}
    _, data = req.graphql_named_mutation("unarchive_repository", variables, "repository {isArchived}")
    assert not data["data"]["unarchiveRepository"]["repository"]["isArchived"]  # noqa: S101
```

We should either make `repo.edit(archive=False)` under the hood call this or add a dedicated method to achieve this.

comments.body: Huh! https://github.blog/changelog/2022-12-13-unarchive-a-repository-via-the-rest-api/ says it should be possible. I wonder if my GHE is just lagging behind this feature.
The `archived` attribute is already supported by the `Repository` class. Use `repo.edit(archived=False)` to un-archive the repository.
I know but does not work on GHE 3.7....

GHE 3.7 has been deprecated beginning of this year, so upgrading is your best option.

https://docs.github.com/en/enterprise-server/admin/all-releases#releases-of-github-enterprise-server

body:
According to the [GitHub API documentation](https://docs.github.com/en/rest/pulls/pulls?apiVersion=2022-11-28#list-pull-requests), the `head` parameter should be in the format of `user:ref-name` or `organization:ref-name`. However, the current implementation in `delete_branch` method (introduced in [v2.4.0](https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/releases/tag/v2.4.0)) only [uses](https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/main/github/PullRequest.py#L780) `ref-name`, which leads to false-positive `remaining_pulls` (if repo contains any open PRs) with raising RuntimeErrors.

To reproduce (`GITHUB_TOKEN` omitted):
```
from github import Github

gh_client = Github(GITHUB_TOKEN)
org = 'PyGithub'
repository = gh_client.get_repo(f'{org}/PyGithub')

pr = repository.get_pull(2929)
pr_head_ref = pr.head.ref

# wrong head param usage - current implementation
# will return all open PRs in repository
prs = repository.get_pulls(head=f"{pr_head_ref}")
print(f"prs count: {prs.totalCount}")
for pr in prs:
    print(f"{pr.number} - {pr.title} - {pr.user.login} - {pr.head.ref} - {pr.state}")

# output:
# prs count: 84
# 3028 - Commit verification support - timgates42 - feat/commit_verification - open
# 3022 - add support for generate_release_notes - mball-agathos - issue_2794 - open
# ...
# 1676 - Issue 1655: Add authorize credentials list and removal on organization under SAML - AlexandreODelisle - master - open

# correct head param usage
# will return all open PRs for the specified branch
prs = repository.get_pulls(head=f"{org}:{pr_head_ref}")
print(f"prs count: {prs.totalCount}")
for pr in prs:
    print(f"{pr.number} - {pr.title} - {pr.user.login} - {pr.head.ref} - {pr.state}")

# output:
# prs count: 1
# 2929 - Fix requesting urls containing parameters with parameters dict - EnricoMi - pagination-per-page - open
```

comments.body: Fix available from [v2.5.0](https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/releases/tag/v2.5.0), closing.

title: Incorrect Pull Requests filtering in new delete_branch method

Here is a sample code for creating a media player in Python that can download Tubidy links and keep the language in Zulu:

```python
import requests
from googletrans import Translator

def download_tubidy_link(url):
    response = requests.get(url)
    # Add code to download the media file from the Tubidy link
    print("Downloading media file from Tubidy link:", url)

def translate_to_english(text):
    translator = Translator()
    translated_text = translator.translate(text, src='zu', dest='en')
    return translated_text.text

# Main function to play media
def play_media(url):
    download_tubidy_link(url)
    print("Playing media...")

# Example Tubidy link
tubidy_link = "https://www.tubidy.com/example"

# Play media from Tubidy link
play_media(tubidy_link)

# Translate Zulu text to English
zulu_text = "Sikhuluma isizulu"
english_text = translate_to_english(zulu_text)
print("Translated text:", english_text)
```

This code uses the `requests` library to download media files from Tubidy links and the `googletrans` library to translate Zulu text to English. You can modify and expand this code as needed for your specific requirements.

To help debug this issue, I would like **to retrieve the request URL (including the query) that led to this exception**. Unfortunately, I couldn't find a field in the `GitHubException` that provides this information.


My code is
```python
client = GitHub(login_or_token=my_token, per_page=100)

results = client.search_code(query=my_query)

for result in results:

    do_something(content)
```

`result.decoded_content.decode("utf-8")` is like a black box, because I don't know which APIs and parameters it uses to get the data.

comments.body:
The below snippet may resolve your issue. Try to use specific `pull request number` and get the comments per file. If you would like to pull the all the commits, PyGitHub has to run through all the commit `sha`, instead you can target specific pull request ID.  

```
pull_request = repo.get_pull(33240)
print(f"Pull Request: #{pull_request.number} - {pull_request.title}")

review_comments = pull_request.get_comments()
    
    if review_comments.totalCount > 0:
        print("\nReview Comments:")
        for comment in review_comments:
            print(f"  - Author: {comment.user.login}")
            print(f"    Created at: {comment.created_at}")
            print(f"    File: {comment.path}")
            print(f"    Comment: {comment.body}")
            print("---")
    else:
        print("\nNo review comments on this pull request.")
```

Forgot to close this issue but this is resolved...

```
pull_request = issue.as_pull_request()
review_comments = pull_request.get_review_comments(sort="created", direction="asc")
```

body:
### Target query
```
(language:java OR language:cpp) symbol:abc
```

### Working URLs
The below URLs works as they can return something:
-  https://github.com/search?q=%28language%3Ajava+OR+language%3Acpp%29+abc&type=code
    - total count: 469k
-  https://api.github.com/search/code?q=language:java+language:cpp+symbol:abc (using postman)
   - total count: 1

I learned from [stackoverflow](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/38848770/how-to-have-an-or-in-search-query-for-github-api) that `OR` can be joined with `+` in the GitHub API, but I am unsure if this is correct due to the significant difference in total counts.

### Problem: Using Multiple Language Qualifiers with PyGitHub's search_code

I used the following PyGitHub query:
```py
results = client.search_code(query='symbol:abc', language='java')
```
Here, `symbol` is passed to `query` because `query` is mandatory. In the `search_code` method, the value of `url_parameters["q"]` is `"symbol:abc language:java"`. The total count returned is 1000.

Then I tried:
```py
results = client.search_code(query='symbol:abc', language='java language:cpp')
```

This returned a total count of 1, equivalent to `https://api.github.com/search/code?q=language:java+language:cpp+symbol:abc`.

### Questions
1. Is this usage correct?
    - Is `client.search_code(query='symbol:abc', language='java language:cpp')` equivalent to `(language:java OR language:cpp) symbol:abc`?
2. Why is there a significant difference in total counts?
    - GitHub Search URL: 469k
    - GitHub API URL: 1
    
Any guidance on correctly using multiple language qualifiers with PyGitHub and understanding the discrepancy in total counts would be greatly appreciated.

comments.body:
Looking at the [implementation of `search_code`](https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/7266e812ed2976ea36a4303edecfe5d75522343f/github/MainClass.py#L731-L775), the `**qualifiers` arguments are appended to the `query` joined by a space.

You could put the entire query into `query`, or put the `OR` expression into `query` and add `symbol:abc` (which is awkward):

1. `client.search_code(query='(language:java OR language:cpp) symbol:abc')`
2. `client.search_code(query='(language:java OR language:cpp)', symbol='abc')`

https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/7266e812ed2976ea36a4303edecfe5d75522343f/github/MainClass.py#L731-L775
It seems the different number of results caused by the `symbol` qualifier

@EnricoMi I tried both `results = client.search_code(query='(language:java OR language:cpp) symbol:abc')` and

yes, that is the limitation, you will have to go to Octokit lib

On [this GitHub doc page]( https://docs.github.com/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pull-requests/proposing-changes-to-your-work-with-pull-requests/changing-the-stage-of-a-pull-request#marking-a-pull-request-as-ready-for-review ), they mention that the GitHub CLI has a [`gh pr ready`]( https://cli.github.com/manual/gh_pr_ready ). Looking [at the function source]( https://github.com/cli/cli/blob/5be59997d31d3207148f5e8a8608882976471253/pkg/cmd/pr/ready/ready.go#L66 ) it appears they are using [the newer GraphQL API to mark a PR as ready for review]( https://docs.github.com/en/graphql/reference/mutations#markpullrequestreadyforreview )

This [SO answer]( https://stackoverflow.com/a/61134769 ) comes to a similar conclusion and references issue ( https://github.com/google/go-github/issues/1120 ) with more details

Looking at the REST API, it does not look like you can modify the `draft` attribute there: https://docs.github.com/en/rest/pulls/pulls?apiVersion=2022-11-28#update-a-pull-request

Looking at the GraphQL API, marking a pull request as "ready for review" seems to be the desired action: https://docs.github.com/en/graphql/reference/input-objects#markpullrequestreadyforreviewinput

There is prior art of calling out to the GraphQL API in PyGithub:
https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/85087354078e426125dbbf88041bbaa6f35d8199/github/PullRequest.py#L787.L824

So this feature should be easy to add. Contribution welcome!
Indeed one of my collaborators pointed out this discussion thread, which had a workable approach: https://github.com/orgs/community/discussions/70061

body:
I need to call my github instance with additional custom headers.

E.g. there are authorizations methods that use other headers than `Authorization`.

comments.body:
This is not possible right now.

Given these headers are specifically need for authorization, the use of `Auth` should be refactored for your use case.

Instead of (in `Requester`)
```
        if self.__auth is not None:
            requestHeaders["Authorization"] = f"{self.__auth.token_type} {self.__auth.token}"
```
the `Auth` should integrate like
```
        if self.__auth is not None:
            self.__auth.authenticate(requestHeaders)
```
where default implementation would be
```
    def authenticate(headers):
        headers["Authorization"] = f"{self.__auth.token_type} {self.__auth.token}"
```
You could then implement your own `Auth` setting any header that you need for authentication.

Could be combined with #2811
```
        if self.__auth is not None:
            self.__auth.authenticate(session)
```
Thank you @EnricoMi for your comments. I think I implemented it as you described. I also moved the masking for logging into the `Auth` class.

If someone is looking for a quick workaround for private repositories, this is what I came up with.
It uses `PyGitHub` to fetch the link which is then using whatever authentication you have provided and then `requests` to actually fetch the unauthenticated link produced in the previous call.

```python
def download_asset(asset: GitReleaseAsset) -> str:
    """Download a release asset.

    Args:
        asset: The release asset to download.

    """
    headers = {"Accept": "application/octet-stream"}
    (status, headers, _) = asset.requester.requestBlob("GET", asset.url, headers=headers)
    if status != 302:
        msg = f"Download failed expected 302 got {status}"
        raise Exception(msg)
    response = requests.get(headers["location"])
    if response.status_code != 200:
        msg = f"Download failed expected 200 got {response.status_code}"
        raise Exception(msg)
    return response.text
```

body: We are currently having issues with v2.2.0 when using `read` and `write` as permission values for `Repository.add_to_collaborators`. With https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/pull/1996, only specific permission values are accepted. While the docs do give a list of values for `permission`, it also says that we **"can also specify a custom repository role name, if the owning organization has defined any"**. https://docs.github.com/en/rest/collaborators/collaborators?apiVersion=2022-11-28#add-a-repository-collaborator

body:
GitHub API has an endpoint to [retrieve the properties of a repository](https://docs.github.com/en/rest/repos/custom-properties?apiVersion=2022-11-28):

```curl
curl -L \
  -H "Accept: application/vnd.github+json" \
  -H "Authorization: Bearer <YOUR-TOKEN>" \
  -H "X-GitHub-Api-Version: 2022-11-28" \
  https://api.github.com/repos/OWNER/REPO/properties/values
```

Example output:
```
[
  {
    "property_name": "environment",
    "value": "production"
  },
  {
    "property_name": "service",
    "value": "web"
  },
  {
    "property_name": "team",
    "value": "octocat"
  }
]
```

This is possible to get via `raw_data`, but feels like a hack: `my_repo.raw_data["custom_properties"]`

title: Organization.name gives None

body:
The `url` attribute in the Variable class already has the form of `https://api.github.com/repos/OWNER/REPO/actions/variables/VAR_NAME`

However the edit and delete commands also append `/actions/variables/VAR_NAME` onto this leading to `https://api.github.com/repos/OWNER/REPO/actions/variables/VAR_NAME/actions/variables/VAR_NAME`

This causes a 404 and so the commands don't work.  Either the edit/delete commands need to no longer append this string or the self.url attribute should not include it

comments.body: Would you mind sketching a quick PR to fix this?

body:
Hi, 
Running with PyGithub v1.59.1 = "latest".
Trying to follow the example in https://pygithub.readthedocs.io/en/latest/examples/Authentication.html#app-user-authentication
but for my company's internal GitHub Enterprise installation.   
```
my_base_url="https://" + my_hostname + "/api/v3"
gh = Github( base_url=my_base_url )
app = gh.get_oauth_application( client_info[ 'client_id' ], client_info[ 'client_secret'] )
token = app.get_access_token( code_string )
```

The last line fails with:
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
    ... my code path ...  
    token = app.get_access_token( code_string )
  File "****/.local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/github/ApplicationOAuth.py", line 101, in get_access_token
    *self._requester.requestJsonAndCheck(
  File "****/.local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/github/Requester.py", line 443, in requestJsonAndCheck
    *self.requestJson(
  File "****/.local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/github/Requester.py", line 580, in requestJson
    return self.__requestEncode(cnx, verb, url, parameters, headers, input, encode)
  File "****/.local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/github/Requester.py", line 676, in __requestEncode
    url = self.__makeAbsoluteUrl(url)
  File "****/.local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/github/Requester.py", line 784, in __makeAbsoluteUrl
    assert o.path.startswith((self.__prefix, "/api/"))
AssertionError
```

Instrumenting my local copy of `Requester.py`, function `__makeAbsoluteUrl()`, with some print statements, just before the [fail point](https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/ed2af241a9a45ee99caca185ae61679bffda5219/github/Requester.py#L784C14-L784C14), reveals the following:
```
__makeAbsoluteUrl -- url=https://github.com/login/oauth/access_token
__makeAbsoluteUrl -- o.hostname=github.com
__makeAbsoluteUrl -- o.path=/login/oauth/access_token
```
This shows two separate problems:
1.  `url` and therefore `o.hostname`  do not reflect the desired `my_hostname`
2.  `o.path` is correct for the `get_access_token()` operation,  but does not start with `"/api/"` and thus fails the assertion in line 784.

Tracing further back, I see that problem 1  is caused by  the hard-coded url in ApplicationOAuth.py  line 100 ff,
which does not allow flexibility in hostname:
```
        headers, data = self._checkError(
            *self._requester.requestJsonAndCheck(
                "POST",
                "https://github.com/login/oauth/access_token",
                headers={"Accept": "application/json"},
                input=post_parameters,
            )
        )
```

I notice that the same problems occur with   ApplicationOAuth.py  function  `refresh_access_token()`.

For now, I bypassed these functions. I can get an access+refresh token by using the `requests` library to post to the correct url,
and then directly building  `auth = Auth.AppUserAuth(  ....  )`   according to the template in [ApplicationOAuth.py  line 123 ff](https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/ed2af241a9a45ee99caca185ae61679bffda5219/github/ApplicationOAuth.py#L123).

comments.body: I think this duplicates #2485.

Thanks for your quick response!  

Yes, problem # 1  above duplicates issue #2485 .

However,  the 2nd problem then remains:   the various `/login/oauth/...` paths do not start with `"/api/"`  and fail the [assertion](https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/ed2af241a9a45ee99caca185ae61679bffda5219/github/Requester.py#L784C14-L784C14) when passed to `requestJsonAndCheck() ... -> __makeAbsoluteUrl()`.
Can you confirm that `f"https://{my_hostname}/login/oauth/access_token"` works in your enterprise installation?

Yes, it does.

My current work-around code for obtaining a new token (given a `code_string` obtained from the web authorization flow):
```
        else :                                                                #  Step 3. We have a code_string. Exchange it for (access_token, refresh_token)
            print( f"{function_name}() -- OK, received authorization code... converting to access_token..." )

            access_t_url = f"https://{my_hostname}/login/oauth/access_token"

            payload = { 'client_id'     : client_info[ 'client_id' ],
                        'client_secret' : client_info[ 'client_secret' ],
                        'code'          : code_string
                      }
            r = requests.post( access_t_url, params=payload )

            if debug : print( f"{function_name}() -- posting to: {r.url}" )
            if debug : print( f"{function_name}() -- response= {r.text}" )    # Step 4: parse the "query parameter string" of the response, and convert it to a "token_dict"
            token_dict = dict( urllib.parse.parse_qsl(r.text) )
            if debug: print( f"{function_name}() -- token_dict={token_dict}" )
```
and similarly for refreshing:
```
    if next_step == 'refresh_token' :                 # If we found a previous, and still valid, refresh_token from tokens_file, use it to get a new token set
        if debug or verbose : print( f"{function_name}() -- Using existing GitHub refresh_token to get new access_token..." )
                                                                              # procedure: see https://docs.github.com/en/apps/creating-github-apps/authenticating-with-a-github-app/refreshing-user-access-tokens#refreshing-a-user-access-token-with-a-refresh-token
        access_t_url = f"https://{my_hostname}/login/oauth/access_token"      # Step 1:  POST request

        payload = { 'client_id'     : client_info[ 'client_id' ],
                    'client_secret' : client_info[ 'client_secret' ],
                    'grant_type'    : 'refresh_token',
                    'refresh_token' : refresh_token
                  }
        r = requests.post( access_t_url, params=payload )

        if debug : print( f"{function_name}() -- posting to: {r.url}" )
        if debug : print( f"{function_name}() -- response= {r.text}" )        # Step 2: parse response
        token_dict = dict( urllib.parse.parse_qsl(r.text) )                   # parse the "query parameter string" of the response, and convert it to a "token_dict"
        if debug: print( f"{function_name}() -- token_dict={token_dict}" )
```

Does this help?

Can you try if the following fix works for you?

    pip install git+https://github.com/enricomi/pygithub.git@oauth-enterprise

Enrico  -- took a bit of hacking. 
Unfortunately the above `pip install` command did not work for our Linux installations, [due to a missing git auxiliary executable `git-remote-https`](https://stackoverflow.com/a/73834366).  An attempt using `git+git` also failed.

So I hacked around it:  I cloned your repo,  found the commit, and copied your updated files into my local 1.59.1 install.  
Worked right away.   Both the new_token and refresh_token flows now work as advertised in https://pygithub.readthedocs.io/en/latest/examples/Authentication.html#app-user-authentication,  as long as all the Github invocations are of the form
```
g = Github( base_url=f"https://{my_hostname}/api/v3" )
```
Thanks for fixing this!

body:
After upgrading to 1.59.0 we got a mypy error on our code catching `UnknownObjectException`:

```
    except github.UnknownObjectException as err:
        message = err.data['message']
```

Now mypy is raising:
```
error: Invalid index type "str" for "str | dict[str, str | list[str] | list[dict[str, str]]]"; expected type "SupportsIndex | slice"  [index]
```

This seems to be caused by the improved type annotation of the `GithubException` base class introduced in #2463:

```
    @property
    def data(
        self,
    ) -> Union[str, Dict[str, Union[str, List[str], List[Dict[str, str]]]]]:
```
Also declared in the `__init__()` signature.

AFAIK `UnknownObjectException` is only raised by `Requester.py` always returning `data` as `output: Dict[str, Any]` so `UnknownObjectException` could be updated to clarify this more accurately so that mypy will not raise typing errors that cannot occur at runtime.

comments.body: @trim21 can you take a look, please?

> AFAIK UnknownObjectException is only raised by Requester.py always returning data as output: Dict[str, Any] so UnknownObjectException could be updated to clarify this more accurately so that mypy will not raise typing errors that cannot occur at runtime.

Yes, I think you are right about this.

because pyi are added before pygithub drop previous python version, they are essential at that time.

title: Basic example is broken

body:
My GitHub app creates a workflow, when installed on an account. I want to delete that same workflow, when the app is uninstalled. So the webhook event is installation with action deleted. 

My PyGitHub version is 1.59.0. The issue seems to be with the line 
**installation = gi.get_app_installation(installation_id)** 

```
auth = github.Auth.AppAuth(app_id, app_key)
gi = github.GithubIntegration(auth=auth)

def handle_webhooks():
    event_type = request.headers.get("X-GitHub-Event")
    payload = request.json
        ...
        if event_type == "installation" and payload["action"] == "deleted":
            installation_id = payload["installation"]["id"]
            installation = gi.get_app_installation(installation_id)
```

although the same kind of authentication works fine, when creating and committing the workflow, meaning that this function: 

```
def create_workflow():
    installation_id = request.json.get("installationId")
    installation = gi.get_app_installation(installation_id)
    workflow_content = "..."
    for repo in installation.get_repos():
        new_file = repo.create_file(
            path=".github/workflows/my-workflow.yml",
            message="Add workflow file",
            content=workflow_content,
            branch="main"
        )
```
works as expected. 

I can provide full error message, if needed.

comments.body: Can you confirm the installation ids are the same in both cases?

Yes.
I think the problem is in the logic, but I am not sure how to fix it - I am trying to delete the workflow along with the app deletion.

My handle webhooks function is waiting for installation event with delete action. 
But by the time i receive the event, the installation is already deleted. So I no longer can access the installation and therefore the repositories to remove the workflow file. I get the exception, because github probably has deleted the object before my call. The way to fix this would be to pause the actual deletion from github, delete the workflow in the installation's repos and then let github delete the installation. But I am not sure this is possible with this approach (event-listening), probably not.

Open to ideas though.

So to summarize:

- the exception is exactly what one should get when trying to access an installation after receiving this event
- the event may be helpful if you have your own database, to remove any records associated with this installation id

This issue isn't related directly to the PyGithub library, so I am going to close it.

Feel free to comment/reopen, if you think it's necessary.

Thanks!

Yes, that makes sense. Your code acts on the installation deletion webhook, so the installation does not exist any more at that point in time. You cannot do any clean-up at that point. There would need to be some kind of pre-delete webhook to do the clean-up before deletion, but that would need to defer the deletion. And since webhooks are async by design, that would be undesirable.

I fear there is currently no way to implement this. Please refer to Github Support, they are very good at pointing to existing functionality or best practice. At least, they can assure you that there is no way to implement this.

title: Installation not found - github.GithubException.UnknownObjectException: 404

body:
<strike>It seems that the signature for `Branch.edit_protection` differs in the `.pyi` and `.py` file. In the [`.pyi`](https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/094538e10c1da6f3bbd31ea1f2d102e48e3649c5/github/Branch.pyi#L38) file the arguments are called `user_bypass_pull_request_allowances`, `team_bypass_pull_request_allowances` and `app_bypass_pull_request_allowances` (not the leading singular) whereas in the [.py`](https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/094538e10c1da6f3bbd31ea1f2d102e48e3649c5/github/Branch.py#L131C4-L131C4) file the arguments are plural (`users_bypass_pull_request_allowances`, `teams_bypass_pull_request_allowances` and `apps_bypass_pull_request_allowances`)</strike> fixed in #2571.

There also seems to be a problem where passing nothing for `user_bypass_pull_request_allowances` results in an error when `require_code_owner_reviews` or `dismiss_stale_reviews` are given:

```
github.GithubException.GithubException: 422 {"message": "Invalid request.\n\nNo subschema in \"anyOf\" matched.\nFor 'properties/bypass_pull_request_allowances', nil is not an object.\nNot all subschemas of \"allOf\" matched.\nFor 'anyOf/1', {\"dismiss_stale_reviews\"=>true, \"require_code_owner_reviews\"=>true, \"bypass_pull_request_allowances\"=>nil} is not a null.", "documentation_url": "https://docs.github.com/rest/branches/branch-protection#update-branch-protection"}
```

https://docs.github.com/en/rest/branches/branch-protection?apiVersion=2022-11-28#update-branch-protection

comments.body: You are right, arguments `users_bypass_pull_request_allowances`, `teams_bypass_pull_request_allowances`, `apps_bypass_pull_request_allowances` are wrong in `pyi` and argument `block_creations` is missing. This is going to be fixed in #2571.

> There also seems to be a problem where passing nothing for `user_bypass_pull_request_allowances` ...

What do you mean with `nothing`, did you set `user_bypass_pull_request_allowances=None` or did you not have the `user_bypass_pull_request_allowances` argument in the method call at all?

> > There also seems to be a problem where passing nothing for `user_bypass_pull_request_allowances` ...
> 
> What do you mean with `nothing`, did you set `user_bypass_pull_request_allowances=None` or did you not have the `user_bypass_pull_request_allowances` argument in the method call at all?

Not having it in the method call at all, e.g.,

```Python
branch.edit_protection(
    require_code_owner_reviews=False,
    dismiss_stale_reviews=False
)
```

Causes the 422 whereas this does work:

```Python
branch.edit_protection(
    require_code_owner_reviews=False,
    dismiss_stale_reviews=False,
    users_bypass_pull_request_allowances=[]
)
```

I also noticed that 

```python
branch.edit_protection(
    require_code_owner_reviews=False,
    dismiss_stale_reviews=False,
    users_bypass_pull_request_allowances=[]
)
```

Doesn't work for fork branches, there is a 422 error which says

```
github.GithubException.GithubException: 422 {"message": "Validation Failed", "errors": ["Only organization repositories can have users and team restrictions"], "documentation_url": "https://docs.github.com/rest/branches/branch-protection#update-branch-protection"}
```

This does work for a forked branch:

```
post_parameters = {
    "required_status_checks": None,
    "enforce_admins": None,
    "required_pull_request_reviews": {
        "dismiss_stale_reviews": False,
        "require_code_owner_reviews": False,
    },
    "restrictions": None,
}
branch._requester.requestJsonAndCheck(
    "PUT",
    forked_github_branch.protection_url,
    headers={"Accept": Consts.mediaTypeRequireMultipleApprovingReviews},
    input=post_parameters,
)
```

Alright, mentioning any of `require_code_owner_reviews` and `dismiss_stale_reviews` adds the `required_pull_request_reviews` field to the requests.

https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/094538e10c1da6f3bbd31ea1f2d102e48e3649c5/github/Branch.py#L245-L255

The `bypass_pull_request_allowances ` field is required but currently omitted when none of users, teams or apps bypass are given.

https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/094538e10c1da6f3bbd31ea1f2d102e48e3649c5/github/Branch.py#L292-L297

Maybe an empty object suffices (as it does for the `dismissal_restrictions` field).

That `dismissal_restrictions` field also mentions
> User and team dismissal_restrictions are only available for organization-owned repositories. Omit this parameter for personal repositories.

There is no such note for `bypass_pull_request_allowances`, but your observation indicates that. To give full control over whether field `users`, `teams` or `apps` exist in the `bypass_pull_request_allowances` object, they should only be added to the `bypass_pull_request_allowances` object when set in the method call.

https://docs.github.com/en/rest/branches/branch-protection?apiVersion=2022-11-28#update-branch-protection
Would you like to create a pull request to fix that logic?
I'll see if I can have a go
Looks like there is a pull request already: #2535

> You are right, arguments `users_bypass_pull_request_allowances`, `teams_bypass_pull_request_allowances`, `apps_bypass_pull_request_allowances` are wrong in `pyi` and argument `block_creations` is missing. This is going to be fixed in #2571.

doesn't look like 2571 will fix thisÔºå it only fix missing arguments
Hi! Any chance we can have the fix for this available in 1.59? We recently updated and now encounter this issue.

title: Calling `Branch.edit_protection` fails when any `required_pull_request_reviews` field set

body:
Hello, 
I have a link for an issue as -> https://github.com/psf/requests/issues/4006 and I am trying to get its pull request ID which should be 4007 according to this link -> https://github.com/psf/requests/pull/4007.

The problem is that when I try to use the following code 
`repo = g.get_repo("psf/requests")
issue = repo.get_issue(number=4006)
pr = issue.as_pull_request()
`

I get a 404 error because the URL resulting from as_pull_request() is https://api.github.com/repos/psf/requests/pulls/4006
**which is WRONG as 4006 is the issue ID not the PR ID**, the correct call should be https://api.github.com/repos/psf/requests/pulls/4007, can someone support me please?

comments.body:
I think you are looking at the wrong feature here.

Github considers a pull request to be an issue, like a sub-class relationship. So given a `PullRequest` instance (with id 4007 in your example), you can get the `Issue` instance of the very same pull request: `PullRequest.as_issue`. That issue has the same id, as it is the Issue-"view" of the pull request itself.

From that `Issue` instance (with id 4007), that actually is a pull request, you can get the `PullRequest` instance: `Issue.as_pull_request`.

This obviously only works for issues that are pull requests.

What you are looking for is the `Issue.pull_request` attribute.
Please reopen if questions remain.

body:
I have a rate limite issue in my app. While debuging, I found a weird behaviour.
The rate limit changes after a call to `totalCount`.

```python
client = Github("TOKEN")
commits = client.search_commits(query = 'author:LucBerge')
print(client.rate_limiting)
commits.totalCount
print(client.rate_limiting)
```

Output
> (4344, 5000)
(28, 30)

I know the [rate limit changes if the user is authenticated or not.](https://docs.github.com/en/rest/overview/resources-in-the-rest-api?apiVersion=2022-11-28#rate-limiting) Could it be related ?

Maybe the call to `totalCount` unauthentify the client (remove the token) ?
Or the `totalCount` request is performed without the token ?

comments.body:
This is specific to the `search_*` methods in the `Github` class.

I don't have any issue with:

```python
client = Github("TOKEN")
commits = client.get_repo('LucBerge/github_email_collector').get_commits()
print(client.rate_limiting)
commits.totalCount
print(client.rate_limiting)
```

Output:
> (4992, 5000)
(4991, 5000)

[It looks like the rate limit is not the same for search requests](https://docs.github.com/en/rest/search?apiVersion=2022-11-28)

It means that PyGithub display the rate limit depending on the last request type made to Github.

In [Requester.py:550](https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/master/github/Requester.py#L550), rate_limit is set to last returned value. This value detends on the request type.

```python
        status, responseHeaders, output = self.__requestRaw(
            cnx, verb, url, requestHeaders, encoded_input
        )

        if (
            Consts.headerRateRemaining in responseHeaders
            and Consts.headerRateLimit in responseHeaders
        ):
            self.rate_limiting = (
                int(responseHeaders[Consts.headerRateRemaining]),
                int(responseHeaders[Consts.headerRateLimit]),
            )
```
**It would be nice to make the difference between search requests and others.**
Yes, I think this is bug #1988. Would you like to sketch a pull request to fix this?

Is `GithubIntegration.get_access_token` known to be broken currently, or am I overlooking something?

comments.body: If after your code changes, your code does not work with the pygithub version that worked for 2 months, than your code changes might have caused it. How do you create `github_integration`? What value does `installation_id` have?

@EnricoMi Thanks for the reply, and the initial hint.

I was indeed not using the correct `installation_id`, which explains the 404 I was getting.
To be frank, the error message could be a bit more clear, shouldn't PyGithub be able to report that the `installation_id` is incorrect?

After making sure I was using the correct `integration_id` (to create the `GithubIntegration` instance), and the correct `installation_id` when calling `get_access_token`, I was running into another problem:
```
github.GithubException.GithubException: 401 {"message": "A JSON web token could not be decoded", "documentation_url": "https://docs.github.com/rest"}
```

This made me scratch my head a bit again, but I then realized that I wasn't using the correct private key when creating the `GithubIntegration` instance.

Once that was fixed, it's working as expected again (with PyGithub 1.58.2 and Python 3.9).

Thanks a lot for giving me a push in the right direction!

I think this shows that error reporting could be a bit more informative, would you agree?

You basically need to make sure that the `integration_id`, `private_key`, and `installation_id` are in sync. While that makes perfect sense of course, it isn't easy to deduce that from the error messages I was presented.

Do you think there's room for improvement there?
I'm happy to try and take a stab at making a pull request myself, if only to help my future self which is no doubt to hit problems like this again in the not-so-distant future...

Method `GithubIntegration.get_access_token` should check that `integration_id` is an `int`. This type of check is pretty standard throughout the code base, but is missing here.

    assert isinstance(installation_id, (int, str)), installation_id

What other checks would you suggest?

`integration_id` was an `int` in my case, but the value was wrong (I was switching between different GitHub Apps & installations to test my code with).

I'm not sure if it's possible, or how easy it would be, but PyGithub could check:

* When the `GithubIntegration` instance is created, `PyGithub` should do a sanity check on both the `integration_id` (does it exist?) and the private key (does it match with the specified `integration_id`), and produce a meaningful error if there's a mismatch.
* If the `installation_id` exists, and produce a meaningful error message when it doesn't ("GitHub App installation with ID 12345 does not exist");

Again, I'm not sure how easy/hard this is, but more meaningful error messages would definitely have helped me to understand where I was wrong.

The code base in this project tries to minimize Github API calls. All that methods can check are the provided arguments. Checking if objects exist (like installation id) should be redundant, because a 404 error is raised as soon as that invalid id is used. So `UnknownObjectException` should be good enough.

Your first error (`TypeError: __init__() missing 1 required positional argument: 'headers'`) is a known bug and should be fixed: #2079 #2324

PyGithub does have retry logic, see `github.Github(retry=...)`.

Since you mention "not found": do you mean that the API responds with "404 NOT FOUND"? That would be a non-retry-able response, because the server responded to your call. That is not a network disconnect. In that case, it is a Github issue and should be solved with their support.

Hello,

When running the below code,
```
from github import Github

query = repo.get_contents(cfg.Github["QueryPath"], cfg.Github["Branch"])

```
I run into this error

`Type: <class 'requests.exceptions.ConnectTimeout'>, Value: HTTPSConnectionPool(host='[api.github.com](http://api.github.com/)', port=443): Max retries exceeded with url: /repos/abcd/xxxx (Caused by ConnectTimeoutError(<urllib3.connection.HTTPSConnection object at 0x7f75390c04d0>, 'Connection to [api.github.com](http://api.github.com/) timed out. (connect timeout=15)')).`

1. Is this a rate limit issue or something else?
2. If I need to add retry logic, how do I do that

Thank You.

comments.body:
This issue is unrelated to rate limits as the connection cannot be established in the first place. Github servers seem to be too busy.

You can configure retries via the `retry` argument:

```python
g = Github(githubToken, retry=10)
```

You can configure more complex retry logic as follows:

```python
from urllib3.util import Retry

g = Github(githubToken, retry=Retry(10))
```

See https://urllib3.readthedocs.io/en/stable/reference/urllib3.util.html#urllib3.util.Retry for all available options.
Got it. I will try this. Thank you @EnricoMi

May be a dupe of #1753 ?

> May be a dupe of #1753 ?

I don't think so - #1753 appears to be about user token credentials. This issue seems to be specific to installation objects. A quick reading of the source shows that the Installation is using the same requester (and same jwt) as the parent integration object (see [GithubIntegration.py line 75-87](https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/master/github/GithubIntegration.py#L75C1-L87)). I think the installation needs an installation token (weirdly enough, fetched using `Integration.get_access_token`) before it would be capable of querying properties of the installation. Using the integration jwt clearly doesn't work.
Yes, looks like the installation has to use an installation token, not the application (integration) jwt. That whole auth looks like needing an rework: #2461

comments.body:
If you're trying to access repositories on a GitHub Enterprise Server (e.g. a company-specific GitHub instance at github.company_name.com), you'll need to provide a different base URL when creating your PyGitHub instance.

``` python
from github import Github

# create a PyGithub instance using your GitHub API token and base URL
g = Github("your-github-api-token", base_url="https://github.company_name.com/api/v3")

# get a specific user or organization by name
user = g.get_user("username")

```

In the above code, we create a PyGitHub instance using our GitHub API token and the base URL for our GitHub Enterprise Server. We then get a specific user or organization by name using the `get_user` method.

Adds the `allow_auto_merge` attribute to a Repository: https://docs.github.com/en/rest/repos/repos#update-a-repository

> `allow_auto_merge` boolean
> Either `true` to allow auto-merge on pull requests, or `false` to disallow auto-merge.

This attribute can be modified via edit (on a private repository):

```
>>> g.get_repo("<test repo>").allow_auto_merge
True
>>> g.get_repo("<test repo>").edit(allow_auto_merge=False)
>>> g.get_repo("<test repo>").allow_auto_merge
False
>>> g.get_repo("<test repo>").edit(allow_auto_merge=True)
>>> g.get_repo("<test repo>").allow_auto_merge
True
```

title: Add support of `allow_auto_merge` attribute to Repository

body:
Currently, the PyGithub library does not provide a method for cloning a repository to a local directory. This feature would be useful for a variety of use cases, such as automated backups, data processing, or testing.

The `clone_to()` method would allow users to clone a repository to a local directory using the GitHub API, without requiring the use of the `git` command line tool. This method would simplify the process of cloning a repository and make it more accessible to users who are not familiar with `git`.

It is important to note that the `clone_to()` method should be designed to run in a single-threaded environment since Cloud functions do not support multiprocessing. However, the method should be optimized for performance and resource usage.

## Example Usage

```python
from github import Github

g = Github("<access_token>")
repo = g.get_repo("<repo_owner>/<repo_name>")
repo.clone_to("<local_directory>")

```

This method would be particularly useful for automated processes that require the use of GitHub repositories, such as continuous integration or deployment pipelines. It would allow users to automate the process of cloning repositories without relying on external tools.

comments.body: This would require support from the GitHub REST API, and I can't see anything like that in the official docs. I would suggest reaching out to https://support.github.com/

title: Add clone_to() method for cloning repositories

body:
The changelog for the project states it ["switched" to semantic versioning](https://pygithub.readthedocs.io/en/latest/changes.html#version-1-8-0-september-30th-2012) in version 1.8

I'm seeing a lot of new versions listing "Breaking Changes" without an actual bump to the major version.
Some example releases that mention breaking changes:
https://pygithub.readthedocs.io/en/latest/changes.html#version-1-57-november-05-2022
https://pygithub.readthedocs.io/en/latest/changes.html#version-1-55-april-26-2021

Is there a way that users can shield themselves from breaking changes excluding pinning a fixed version in their project's dependency?

comments.body:
You are right, from the change log it looks like this project does not follow semantic versioning any more.

Even for unintended breaks like #1986 it takes maintainers a month to review, merge and release quick fixes. So it is unlikely to get quick patch releases fixing unintended breaks.

From this experience, I recommend to pin the PyGithub version, and brace for integration work when upgrading to a higher minor version.

title: Does PyGitHub follow semantic versioning?

body:
Hello there,

It seems like the `base_url` passed to the default constructor is not used to fetch the access token for app authentication.

Here's an example code:
```
app_id = "XXX"
app_private_key = "XXX"
installation_id = "XXX"
g = github.Github(
    base_url="https://custom-github-url.com"
    app_auth=github.AppAuthentication(
        app_id=app_id,
        private_key=app_private_key,
        installation_id=installation_id,
    ),
)
```

Whatever `base_url` is passed, the following error occurs:
`requests.exceptions.ConnectionError: HTTPSConnectionPool(host='api.github.com', port=443): Max retries exceeded with url: XXX`

As can be seen in the stack trace, the host is the one defined [here](https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/5e27c10a3140c3b9bbf71a0b71c96e71e1e3496c/github/Consts.py#L135), which is `DEFAULT_BASE_URL = "https://api.github.com"`.

I suspect the error comes from [here](https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/5e27c10a3140c3b9bbf71a0b71c96e71e1e3496c/github/Requester.py#L377). The param `base_url` is not passed to `GithubIntegration` which therefore uses the default url.

comments.body: This is been reported in #2420 and fixed in #2425. Will be released in [v0.58.1](https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/milestone/39).

I tested with master today and while `base_url` is propagated, `verified` is not. `verified` is a bool or string and the string is needed when the enterprise installation uses a SSL/TLS certificate that is not issued by a root ca in pythons included ca bundle.

We're getting there though!

[Edit] Submitted PR https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/pull/2455 to fix the verify propagate issue, but then while refreshing the access token, a check for expiring access token is done which then refreshes the access token, which checks the token ... until recursion limit is met.
The fix has been released.

> but then while refreshing the access token, a check for expiring access token is done which then refreshes the access token, which checks the token ... until recursion limit is met.

@goldstar611 I could not reproduce this issue, and looking into the code, I could not see how this would recurse. The refresh request creates its own new requester instance. Can you provide a stack trace? That would help to investigate the issue.
Yes let me get my VM set back up and I'll provide a log.

I tested both the `Github` class with a personal access token as well as the `GithubIntegration` class with a private key and did not see this issue again.

I remember what happened however. I changed the host name (sometimes we use a domain suffix inside our LAN) and that caused the Github appliance to send a redirect. This can be reproduced with the following test case but, IMO, it's user error.

```python
from github import Github

# Github Enterprise with custom hostname
g = Github(base_url="https://www.github.com/api/v3",
#                            ^^^^ notice the www.
           login_or_token="doesn't matter what it is",)
print(g.get_user().name)
```
Thank you for the input. I think PyGithub should identify this situation and raise an error and not follow the redirection. This is going to be fixed in #2524.

@jodelasur maybe you had package `jwt` installed, which conflicts with `PyJWT`, which is a dependency of `PyGithub`?

If you'd uninstall `jwt` and reinstalled `PyGithub`, it should work.

title: Add cryptography as dependency (for app-based auth)

body:
To support data exchange, being able to serialize non-JSON-serializable `GithubObject`s has been easily achieved in past with `pickle`. However, starting with v1.58, `GithubObject`s like `Repository`, `NamedUser`, etc. are no longer serializable with with `pickle`,

For example,
```py
import github
import pickle

repo = github.Github().get_repo(full_name_or_id="PyGithub/PyGithub")
pickle.dumps(repo)
```
raise the following exception:
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/joshfell/code/daedalus/tempCodeRunnerFile.python", line 15, in <module>
    pickle.dumps(repo)
  File "/usr/local/Cellar/python@3.10/3.10.9/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.10/lib/python3.10/multiprocessing/synchronize.py", line 101, in __getstate__
    context.assert_spawning(self)
  File "/usr/local/Cellar/python@3.10/3.10.9/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.10/lib/python3.10/multiprocessing/context.py", line 373, in assert_spawning
    raise RuntimeError(
RuntimeError: RLock objects should only be shared between processes through inheritance
```

The underyling `Requester` object now has an `RLock()` attribute, `__auth_lock`, which looks to be preventing this serialization.

comments.body:
Pickle allows `Requester` to exclude the lock from being serialized:
https://docs.python.org/3/library/pickle.html#handling-stateful-objects

And we should add tests that prove pickle support.
@EnricoMi, Thanks for taking a look so quickly and the tip on the `pickle` workaround!

title: GithubObjects are no longer serializable with `pickle`

hi, just as a data point, we're running into this with [get_org_installation()](https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/v1.58.2/github/GithubIntegration.py#L175), as well. we know it [always uses a fresh token](https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/v1.58.2/github/GithubIntegration.py#L83), just like `get_access_token()` per [this PR](https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/pull/2460), so we're not sure what's going on there.
This will be fixed in #2528.

just to confirm as we're implementing a workaround before #2528 is merged and released. the problem is that the integration object [creates and caches a JWT](https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/217d4241872f428963f7cd959cf5baeec370f698/github/GithubIntegration.py#L52) which [then gets used in the Authorization header](https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/master/github/Requester.py#L651) as the request to retrieve an installed app's metadata is sent out, and so it wouldn't matter whether the integration refreshes the token in [get_org_installation()](https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/v1.58.2/github/GithubIntegration.py#L175)? is this correct? if I'm not mistaken, creating a new `GithubIntegration` before each attempt to call `get_org_installation()` should fix this in the meantime, right?

> @cvirtucio that is what we use in our case
> 
> that puts more load on GH API, but the only solution
> 
> see https://github.com/canonical/gh-jira-sync-bot/blob/0ec40e03c4b634ccad446c525f6b49ba430e3dc6/github_jira_sync_app/main.py#L138

what we ended up doing was cache the integration and refresh the cache when we hit a `401`. that should offset the load a bit.

Please test #2528:

    pip install git+https://github.com/enricomi/pygithub.git@requester-auth-rework

@EnricoMi looks to work good on our end, will continue testing for another day !
thanks for putting it together!
fix works for us, as well

title: 401 unauthorized after upgrading to 1.58.0

body:
1.58 introduces a dependency on multiprocessing.RLock which it not compatible with AWS Lambda. multiprocessing.SemLock (used by RLock in Requester.py) will raise OSError [Errno 38] Function not implemented. This is caused by /dev/shm not being available in AWS Lamba.

I don't have a workaround and downgraded to 1.57 which works fine.

comments.body: Confirmed. This broke our Lambda deployments too. Thanks for reporting.
This broke our Lambda deployments as well..

Can you please provide the full stacktrace?

Is the error thrown on `import`, when calling `RLock()` or when entering the `with` context.
It's when calling `RLock()`. I'll find the stacktrace in a few minutes.

```
    2023-02-20T21:17:16.480+00:00   File "/var/task/github/MainClass.py", line 122, in __init__
    2023-02-20T21:17:16.480+00:00   self.__requester = Requester(
    2023-02-20T21:17:16.480+00:00   File "/var/task/github/Requester.py", line 316, in __init__
    2023-02-20T21:17:16.480+00:00   self.__auth_lock = RLock()
    2023-02-20T21:17:16.480+00:00   File "/var/lang/lib/python3.9/multiprocessing/context.py", line 73, in RLock
    2023-02-20T21:17:16.480+00:00   return RLock(ctx=self.get_context())
    2023-02-20T21:17:16.480+00:00   File "/var/lang/lib/python3.9/multiprocessing/synchronize.py", line 187, in __init__
    2023-02-20T21:17:16.480+00:00   SemLock.__init__(self, RECURSIVE_MUTEX, 1, 1, ctx=ctx)
    2023-02-20T21:17:16.480+00:00   File "/var/lang/lib/python3.9/multiprocessing/synchronize.py", line 57, in __init__
    2023-02-20T21:17:16.480+00:00   sl = self._semlock = _multiprocessing.SemLock(
    2023-02-20T21:17:16.480+00:00   OSError: [Errno 38] Function not implemented
    ```

I'd suggest to wrap `self.__auth_lock = RLock()` with a try block and fall back assigning an no-op context manager to `self.__auth_lock`. This way the usage of the lock in `with self.__auth_lock:` will still work, though there is no locking. Does not hurt since there is no concurrency anyway.

Someone here volunteering to draft a PR for this?

I faced a similar issue in AWS Lambda after upgrading to 1.58. In my case I got a `FileNotFoundError` exception when calling the main class `Github`:

```
  File ... line 42, in create_pull_request
    gh = Github(gh_access_token)
  File \"/home/app/github/MainClass.py\", line 122, in __init__
    self.__requester = Requester(
  File \"/home/app/github/Requester.py\", line 316, in __init__
    self.__auth_lock = RLock()
  File \"/usr/lib/python3.10/multiprocessing/context.py\", line 73, in RLock
    return RLock(ctx=self.get_context())
  File \"/usr/lib/python3.10/multiprocessing/synchronize.py\", line 187, in __init__
    SemLock.__init__(self, RECURSIVE_MUTEX, 1, 1, ctx=ctx)
  File \"/usr/lib/python3.10/multiprocessing/synchronize.py\", line 57, in __init__
    sl = self._semlock = _multiprocessing.SemLock(
FileNotFoundError: [Errno 2] No such file or directory"
```
Confirmed this broke our lambda too, thank you for reporting
Given that it broke **all** Lambdas, would it be possible to cut a new bugfix release ASAP üôèüèª?

title: Cannot import name 'Github' from 'github'

body: While reading https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/pull/309 it looked like https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/issues/172 was addressed however I am still unable to find a way to set up a proxy. Was this never done? or am I just not finding how to set up a proxy?

comments.body:
PyGitHub uses the Python package `requests` under the hood to do the HTTP calls. The requests package supports environment variables to configure proxies:

https://requests.readthedocs.io/en/latest/user/advanced/#proxies

```
export HTTP_PROXY="http://10.10.1.10:3128"
export HTTPS_PROXY="http://10.10.1.10:1080"
export ALL_PROXY="socks5://10.10.1.10:3434"
```

These environment variables are pretty standard. Many applications and libraries use them. So there is no need to tell PyGitHub about proxies, the requests package will pick that up on its own.

It also supports HTTP basic auth. See the docs above on how to setup proxy settings.

Many thanks for taking the time to reply

The issue I was having was not while running local, a Flask application using PyGitHub had no problem to pick up the Proxy variables 

The issue was with the application deployed, the inner request PyGitHub was doing was not picking up the proxy 

Just sharing in case anyone else is having this issue, my problem was that I was missing to add the proxy settings in my program.service

```
[Service]
User=XXXXXx
Group=XXXXX
WorkingDirectory=/home/XXXXX/XXXX
Environment=https_proxy=http://XXX.XXX.XX.X:XXXX
Environment=https_proxy=http://XXX.XXX.XX.X:XXXX
```

Thanks again for the help!
