body:
Hi,

I was investigating how to implement the new options around default commit messages when merging a pull request:

https://github.blog/changelog/2022-08-23-new-options-for-controlling-the-default-commit-message-when-merging-a-pull-request/ 

Based on the above this can be implemented via the API using:
`squash_merge_commit_title` and `squash_merge_commit_message` as seen on the API: https://docs.github.com/en/rest/repos/repos#update-a-repository

I can't find this being implemented on `PyGithub` but I can see we can modify on the `edit` repo the type of merge: https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/master/github/Repository.py#L1564-L1566

Is this something that people would be interested about?

Thanks,

comments.body:
+1 

hacking this for now with:
```python
        requester: Requester = self._client._Github__requester     # type: ignore

        # squash merging commits default to pull request title and description
        post_parameters = {
            "squash_merge_commit_title": "PR_TITLE",
            "squash_merge_commit_message": "PR_BODY"
        }
        _, _ = requester.requestJsonAndCheck(
            "POST", f"{requester.base_url}/repos/{org_name}/{repo_name}", input=post_parameters
        )
```

Looks like all is needed here is adding the `squash_*` attributes to `Repository`. Any volunteers?

https://docs.github.com/en/rest/repos/repos?apiVersion=2022-11-28#update-a-repository
Thanks @EnricoMi I've raised #2700 for this.

title: Missing new options for controlling the default commit title on the Repository

body:
Hi all,

I have a script running where I collect stats for different organizations on a weekly basis. The script has run fine multiple times, but only recently there has been a problem where the API call returns a 502 server error.

As an example, for a certain organization and it's repos, I ran the script and it gave me a 502 error, but then a few minutes later it ran as intended and gave me the correct results.

Any idea what could be the issue here? Is it totally on Github's end, or is there something I am missing on my end? Since the script has ran as intended a fair few times before, don't think it can be an issue on my end.

Anyone else facing this issue?

Thanks for the help!

comments.body:
The 502 error is on GitHub's end, and as you say it is transient. It can happen any time. Retrying your request should be the best strategy here.

Provide a `urllib3.util.retry.Retry` instance to PyGithub, that is configured to retry 5xx responses on all types of requests:

```python
from urllib3.util.retry import Retry
g = Github("access_token", retry=Retry(status_forcelist=list(range(500, 600)), allowed_methods={'DELETE', 'GET', 'HEAD', 'OPTIONS', ,'POST', 'PUT', 'TRACE'}))
```

Then PyGithub will retry requests that fail with 5xx errors for you.

https://urllib3.readthedocs.io/en/stable/reference/urllib3.util.html
Thank you very much, will implement this!

Hello,

I am currently using https://docs.github.com/en/rest/commits/commits#list-pull-requests-associated-with-a-commit via `Requests` to fetch pull request data associated by commit. I am interested in switching to PyGithub but am not seeing if this is currently supported by `get_pull()` (only `param` is the PR number), any other approach I can use?

Can I get all pull data (i.e, `html_url`, `title`) associated by a known SHA/commit?

https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/master/github/Repository.py#L2815

comments.body:
Hi @AaronMT ,

[github.Commit.Commit.get_pulls](https://pygithub.readthedocs.io/en/latest/github_objects/Commit.html#github.Commit.Commit.get_pulls) implements the mentioned Path, you can call it by iterating over commits of a repository and get a list of [PullRequest](https://pygithub.readthedocs.io/en/latest/github_objects/PullRequest.html) Objects back:

> adding `since` to `get_commits` to limit requests :slightly_smiling_face: 

```python
    repo = client.get_repo("PyGithub/PyGithub")

    for commit in repo.get_commits(since=datetime(year=2022, month=11, day=1)):
        for pull in commit.get_pulls():
            print(f"sha|{commit.sha} pull|{pull.title}")
```

.. or directly query it for a known SHA:

```python
    repo = client.get_repo("PyGithub/PyGithub")
    commit = repo.get_commit("7902351d4fa501dc108dbf3724e93831d922f582")

    for pull in commit.get_pulls():
        print(f"sha|{commit.sha} pull|{pull.title}")
```

[PullRequest](https://pygithub.readthedocs.io/en/latest/github_objects/PullRequest.html) Objects have a [title](https://pygithub.readthedocs.io/en/latest/github_objects/PullRequest.html#github.PullRequest.PullRequest.title) as well as a [html_url](https://pygithub.readthedocs.io/en/latest/github_objects/PullRequest.html#github.PullRequest.PullRequest.html_url) Property :slightly_smiling_face: 

Does that help?
Yes, thanks.

body:
As I'm already familiar with lazy objects & workflows, I would like it to have `lazy==True` to be the default. But because this may be not the best for everyone, I propose adding a default lazy argument to the initial `Github` class constructor which becomes the default for every method called by it. If I gain some time, I will look into implementing it myself. However if someone else is faster to implement it, feel free to implement & submit it yourself.

This may be implemented by adding a variable to `Github` which holds the global default, can be set by using the constructor and defaults to `False` (to keep the current behavior the default). Then every method supporting lazy behavior may either look up this global default by itself or a decorator is implemented which replaces the lazy parameter by itself. The default for the method's argument should be set to `None`. Then the following comparison code can be used to resolve the value to use:
```python
lazy_global_default if lazy_method_arg is None else lazy_method_arg
```

(This issue serves as a reminder for myself.)

PS: This library looks really good & is easy to use, thanks for the work.

Hello,

Is there any support for artifacts? Meaning request `/repos/{owner}/{repo}/actions/artifacts` . I could not find anything and I would like to rewrite an existing script which purges artifacts using module `requests` into one using module `github`.

comments.body: Hi @lelegard, I've made a PR for adding artifacts support: https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/issues/2313. I will appreciate if you can check it out.

Hi @lexa 

Thanks a lot for the prompt improvement, much appreciated.

I have a few questions. To give you an idea of what is done, the script I would like to update is here: https://github.com/tsduck/tsduck/blob/master/.github/maintenance/purge-artifacts.py

This script still uses the `requests` module. The other scripts in the same directory were already converted to `PyGithub`.

The required methods for the artifacts script are (with links to the API docs):
1. [List all artifacts of a repo](https://docs.github.com/en/rest/actions/artifacts#list-artifacts-for-a-repository)
2. [Delete an artifact](https://docs.github.com/en/rest/actions/artifacts#delete-an-artifact)

Quickly browsing through the changes in your PR, I do not see the way to achieve this.
- There is a method to get the artifacts of a workflow run, but no method `get_artifacts()` in class `Repository`, for all artifacts in the repository (requirement 1).
- I see no method to delete an artifact in class `Artifact`. 
- Given the [way it works in the REST API](https://docs.github.com/en/rest/actions/artifacts#delete-an-artifact), it could be appropriate to add a method `remove_artifact(int_id)` in class `Repository`, consistent with other "remove" methods in that class (requirement 2).

Thanks for your help.

Thanks @lelegard  for checking out my PR.

>There is a method to get the artifacts of a workflow run, but no method get_artifacts() in class Repository, for all artifacts in the repository (requirement 1).

added in the commit https://github.com/lexa/PyGithub/commit/b07bdf3f4e0dcd63db245c59d8e72a8263b895e0

>I see no method to delete an artifact in class Artifact.

added in the commit https://github.com/lexa/PyGithub/commit/fc4e77fb0e13e11ce057cafc65786b98f9e0d28e

Unfortunately I can't test it, because I don't have any artifacts to delete. Could you please test if for me?

To run the test you need to amend https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/pull/2319/commits/36f7fefb8fd78e2b421f38d296b2eb30639f2d10#diff-290729c59eb604d2187e1aa53a36ad692922094ca021239df18330436df52429R45

to set `artifact_id` and `repo_name` to the repo and artifact id you want to remove and then run:
```
pytest  tests/Artifact.py -k testDelete --record
```

It should pass. As the result of the run you will get a recording file `tests/ReplayData/Artifact.testDelete.txt` which i need to include in my PR.

> Given the [way it works in the REST API](https://docs.github.com/en/rest/actions/artifacts#delete-an-artifact), it could be appropriate to add a method remove_artifact(int_id) in class Repository, consistent with other "remove" methods in that class (requirement 2).

I think that is enought to have `delete` method on the `Artifact` itself. What is the point of having `remove_artifact()` in `Repository` if you need to create `Artifact` to get its id?

Hi @lexa 

I will have a look at the update.

> I think that is enought to have delete method on the Artifact itself. What is the point of having remove_artifact() in Repository if you need to create Artifact to get its id?

Functionally, you are right. This was just a suggestion.

In principle, it would match the REST API where there is a call on the repo, specifying the id of the artifact to delete. But you may consider that the class structure in PyGithub is designed to hide this functional approach.

In practice, this is a way to simplify the code structure when you have to browse through all artifacts of a repo and delete some of them. There is a pitfall in the Github API about "paginated" lists. When you iterate page by page (say 100 items per page), reading the "next page" is not "starting after the last returned item", this is "page number 2", meaning "starting at item number 101". If you iterate on items without deleting or creating any, it does not make a difference. However, when you list all "items" (artifacts for instance), decide which should be deleted and delete them, then you have a problem. Let's take an example: in the first page (items 1 to 100), you decide to delete 10 of them. Then, moving to "next page" means "start at item 101, _after the deletion_, meaning that items which were numbered 101 to 110 before deletion are missed because they are now numbered 91 to 100.

The problem is real, I ran into it with the REST API and with PyGithub `PaginatedList`. It took me some time to understand why my purge script randomly missed some artifacts and I had to run it several times to do a complete purge.

So, in practice, you need a first pass where you read the items to delete, store their id in some list. Then, during a second pass, you delete the items by id. This is [what my script does](https://github.com/tsduck/tsduck/blob/master/.github/maintenance/purge-artifacts.py) and now it always works at the first run.

I also had the issue, initially, with [this script](https://github.com/tsduck/tsduck/blob/master/.github/maintenance/close-pending.py) which closes issues with a certain label (and then remove the label). Since the issues are browsed using `repo.get_issues(labels = ['close pending'])`, removing the label of one issue while browsing changes the numbering of issues with that label when the next page is transparently fetched by the iterator at some point.

This is a particularly nasty behaviour that I haven't seen documented anywhere, neither in the Github API doc nor in the PyGithub doc. Once you understand it, it makes sense. But it may take some time to understand it.

If is perfectly possible to build and store a list of instances of `Artifact` during the first pass and then invoke their `delete()` method in the second pass. I thought it would be faster and less resource-demanding to store only a list of integer ids during the first pass and then delete them by id using the instance of `Repository`.

However, this is just the rationale for my suggestion. We can live without it and feel free to ignore it if you do not like it.

Hi @lexa,

I have converted my [purge-artifact script here](https://github.com/tsduck/tsduck/blob/master/.github/maintenance/purge-artifacts-new.py). It works perfectly.

Forget about the suggestion to provide a delete_artifact method by id in the ` Repository` class. I used a list of `Artifact` instances.

Currently, I keep the two versions of the scripts, one using the REST API and one using your updated `PyGithub`. When do you think the updated version of `PyGithub` will be available in PyPI?

Thanks again @lexa for the update.

>Currently, I keep the two versions of the scripts, one using the REST API and one using your updated PyGithub. When do you think the updated version of PyGithub will be available in PyPI?

No idea, but considering that the last activity on this repo was in december 2021 you shouldn't expect that it will ever reach the upstream.

> No idea, but considering that the last activity on this repo was in december 2021 you shouldn't expect that it will ever reach the upstream.

Too bad... Any idea on who is managing the project these days ?

comments.body:
My guess is an unfortunate `python` install.

What does `python -c 'import sys;print(sys.path)'` give?
For example, mine gives,
```
euclid% python -c 'import sys;print(sys.path)' 
['', '/usr/lib/python310.zip', '/usr/lib/python3.10', '/usr/lib/python3.10/lib-dynload', '/home/jamison/.local/lib/python3.10/site-packages', '/usr/lib/python3.10/site-packages']
```
which includes the path which my `pygithub` is installed,
```
euclid% pip show pygithub
Name: PyGithub
Version: 1.55
...
Location: /home/jamison/.local/lib/python3.10/site-packages
...
```
---
fwiw, I _might_ have been able to reproduce this the first time I started a `zsh` shell. I patched the script to,
```
import github

print(github.Github.get_user("Riffecs"))
```
(this is how I personally prefer important packages), and it's worked since, but probably just coincidence.
Hi @jl-applied I took a picture for the sake of simplicity. ```python -c 'import sys;print(sys.path)'``` ```pip show pygithub```

Sorry. I pressed the wrong button.
Even if I add the path in the ZSH as Python Path it does not work. What am I doing wrong?

Something seems strange with your environment/python install. The original post showed `python --version` pointing to `python3.10` and now it is not found.

I'm not an expert here, but I don't think your shell's `PATH` is all that relevant. Maybe python relies on it to infer what the `sys.path` should be, but that inevitably is where it will look for packages to `import` -- (there is also an analogous `PYTHONPATH` variable to append a path through the shell env).

Given the outputs above, I would suspect `python3 -c 'import github'` should work. If not, maybe also try `python3.8 -c 'import github'`

---
Also, it you want to use `python3.10`, you'll probably want to explicitly install `pip3.10`. Using `python3.10` will not be aware of packages installed with `pip3.8` (unless you explicitly allow this i.e. with altering your `PYTHONPATH` which is probably not recommended).

It seems to me that you installed correctly the packages for python3.10, but in your environment python3.8 has a higher priority so it gets executed (and there you don't have the packages you need).

Launch your script as `python3.10 repo.py` or, if you want to use the interpreter manually, `python3.10` instead of `python3`.
If it correctly works, you may want to update the reference to python3.10 with `update-alternatives` ([here](https://www.kalilinux.in/2021/05/update-alternatives-error-no-alternatives-for-python3.html) you find an example for kali, but for ubuntu the steps are the same).

Thank you for your help. I just reinstalled Ubuntu. Thereby there was only the 3.8 version. Well, then I just live with it. Apparently it can import github as PyGitHub. The code below is from @jl-applied from the issue. But what I don't understand is why this doesn't work with Python 3.10. 
Greetings @Riffecs

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/102326693/180860125-f04410bd-cff8-453e-b8fe-a14ed9c97d8f.png)

To be clear, it is perfectly normal to have multiple versions of python installed (I have `3.6`-`3.10` installed personally). That being said, it can definitely complicates things a bit.

Moreover, similar to python, the minor version of `pip` is also relevant here and must match the version of python you intended to use.

Whenever in doubt, you can always invoke the specific versions of either directly with `python3.10` and `pip3.10`. If you installed `python3.10` and `pip3.10` now and use them directly, I suspect it would work (it worked for me at least).

---

As for you new issue, I too was getting this when debugging and seems like the code provided has some issue (maybe you're missing initializing this `Github` object without an access_token,
```
print(g('your_access_token_here').get_user("Riffecs"))
```
), but I'll let someone with more experience with this particular package speak to that. Good luck :)

Hello people. 
Thanks for all your help. I will now close the issue. 
With kind regards

body:
Dear all,
in using the `merge` function I noticed that, even when the only allowed possibility is `squash and merge`, the commits do not get squashed automatically. Here is a minimal code to reproduce my results:

```
from github import Github
import os

GITHUB_TOKEN = os.getenv("GITHUB_TOKEN")


def create_pr_and_merge():
    git = Github(login_or_token=GITHUB_TOKEN)
    repository = git.get_repo("my-repo")
    branch = "test-branch"

    repository.create_file(message="Adding file",
                           path="my_file.py",
                           branch=branch,
                           content="# Some interesting content")

    repository.create_pull(title="Ticket nr. XXX",
                           body="",
                           head=branch,
                           base="master")

    repository.merge(base="master",
                     head=branch,
                     commit_message="Bug fix")


if __name__ == "__main__":
    create_pr_and_merge()
```

Given the automatic squash, I would expect to see only one commit message, i.e. "Ticket nr. XXX". Instead, I see both the latter and "Adding file", which is undesired behavior. Any ideas why this is the case?

comments.body:
Just found the right way to do it, that I will report for completeness and close the issue:

```
from github import Github
import os

GITHUB_TOKEN = os.getenv("GITHUB_TOKEN")


def create_pr_and_merge():
    git = Github(login_or_token=GITHUB_TOKEN)
    repository = git.get_repo("my-repo")
    branch = "test-branch"

    repository.create_file(message="Adding file",
                           path="my_file.py",
                           branch=branch,
                           content="# Some interesting content")

    repository.create_pull(title="Ticket nr. XXX",
                           body="",
                           head=branch,
                           base="master").merge(merge_method='squash')


if __name__ == "__main__":
    create_pr_and_merge()
```

Thank's a lot!

comments.body:
my first example is. but this is not the final solution :(

```python
def get_commits_of_ref(self, repo, ref_name):
    ''' return commits of ref '''
    # init commits
    commits = []

    # get head commit
    if self.check_if_branch_exist(repo, ref_name):
        current_commit = repo.get_branch(ref_name).commit
    elif self.check_if_tag_exist(repo, ref_name):
        current_commit = self.get_tag(repo, ref_name).commit
    else:
        return commits

    # get commit info
    while True:
        commit_info = {}
        commit_info['message'] = current_commit.commit.message
        commit_info['committer'] = current_commit.commit.committer.name
        commit_info['sha'] = current_commit.commit.sha
        commit_info['url'] = current_commit.commit.html_url
        commits.append(commit_info)
        # and next when only one parent exist
        if len(current_commit.commit.parents) == 1:
            current_commit = current_commit.parents[0]
        else:

```

I take the head of the branch and step over the parent commits to a commit with more than one parent. This works. But I have to stop when a commit has two childs. Do I have an option to get a child information via REST API? I could not found anything like this.
i found a solution
@bauergeorg , please share your solution

Hi @neshkeev,

the problem is: **When did your branch started?** I decided (for me) that the branch startpoint is the last merge point. 
This code works like that following procedure: I start walking at the branch commit (head) to the next parent commit. I stop if the commit has two parents (last merge point). This named this "stub" as tail.

This is an abstract of an class. I think you can handle it ;)

```python
    def get_commits_of_ref_tail_only(self, repo, ref_name):
        ''' return commits of reference - tail only'''

        # init commits
        commits = []

        # get head commit
        if self.check_if_branch_exist(repo, ref_name):
            current_commit = repo.get_branch(ref_name).commit
        elif self.check_if_tag_exist(repo, ref_name):
            current_commit = self.get_tag(repo, ref_name).commit
        else:
            return commits

        # get commit info
        while True:
            commit_info = {}
            commit_info['message'] = current_commit.commit.message
            commit_info['committer'] = current_commit.commit.committer.name
            commit_info['sha'] = current_commit.commit.sha
            commit_info['url'] = current_commit.commit.html_url
            commits.append(commit_info)
            # and next when only one parent exist
            if len(current_commit.commit.parents) == 1:
                current_commit = current_commit.parents[0]
            else:
                return commits
```
this could be helpful, too:
```python
    def check_if_branch_exist(self, repo, branch_name) -> bool:
        ''' Check if branch exists '''
        # handle if no branch name is set
        if branch_name == None or branch_name == '':
            return False
        else:
            # get list of branches in your repo
            branch_names = self.list_branch_names(repo)
            # branch name in list: return True
            if branch_name in branch_names:
                return True
            else:
                return False

    def check_if_tag_exist(self, repo, tag_name) -> bool:
        ''' Check if tag exists '''
        # handle if no branch name is set
        if tag_name == None or tag_name == '':
            return False
        else:
            # get list of tags in your repo
            tag_names = self.list_tag_names(repo)
            # tag name in list: return True
            if tag_name in tag_names:
                return True
            else:
                return False

    def list_branch_names(self, repo) -> list:
        ''' List all branch names of a repository

        Parameter:
            repo: Repository with type 'Github.get_repo()' or as str.

        Example: 
            >>> mngt.list_branch_names(repo)
            ['develop', 'main', 'test/feature_blue']
        '''
        # input management
        if isinstance(repo, str):
            repo = self.get_repo(repo)

        # init return
        ret = []
        # get refs of repo
        refs = repo.get_git_refs()
        # create list
        for ref in refs:
            if ref.ref.find('refs/heads/') != -1:
                branch_name = ref.ref.split('refs/heads/')
                ret.append(branch_name[1])
        return ret

    def list_tag_names(self, repo) -> list:
        ''' List all tag names of a repository

        Parameter:
            repo: Repository with type 'Github.get_repo()' or as str.

        Example: 
            >>> mngt.list_tag_names(repo)
            ['example-tag']

        '''
        # init return
        ret = []
        # get refs of repo
        refs = repo.get_git_refs()
        # create list
        for ref in refs:
            if ref.ref.find('refs/tags/') != -1:
                tag_name = ref.ref.split('refs/tags/')
                ret.append(tag_name[1])
        return ret

```

I've been struggling to find the best way to use Python to programmatically upload a .ipa file, and I figured this library would be absolutely perfect. However, I couldn't find any examples of other people using the PyGithub releases-related methods so I am not entirely sure if I am using it correctly.

Here's the error traceback:
```
Exception has occurred: ConnectionError
('Connection aborted.', ConnectionResetError(10054, 'An existing connection was forcibly closed by the remote host', None, 10054, None))

```

Here's the code snippet I am currently using to upload:
```py
g = Github(os.getenv("GITHUB_TOKEN"))
g_repo = g.get_repo(321891219)
g_release = g_repo.get_latest_release()
with open(ipa_path, "rb") as file:
        uploaded_asset = g_release.upload_asset_from_memory(file_like=file, file_size=ipa_path.stat().st_size,

For reference, `ipa_path` is a Path (pathlib) object that looks something like this: `WindowsPath('C:/Users/noah/AppData/Local/Temp/tmpd5jl9qo9/temp2.zip')`

The file in question is zip file by nature, but is technically an IPA (Apple software package). If it matters, the basename of the file and the name supplied to the upload method are not the same, but I tested this theory and it didn't seem to matter.

If you can tell me what I'm doing wrong here, if its not an issue with the library, please don't hesitate. Thanks!

comments.body: This issue has been automatically marked as stale because it has not had recent activity. It will be closed if no further activity occurs. Thank you for your contributions.

This is down to github not being able to serve the current load of connections.

You can configure retries via the `retry` argument:

```python
gh = Github(retry=10)
```

You can configure more complex retry logic as follows:

```python
from urllib3.util import Retry

gh = Github(retry=Retry(10))
```

See https://urllib3.readthedocs.io/en/stable/reference/urllib3.util.html#urllib3.util.Retry for all available options.

body:
I know that the GitHub API makes it possible to change a public repo to be a private one. And according to the docs (https://pygithub.readthedocs.io/en/latest/github_objects/Repository.html), it seems like it should be possible to set the visibility from 'public' to 'private', But I can't figure out how to get this to work.  Is this functionality available, or should I use the REST API in this case?

Thanks!

comments.body:
The functionality is available, to change visibility from 'private' to 'public', you can do this
```
from github import Github

g = Github("token")
repo = g.get_repo("username/repo")
repo.edit(private=True)
```
To change any other property of a repository you can go here use the edit function, here's the [link](https://pygithub.readthedocs.io/en/latest/github_objects/Repository.html#github.Repository.Repository.edit). Feel free to ask any more questions
Thanks *SO* much. Both this answer, and your work, are greatly appreciated.

title: How can I change a public repo to a private one?

body:
I am trying to get the repo topics from pyGithub. It works fine using `get_topics()`, but this consumes an extra API call for each repo I am checking. The standard API response from GitHub returns the topics as well. To check:

```bash
curl \
  -H "Accept: application/vnd.github.v3+json" \
  https://api.github.com/orgs/secureCodeBox/repos | jq '.[].topics'
```

(substitute "secureCodeBox" with any org of your choice).

Is there any reason why this data is not exposed when getting the repository (we're going it via the `get_repos` function of the `Organization` class, if that makes a difference)? It seems to me like it [calls the same API endpoint that my example here uses](https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/0245b758ca323dfa18cd7910d50300ca42514999/github/Organization.py#L929). I see that there was [another discussion on this topic](https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/issues/1545), but it does not seem like it actually resolved the question for why this is not currently being done.

Thanks for building this library!

comments.body: It looks as though #1504 caused a regression with this functionality.

body:
I'm getting a mypy type error that I believe is incorrect from `Repository.get_workflow_runs()`, where I use the branch argument as a keyword argument:
```
myfile.py:305: error: Unexpected keyword argument "branch" for "get_workflow_runs" of "Repository"
```
I believe it's because Repository.py and Repository.pyi are out of sync for `Repository.get_workflow_runs()`.

The function definition in Repository.py has arguments:
https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/001970d4a828017f704f6744a5775b4207a6523c/github/Repository.py#L3158-L3164

but the function stub in Repository.pyi is defined without any arguments:
https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/001970d4a828017f704f6744a5775b4207a6523c/github/Repository.pyi#L468

try this, I got the same error, it helped me:
https://github.com/VFrontDe/ESXi-Customizer-PS/issues/15#issuecomment-656938625

This is down to github not being able to serve the current load of connections, this is unrelated to any limits. You could add retries, but if this never connects, then you should troubleshoot your internet connection (e.g. proxy settings: #2426).

You can configure retries via the `retry` argument:

```python
gh = Github(retry=10)
```

You can configure more complex retry logic as follows:

```python
from urllib3.util import Retry

gh = Github(retry=Retry(10))
```

See https://urllib3.readthedocs.io/en/stable/reference/urllib3.util.html#urllib3.util.Retry for all available options.

title: `watchers_count` is incorrect

body:
For the Get Content Repository endpoint: https://docs.github.com/en/rest/reference/repos#get-repository-content

When the the `{path}` on the endpoint ends with a trailing `/`, the api responds with a `302 Found` and therefore PyGithub must then perform a GET on the url in `location` response header.

This currently is handled in the below code in PyGithub: https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/master/github/Repository.py#L1824-L1828

```python
        # Handle 302 redirect response
        if headers.get("status") == "302 Found" and headers.get("location"):
            headers, data = self._requester.requestJsonAndCheck(
                "GET", headers["location"], parameters=url_parameters
            )
```


The issue I am facing with this now is that PyGithub expects there to be a `status` in the response headers, however the Github api _no longer_ sends `status` as a response header.

I found this github support community post confirming this change: https://github.community/t/githubs-api-is-not-returning-status-in-its-response-header/160531

See the below cURL commands where I confirmed...

This request returns `200` when I send `github` as the path
```bash
{18:49}~ ‚û≠ curl -I --request GET 'https://api.github.com/repos/PyGithub/PyGithub/contents/github' \
--header 'Authorization: Bearer <token redacted>'
HTTP/2 200
server: GitHub.com
date: Wed, 08 Dec 2021 23:49:06 GMT
content-type: application/json; charset=utf-8
content-length: 198400
cache-control: private, max-age=60, s-maxage=60
vary: Accept, Authorization, Cookie, X-GitHub-OTP
etag: "c4c07fd89012d914782b5cc0b5fc2028374d8a35"
last-modified: Wed, 08 Dec 2021 05:34:29 GMT

```

This request returns `302` when I send `github/` as the path
```bash
{18:49}~ ‚û≠ curl -I --request GET 'https://api.github.com/repos/PyGithub/PyGithub/contents/github/' \
--header 'Authorization: Bearer <token redacted>'
HTTP/2 302
server: GitHub.com
date: Wed, 08 Dec 2021 23:49:09 GMT

```



In both of these cases, we can see there is no `status` header being returned by Github. 

Therefore, when I replicate this function with the trailing `/` in the path with PyGithub, I get the following error b/c PyGithub fails to perform the necessary redirect since in the above if statement, `headers.get("status") == "302 Found"` does not return as True.

Python Code
```python
from github import Github
from github import Repository

g = Github("<token redacted>")

repo = g.get_repo("PyGithub/PyGithub")

content = repo.get_contents("github/")
```

Output
```bash
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/webbchawla/Documents/Projects/pygit_tst/main.py", line 10, in <module>
    content = repo.get_contents("github/")
  File "/Users/webbchawla/Documents/Projects/pygit_tst/.venv/lib/python3.9/site-packages/github/Repository.py", line 1810, in get_contents
    return github.ContentFile.ContentFile(
  File "/Users/webbchawla/Documents/Projects/pygit_tst/.venv/lib/python3.9/site-packages/github/GithubObject.py", line 283, in __init__
    super().__init__(requester, headers, attributes, completed)
  File "/Users/webbchawla/Documents/Projects/pygit_tst/.venv/lib/python3.9/site-packages/github/GithubObject.py", line 84, in __init__
    self._storeAndUseAttributes(headers, attributes)
  File "/Users/webbchawla/Documents/Projects/pygit_tst/.venv/lib/python3.9/site-packages/github/GithubObject.py", line 96, in _storeAndUseAttributes
    self._useAttributes(attributes)
  File "/Users/webbchawla/Documents/Projects/pygit_tst/.venv/lib/python3.9/site-packages/github/ContentFile.py", line 191, in _useAttributes
    if "content" in attributes:  # pragma no branch
TypeError: argument of type 'NoneType' is not iterable
```


For now, I am able to work around this issue by doing `.rstrip("/")` on the path before calling `get_contents()` but I figured it would be wise for PyGithub to handle the redirect case as well, however the maintainers feel is the best way.


Let me know if you need any more examples or clarification üòÑ

title: get_pulls failed to get latest PR with both reversed and get_page

body:
All of the PyGitHub object are self contained, built from the JSON returned from the API calls. And this works most of the time. But every pull request belongs to a single repository. There is a tree structure linking many of these objects. 

The request here is to be able to walk back up the tree, getting the objects higher in the API tree structure from a given object. For example: 

```
     pull = pull_request_comment.get_pull()
    repo = pull.get_repo()
```

comments.body: The more specific reason for this request is objects generated by `repo.organization` and `gh.get_organization()` do not match in important and significant ways such that specific calls (e.g. `org.get_teams()` ) that work with the latter call do not work with the former object.

title: github.Organization.Organization missing some repositories and pages permissions properties

body:
Over the summer, github introduced [secondary rate limits](https://docs.github.com/en/rest/guides/best-practices-for-integrators#dealing-with-secondary-rate-limits).

It'd probably make sense for PGH to have built-in support for those:

* mutation requests can now return a failure (403) with a `Retry-After` header, indicating how many seconds to wait
* mutation requests *should* now be interspersed by at least one second
* the more complicated objects (those which trigger notifications e.g. prs, issues, comments, reviews, probably repos) are further restricted but with no indications

Would be nice if PGH could support these at least as an opt in e.g.

* opting into automatically retrying on 403 + `Retry-After`
* opting into self-rate-limiting on mutation request (could be as simple as a `delay_mutation=False` which would be used as a number of seconds since the last mutation query, since `False == 0` and `True == 1` that could directly be interpreted as seconds *and* would further allow users to tune the rate-limiting more finely)
* opting into a more extensive rate limiting for the more complex class of objects

comments.body: related: https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/pull/2127

I think PyGithub should throttle all requests so that rate limit errors are avoided in the first place (#1989). If they occur, they should be retried while respecting `Retry-After`.

And this is where things get complicated:

1. Rate limit errors (403) do not have `Retry-After` header, at least not in all situations: https://github.community/t/no-retry-after-header/184498/7.
2. Not all 403 errors are retry-able (e.g. access forbidden if not authenticated), so retrying based on status code (403) only would be a bad idea. The `urllib3.util.retry.Retry` interface does not allow for checking the response message or body content, only response code: https://github.com/urllib3/urllib3/pull/2500

What I do is create a GitHub instance with a bespoke `urllib3.util.retry.Retry` class that is able to determine whether to retry based on the response content. With that, 403 responses that refer to `RateLimitExceeded` are retried, other 403 responses are not retried. The default `Retry` implementation will then respect `Retry-After` headers if they exist.

https://github.com/EnricoMi/publish-unit-test-result-action/blob/043296c976c53f4536194ebe3841ed720e04d496/python/publish/retry.py#L17-L76

```
retry = GitHubRetry(total=retries,
                    backoff_factor=backoff_factor,
                    allowed_methods=Retry.DEFAULT_ALLOWED_METHODS.union({'GET', 'POST'}),
                    status_forcelist=list(range(500, 600)))
github.Github(login_or_token=token, base_url=url, per_page=100, retry=retry)
```

> I think PyGithub should throttle all requests so that rate limit errors are avoided in the first place (#1989).

"Mitigated" is probably a better qualifier: because github publishes no guidance on notification-triggering operations, can change the rate limiting at any moment, and provides no `Retry-After` header then, there is no way to ensure the issue is avoided.
"Mitigate" is a better word indeed as we cannot avoid the RateLimitExceededExceptions: #2145
This issue has been automatically marked as stale because it has not had recent activity. It will be closed if no further activity occurs. Thank you for your contributions.
Hitting this error.  Is this slated for a fix?

title: Support for secondary and additional rate limits

body:
For big repositories or when github is quite loaded (which is common these days), it regularly happens that the creation objects succeeds but the objects are not immediately visible, and operations trying to affect those then fails.

An easy way to trigger the issue is to loop around creating new repositories and immediately deleting them, I'd say there's about 10% chances the delete will fail with a 404, but I've also seen it with PRs[^1].

Anyway so far as I can see, PyGithub has no real way to check for an object's visibility aside from looking up said object through its parent and looping by hand. But having it built-in would:

* provide for a better interface (e.g. an `ensure_visible` or `wait_visible` method with parameters like the iteration sleep and total wait time)
* allow using `HEAD`, to not retrieve the entire object body *again*

[^1]: not that this is the only "reliability" issue, other I've noted over the years:
    * pr creation reports failing but the PR was created
    * update ref, read ref back, get different result
    * update ref, update is not visible to `git` (via `$repo/info/refs`), visibility to git is independent from visibility through API which is fun

Have either of these features been implemented in PyGithub and I am simply failing to find the documentation or code? Or is this functionality currently missing from PyGithub?

title: Auto-generating release notes

body:
From what I can tell, it's currently not possible to add a label to an issue with PyGithub, but it seems to be lacking in providing a method to add a label to a PR.

Is there any plan to provide this option?

Thanks!

comments.body:
sorry, I was too hasty in opening this issue. For anyone that comes across it hoping to achieve something similar, you can use something like the following if you only know the branch number (but not the PR number):

```
for pr in repo.get_pulls(head=BRANCH_NAME):
      pr = pr
pr.add_to_labels("bug")
```

Or if you know the PR number:
```
pr = repo.get_pull('1176')
pr.add_to_labels("bug")
```
Closing because I found there was already a method of achieving this.

body:
Thanks for the great package!
It seems like there is no support for multi-line comments yet.
In [GitHub Docs](https://docs.github.com/en/rest/reference/pulls#create-a-review-comment-for-a-pull-request), we can create a comment that applies to more than one line in the pull request diff, by specifying `line`, `side`, `start_line` and `start_side` instead of a single parameter `position`.
Is there any plan to support this API?

comments.body: I found some [related](https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/issues/1805) [issues](https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/issues/1803), and maybe this feature is deliberately not supported  because it is a preview feature? üòÖ

Hmm.. but it seems like some features are actually based on [preview features](https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/pull/1433), so if it is ok to have additional preview feature, I think I can contribute.

### Possible combinations of parameters
 - Required: `owner`, `repo`, `pull_number`, `body`, `commit_id`, `path`
 - `position` (if this is used, the parameters below are ignored)
 - `side` (`LEFT` or `RIGHT`) + `line`  (just like one-line comment using `position` only)
 - `side` + `start_side` + `line` + `start_line` (multi-line comment)

Hi,

I created this pull request #2540 that might fix this issue
This has been fixed in #2540.

This is likely due to missing proxy settings: #2426 or other network restrictions in your production environment.

If network is fine, you can configure retries via the `retry` argument:

```python
gh = Github(retry=10)
```

You can configure more complex retry logic as follows:

```python
from urllib3.util import Retry

gh = Github(retry=Retry(10))
```

See https://urllib3.readthedocs.io/en/stable/reference/urllib3.util.html#urllib3.util.Retry for all available options.

That will fetch every commit one at a time due to us not knowing if the objects are complete when we fetch them. Operate on the PaginatedList itself instead. For example:

```
>>> g = Github(TOKEN)

>>> commits = repo.get_commits()

body:
How to get the diff of a pull request? I can get the `diff_url` pretty easily but how do I make PyGithub request the url...
```python
from github import Github
from getpass import getpass
token = getpass()
base_url = 'https://internal-github-domain.com/api/v3'
g = Github(base_url=base_url, login_or_token=token)
repo = g.get_repo('repo-name')
pull = list(repo.get_pulls())[0]
diff_url = pull.diff_url
# What do I do with diff_url?!?
```
Is there like a `g.get(diff_url)` that'll reuse the token-based authentication?

comments.body:
Everything we're normally doing, we talk to the API REST endpoint, not to the general HTTPS frontend, which is what the diff_url returns, and does not require a token to fetch. I'd suggest just using `requests`, like so:

```
>>> repo = g.get_repo("PyGithub/PyGithub")
>>> pr = repo.get_pull(2078)
>>> import requests
>>> r = requests.get(pr.diff_url)
>>> for line in r.text.split('\n')[:2]:
...     print(line)
... 
diff --git a/github/WorkflowRun.py b/github/WorklowRun.py
index b9748940b..4c1cfad1b 100644
```

Unfortunately that does *not* work. I'm using an internal corporate hosted GitHub and all requests must be authenticated. Trying with requests:
```
In [74]: import requests

In [76]: resp = requests.get(pull.diff_url)

In [77]: resp.text
Out[77]: '\n<!DOCTYPE html>\n<html lang="en">\n  <head>\n    <meta charset="utf-8">\n\n\n\n  <title>Initiating SAML single sign-on</title>\n  <meta http-equiv="
```
Notice the "Initiating SAML single sign-on" message in the title due to internal network restrictions. Using the API endpoint and token authentication would work fine. Can PyGithub support this?

Internally, we pretty much assume everything is JSON, which is why we mark all of the methods as internal. However, requests can support what you're after: `requests.get(pull.diff_url, auth=('username', 'token'))`

Any examples of how to use the new environment feature to add Deployment Branch rule using the branch name pattern?

![image](https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/assets/4138749/7141c2e4-59bb-4eac-8d84-c518d92a4145)

If the branch you want to limit deployment to is covered by branch protection rules, then setting `protected_branches=True` like [in this test](https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/main/tests/Environment.py#L137C17-L137C40) might work. See [documentation](https://docs.github.com/en/rest/deployments/environments?apiVersion=2022-11-28#create-or-update-an-environment) under "properties of deployment_branch_policy". If not, then you might have to implement [deployment branch policies](https://docs.github.com/en/rest/deployments/branch-policies?apiVersion=2022-11-28).

The way we solved this is by just specifying branches in the Github Actions workflow and let that determine to what environment a particular branch is deployed. We are not so defensive that we want to protect against developers modifying the workflow to deploy their development branch to production.
Does anyone know an alternative way to update secrets from environments using python, even if this requires use of another library or just producing REST HTTP api call manually?

You should be able to use the REST calls documented [here](https://docs.github.com/en/rest/actions/secrets?apiVersion=2022-11-28#list-environment-secrets). I don't think it would be difficult to add to PyGithub.

body:
I have wrote me a function to get submodules. But it needs a lot of requests cause I scan the total content. Do you have another idea?

```python
def get_submodules(self, repo, branch_name = None):
    ''' Returns submodule information.

    Parameter:
        repo: Repository with type 'Github.get_repo()'.
        branch_name: 'main' or 'develop'. If no parameter is set. The function use default-branch.

    Example:
        >>> mngt = pipeline_management(token)
        >>> repo = mngt.get_repo('<example-repo>')
        >>> get_submodules(repo)
        [
            {'name': 'downgrade', 'path': 'downgrade', 'src': 'repo_a', 'url': 'git@github.com:<your-org>/<repo_a>.git', 'sha': '139ebc68145404d0dd44a222af715b6c7b33d1c5'},
            {'name': 'update', 'path': 'update', 'src': 'repo_a', 'url': 'git@github.com:<your-org>/<repo_a>.git', 'sha': '139ebc68145404d0dd44a222af715b6c7b33d1c5'},
            {'name': 'pyroh', 'path': 'subfolder/pyroh', 'src': 'pyroh', 'url': 'git@github.com:<your-org>/pyroh.git', 'sha': 'a50bd7770aa4433cb7074bb2d40d4a203024fc42'}
        ]
    '''

    # init return value
    ret = []

    # input management
    if isinstance(repo, str):
        repo = self.get_repo(repo)

    # get contents of default branch
    if branch_name == None or branch_name == '':
        contents = repo.get_contents('')
    # get contents of special defined branch
    else:
        # check if branch exists
        if self.check_if_branch_exist(repo, branch_name):
            # if branch exist
            repo.get_branch(branch_name)
            # get contents
            contents = repo.get_contents('', ref = branch_name)
        else:
            print("WARNING: Repo '{}' has no branch {}. Default-branch '{}' will be taken.".format(repo.name, branch_name, repo.default_branch))
            branch_name = repo.default_branch
            # get content of default
            contents = repo.get_contents('')

    while contents:
        file_content = contents.pop(0)
        #print(file_content)
        # extrend if directory
        if file_content.type == 'dir':
                if branch_name == None:
                    contents.extend(repo.get_contents(file_content.path))
                else:
                    contents.extend(repo.get_contents(file_content.path, ref = branch_name))
        else:
            # check type == 'submodule' will not work yet: https://github.com/github/developer.github.com/commit/1b329b04cece9f3087faa7b1e0382317a9b93490
            # if(file_content.type) == 'submodule'):
            if(file_content.size <= 100):
                # get submodule info
                if(file_content.raw_data.get('type') == 'submodule'):
                    if file_content.raw_data.get("submodule_git_url") != None: 
                        src = self._extract_src_from_url(file_content.raw_data.get("submodule_git_url"))
                        url = file_content.raw_data.get("submodule_git_url")
                        ret.append({'name': file_content.name, 'path': file_content.path, 'src': src, 'url': url, 'sha': file_content.sha})

    return ret
```

comments.body: Not really, perhaps operate on the repository itself using https://pypi.org/project/GitPython/ ?

@s-t-e-v-e-n-k Thanks for your comment.

Yes, of course using GitPython is a possibility. But you have to check-out the total repository. This need a lots of time in a recursive style with very large repositories.

I think a smarter possibility is to parse the ".gitsubmodule" file in parent folder via PyGithub. This is the fastest option I know. To scan the total repository for a file with "content type = submodule" is not very effective. And need a lot of time for large repsoritories **AND a lots of API RATES**.

I think I have two possibilities:
- to wait for a good submodule implementation at one of the future REST API releases
- to parse the ".submodules" file via PyGithu (fast and api rate thrifty)

What do you think?
It's up to GitHub what they expose via the REST API, I'm not sure what they are planning. Parsing the .submodule file does sound like the best option.

When I try to unit test using PyGithub library I get the warning message 
```py
ResourceWarning: unclosed <ssl.SSLSocket fd=1652, family=AddressFamily.AF_INET, type=SocketKind.SOCK_STREAM, proto=0, laddr=('xxx.xxx.x.xxx', xxxxx), raddr=('xxx.xx.xxx.x', 443)>

I try to rewrite code with async but it does work I have the same problem, I couldn't find the cause of the problem

comments.body:
It looks like it may be related to not closing connections that are opened up during testing. More info on that [here](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/48160728/resourcewarning-unclosed-socket-in-python-3-unit-test).

Also, it is just a warning, so if you don't care about unclosed connections after testing you can ignore the error as shown [here](https://stackoverflow.com/a/55411485)

body:
If you have a long list of say 50000 items and try to slice the list at index 7000 (intending to ignore early items in the list), the current PaginatedList slicing code seems to still make requests for the earlier, ignored items. This seems unnecessary. 

I replaced slicing with " list[start:] " with this code in my app, as an example of what seemed to work better:

```python
def iterate_list(github_list, starting_index):
    num_pages = math.ceil(github_list.totalCount / GITHUB_ITEMS_PER_PAGE)

    starting_page_index = int(starting_index / GITHUB_ITEMS_PER_PAGE)
    print('starting this list on page index {}'.format(starting_page_index))
    num_items_skipped = starting_page_index * GITHUB_ITEMS_PER_PAGE

    for page_index in range(starting_page_index, num_pages):
        print('fetching page {}'.format(page_index))
        page_items = github_list.get_page(page_index)

        for item in page_items:
            if num_items_skipped < starting_index:
                print('skipping an item in this page')
                num_items_skipped += 1
                continue
            yield item

```

It seems like the PaginatedList class could do something similar, and as a user of this library I was definitely surprised that it did not do this.

comments.body: Currently the PaginatedList code steps through each next page when we grow. The problem is that PaginatedList really really wants it's internal data structure to be fully populated, and gets quite upset with horrible to debug failures when it isn't. This allows you to do really neat things with bounded slices, but any changes here will A) be wide-reaching, and B) most likely an API break, and I don't think that I'm okay with that.

title: Slicing long paginated lists does not reduce API calls

body:
I have a script that uses PyGithub's `Repository.compare()` function to generate a list of changes between two commits.  Our repository has become fairly busy of late, and I only recently discovered that this API returns a page size of 250 commits, by default.  Documentation is [here](https://docs.github.com/en/rest/reference/repos#compare-two-commits) on the corresponding GitHub API.

When PyGithub consumes this API, the `commits` property in the `Comparison` object is just a plain old list.  It would be great if this could be a `PaginatedList` instead, so that we can consume all of the commits without worrying about the pagination.  I think this may be a bit weird, because the commits list is only part of the returned response.  There's also a list of files, which doesn't support pagination.  Additionally, according to the documentation, the sort order of the commits returned changes when pagination parameters are provided.

It would be fantastic if all of this weirdness could be hidden away from users of PyGithub!  But I'm not sure that it's straightforward to do because of the weirdness.  I'm happy to work on a PR to provide this, but would prefer not to do so without a better understanding from PyGithub's maintainers about how it should work.

For anyone who may come across this in the very near future, I'm working around this in a really terrible way by appending the pagination parameters onto the `head` parameter with each call, i.e. `repo.compare(base, f"{head}?page={page}")`.

Hello, I am using pygithub in a script to clone repos, after 60 call I get the error saying I have exceeded my limit 
`github.GithubException.RateLimitExceededException: 403 {"message": "API rate limit exceeded for user ID 45185179.", "documentation_url": "https://docs.github.com/rest/overview/resources-in-the-rest-api#rate-limiting"}
`

but if I curl my api I can see that I still have x-ratelimit-limit: 5000
x-ratelimit-remaining: 4999

my script is supposed to be properly setup with my token.

`ACCESS_TOKEN = open("token.txt","r").read()
g = Github(ACCESS_TOKEN)`

I am really at loss, what should I do to fix this issue?

comments.body: I suspect there are a few different rate limits here -- there's the one in the headers that you can see counting down, and I suspect another that throws a 403 if you're calling endpoints too quickly. 60 calls in a short period of time, for an expensive operation like clone does sound reasonable to put the brakes on. Have you tried waiting after each clone? Or using GitPython to clone the repos which will use the git protocol or https and not use API limits?

body:
i was trying this
```py
issues = Repository.get_issues(state="all")
open_issues = [i for i in issues if i.state == "open"]
```
and all my remaining calls got used and RateLimit exception was raised...
I know i can use `get_issues(state="open")` but i though why not getting all the issues and filtering it out so i don't have to make an api call for closed issues... but it seems that get_issue(state="open/closed") will make only 2 calls which is very less as compared to filtering out.. Why this is happening? Iterating over PaginatedList makes api call?

Edit: It made 28 API calls to iterate over paginated list of four thousands fifty seven issues...
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/68418241/125417907-a9cdcc5f-5313-451c-b9fc-1e48359b4cfc.png)

comments.body:
Yes. Github REST API has `per_page` and `page` for paginated. See: https://docs.github.com/en/rest/reference/issues 

```Python
issues = Repository.get_issues(state="all")
```

`issues` is a `PaginatedList`. If you iter this object, you will get all issues.

https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/83d6e0719cb7bfee57af398f93a73516b62af5f2/github/Repository.py#L2532-L2534

So you need to use some argument to filter this issue. The difference is filtering in the Github Server or your local.
So @Hanaasagi , How can i filter it locally?.. As you suggested that filtering on GitHub server makes API call?üëÄ
Yes, this is how this works -- we will make further calls to get each page, there is a per_page setting that can be fiddled, or you can pass more filtering parameters to get_issues().

body:
Sending requests to the GitHub API too quickly will result in abuse rate limit errors. This has been discussed in several issues here (#1235, #2113, #2005, #1319, #1115, #810). I'd like to propose to wrap the Requester.__requestRaw method in a throttling method that ensures subsequent calls are at least a configured number of (float) seconds apart. This way the user of the client library can rely on calls not being too frequent.

Throttling in user code adds complexity on top of the client library and duplicates code across projects that use this client library. A good example is https://github.com/clockfort/GitHub-Backup/pull/44. Especially when iterating over paginated results, throttling becomes difficult in user code.

I have wrapped the `Requester.__requestRaw` method with the following code, which allows me to configure seconds between read (`GET`) and write (all verbs other than `GET`) requests. All requests will then be deferred by the client library if called  too quickly:

https://github.com/EnricoMi/publish-unit-test-result-action/blob/4b6277f1917325e96cadc94a1116031a0ae906bb/python/publish_unit_test_results.py#L99-L122

I am delaying retrys by a urllib `Retry` instance with a backoff factor identical to the configured delays above, which is out of scope of this issue.

comments.body: This issue has been automatically marked as stale because it has not had recent activity. It will be closed if no further activity occurs. Thank you for your contributions.
@s-t-e-v-e-n-k what are your thoughts on this?

Can I just cast my vote in favour of this? I've got a program that calls many different methods of the library and am currently having to try and wrap all of them in a helper function to prevent hitting the rate limit. Having a simple setting to pass to tell the library just to go slow would both help it conform to the docs which request that you [wait 1 second between requests](https://docs.github.com/en/rest/guides/best-practices-for-integrators#dealing-with-secondary-rate-limits) when doing a large number of requests.

Could also have an option to wait for the value in the retry-after header instead of having to implement a wait for that project side.

(Btw the library is really great though and really helping with the project I'm working on thanks for the amazing work)

The way I got around this was to just throw everything into a thread and then cache the results. I think something that doesn't particularly help is it's not 100% clear what results in a request being executed.

I was able to use a custom Retry class to handle the retry headers and make sure to trigger a retry on a 403

https://docs.github.com/en/rest/overview/resources-in-the-rest-api#checking-your-rate-limit-status

```python
class RateLimitRetry(urllib3.util.retry.Retry):
    def get_retry_after(self, response):
        reset_time = datetime.datetime.fromtimestamp(int(response.headers["X-RateLimit-Reset"]))
        retry_after = (reset_time - datetime.datetime.now()).total_seconds() + 1
        retry_after = max(retry_after, 0)  # In case we hit a negative total_seconds
        print(f"Rate limited,  retry after: {retry_after} seconds")
        return retry_after
```
@jogo How do you use it with PyGithub?

@jogo not all 403 responses are rate limit errors, contain a `X-RateLimit-Reset`, or are retryable at all. I think only the content of the response provides enough evidence to identify a retryable 403: #2387

Hey @EnricoMi, just wanted to thank you for all your work in this area. Over the last 18 months, I kept running into [these errors](https://github.com/zed-industries/zed/actions/runs/8584680293) off and on in my [script for building top-ranking issue reports](https://github.com/zed-industries/zed/blob/main/script/update_top_ranking_issues/main.py) in the Zed editor repository and today I finally decided to try fixing it. I spent a bit of time putting in some custom error handling, but then ran into your PRs here and found things were working after simply bumping the packages (I was on v1.55!). Thanks for all of the work here!

title: feature request: archive notification

body:
When first requesting the `mergeable` property of a PullRequest, the GitHub API returns `null` and kicks off a job to determine if the PR is mergeable or not. You have to re-request the data after a delay. Due to the way PyGithub caches the result of querying for a property, it gets stuck as null/None.

PyGithub should either re-request internally until the returned value is a concrete boolean, or accessing the `mergeable` property a second time should re-trigger the API query (I'd prefer the former).

My workaround at the moment looks something like...
```python
from github.GithubObject import NotSet
while pull.mergeable is None:
    time.sleep(5)
    pull._mergeable = NotSet
    pull._CompletableGithubObject__completed = False
```

body:
https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/0245b758ca323dfa18cd7910d50300ca42514999/github/GithubException.pyi#L4
suggests that `headers` arg is `Optional` (technically, `None` value is acceptable), yet
https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/0245b758ca323dfa18cd7910d50300ca42514999/github/GithubException.py#L41
implies that positional `headers` arg is mandatory.

Which one is more correct?

Note that adding a new mandatory arg breaks backwards-compatibility.

comments.body: `Optional[T]` is just a Union type means either `None` or `T`. It does not matter whether the parameter is positional. And it not require the parameter has a default value, like `headers=None`. Further more,  I think `GithubException` is a internal exception, should only be created by this lib.

body:
Hi :wave: Thanks for the great project!

I ran into some issues when dealing with updated date and times of Issue and PR entities. In my use case, I am trying to mock the GH API for tests, so I end up writing a custom date time in the `updated_at` attribute of the issue object that would be returned by the API.
In this case, I am using a code similar to this:
```python
# issue_data is a dictionary with the Issue data that would be returned by GH
issue_data["updated_at"] = str((datetime.now()).isoformat()) + "Z"
```
This writes something like `2021-05-26T15:22:00.286880Z` in the object.

However, because of the parsing that is done in https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/4faff23ce9eab00c451ffdd842686781e8a1b4eb/github/GithubObject.py#L173, I am actually getting a wrong date in the result:
1. The length of this string is `27`, making it enter the second case in the `if` statement
2. AFAICS in https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/4faff23ce9eab00c451ffdd842686781e8a1b4eb/github/GithubObject.py#L185 the data after the `.` of the milliseconds is ignored as is treated as a time delta to be computed in the original date

I was able to solve this by changing the code above to 
```python
issue_data["updated_at"] = str((datetime.now()).isoformat(timespec="seconds")) + "Z"
```
making it return `2021-05-26T15:25:28Z` and be parsed correctly.

However, I could use the ability to read the milliseconds in this case. Could it be possible?

body:
### Summary
The debug level authentication redaction found in Requester.__log() https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/master/github/Requester.py#L631 seems to be breaking authentication on redirect. This seems to be a long-standing issue, reported as early as 2016 https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/issues/470 and then i believe mistakenly closed. The same user also submitted a PR https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/pull/471/files which looks like it would solve the issue (and does solve it in my local testing).

I also think this may be some of the root cause for other open/past issues with people seeing authentication failures. It took a while of digging for me to find out that DEBUG was just enabled `isEnabledFor(logging.DEBUG)` in my environment. It does work to set logging to a higher level or disable debug with `logging.disable(logging.DEBUG)`, but that is not the ideal solution.

My particular use case is the redirect on moved/renamed repo's. This only comes into play when authentication is being used (whether it is needed or not, providing bad auth will cause the problem).


### Reproduce

1.  Create a repo to rename, rename the repo
    https://github.com/dannyscript/testmove -> https://github.com/dannyscript/testmoved
    (I'll leave that repo sitting there in case anyone wants to test against an already renamed repo)
2. import and create an instance
```
from github import Github
github_api = 'https://api.github.com'
ghe = Github(base_url=github_api)
```
3. Test
```
ghe.get_repo('dannyscript/testmoved')
Out[5]: Repository(full_name="dannyscript/testmoved")  <--- Success new name
ghe.get_repo('dannyscript/testmove')
Out[6]: Repository(full_name="dannyscript/testmoved")  <--- Success old name
```
4. Enable logging at DEBUG level
```
import logging
logging.basicConfig(level=logging.DEBUG)
```
5. Repeat step 3, still works, just more logs
```
ghe.get_repo('dannyscript/testmoved') <--- Success new name
DEBUG:urllib3.connectionpool:https://api.github.com:443 "GET /repos/dannyscript/testmoved HTTP/1.1" 200 1173
DEBUG:github.Requester:GET https://api.github.com/repos/dannyscript/testmoved [...]
Out[9]: Repository(full_name="dannyscript/testmoved")
ghe.get_repo('dannyscript/testmove')  <--- Success old name
DEBUG:urllib3.connectionpool:https://api.github.com:443 "GET /repos/dannyscript/testmove HTTP/1.1" 301 150  <--- Success on redirect
DEBUG:github.Requester:GET https://api.github.com/repos/dannyscript/testmove [...]
DEBUG:urllib3.connectionpool:https://api.github.com:443 "GET /repositories/370880167 HTTP/1.1" 200 1173
DEBUG:github.Requester:GET https://api.github.com/repositories/370880167 [...]
Out[10]: Repository(full_name="dannyscript/testmoved")
```
6. Create a personal token, set up new instance
```
token = 'ghp_***'
ghe = Github(base_url=github_api, login_or_token=token)
# Note that logging at DEBUG level is still enabled
```
7. Redirect fails once authentication is expected and not found on the second (redirected) request.
```
ghe.get_repo('dannyscript/testmoved')
DEBUG:urllib3.connectionpool:Starting new HTTPS connection (1): api.github.com:443
DEBUG:urllib3.connectionpool:https://api.github.com:443 "GET /repos/dannyscript/testmoved HTTP/1.1" 200 None
DEBUG:github.Requester:GET https://api.github.com/repos/dannyscript/testmoved [...]
Out[13]: Repository(full_name="dannyscript/testmoved")  <--- Success new name
ghe.get_repo('dannyscript/testmove')

`gcc -Who-unused-result -Wsign-compare -DNDEBUG -g -fwrapv -03 -Wall -fomit-frame-pointer -g -fno-semantic-interposition -fomit-frame-pointer -g -fno-semantic-interposition -fomit-frame-pointer -g -fno-semantic-interposition -DTHREAD_STACK_SIZE=0x100000 -fPIC -I/user/include/ffi -I/usr/include/libffi -I/usr/include/python3.8 -c c/_cffi_backend.c -o build/temp.linux-i686-8.8/c/_cffi_backend.o`

https://github.com/pyca/pynacl/issues/601 is a related issue.

body:
When https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/pull/1681 was merged, it added the `pynacl` dependency, and `pynacl` depends on `cffi`.

This is not inherently an issue but it does cause anyone using it to now need compiling dependencies. Especially for docker containers, this means including a number of packages that might not have been included originally. For example, my docker container base was `python:3.9-alpine`. I didnt install any compile tools, and thus when `pip install PyGithub==1.55` is run, it fails.

I needed to add a step to install `gcc`, `musl-dev`, and `libffi-dev` via `apk` beforehand for pip to pass.

I think this should probably be called out in the documentation as a new dependency and possibly a new step if someone does not yet have the proper build tools installed wherever `PyGithub` is targeted for installation.

EDIT: I understand this is a `pynacl` issue. `pynacl` seems to have pretty limited wheel builds and for latest python at least, they do not build wheels with either the `none` or `linux_x86_64` tags. I am just calling out that the docs should probably at least warn of this new dependency.

body:
Hello :wave: ,

since the `PaginatedList` is considered iterable, I think it is reasonable to be able to call `len()` on it.

comments.body: We have tried to implement `__len__` on PaginatedList a few times, last time I tried it ended up with wide-spread test failures and tears.
This issue has been automatically marked as stale because it has not had recent activity. It will be closed if no further activity occurs. Thank you for your contributions.
This also means that an empty `PaginatedList` evaluates to `True` instead of `False`!
This issue has been automatically marked as stale because it has not had recent activity. It will be closed if no further activity occurs. Thank you for your contributions.

Adding `__len__` to `PaginatedList` will allow calling `len(pl)` on `pl: PaginatedList`.

However, turning the `PaginatedList` into a list like

    list(pl)

calls `len(pl)` first. In cases where `totalCount` is not known, this induces another API call, which breaks tests and is undesired in general.

Calling `list(pl)` should call `pl.__len__()` only if `totalCount` is known, that would be ideal. But there is no way to implement that.

title: Make `len()` compatible with `PaginatedList` (as an alias for `totalCount`)

body:
The issue #1078 seems not to be fixed.

Here, there is an assertion that forces the requested port to be equals to the base_url port:
https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/babcbcd04fd5605634855f621b8558afc5cbc515/github/Requester.py#L590-L598

`urllib.parse.urlparse` only returns port when explicitly set:
```python
>>> import urllib.parse
>>> urllib.parse.urlparse("https://example.com:443").port
443
>>> urllib.parse.urlparse("https://example.com").port == None
True
```

It should not be a problem, but all the URLs for the API are only taking the URL into account so the most of the times the assertion is `None == None`. For example:
https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/babcbcd04fd5605634855f621b8558afc5cbc515/github/Organization.py#L578-L580

On the other hand, [`Requester.__createConnection`](https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/babcbcd04fd5605634855f621b8558afc5cbc515/github/Requester.py#L610-L626) already creates the connectionClass so, why not use relative paths exclusively for all `requestJsonAndCheck` calls? This is already done for some requests:
https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/babcbcd04fd5605634855f621b8558afc5cbc515/github/Organization.py#L922-L924

comments.body:
The short answer is: We can't. The biggest user by far is PaginatedList, where we are the mercy of whatever GitHub or GitHub Enterprise feeds us in the headers for traversing the pages, and those URLs are not relative. We could probably relax that check if the parsed port is None, but I also question why you're setting base_url yourself in ansible when the default is api.github.com anyway.

(How did I check?:

```
--- a/github/Requester.py
+++ b/github/Requester.py
@@ -584,6 +584,8 @@ class Requester:
     def __makeAbsoluteUrl(self, url):
         # URLs generated locally will be relative to __base_url
         # URLs returned from the server will start with __base_url
+        with open('/tmp/q', 'a') as f:
+            f.write(f"{url}\n")
         if url.startswith("/"):
             url = f"{self.__prefix}{url}"
         else:
```
)
This issue has been automatically marked as stale because it has not had recent activity. It will be closed if no further activity occurs. Thank you for your contributions.

body:
* **I'm submitting a ...** - [X] bug report - [ ] feature request - [ ] support request * **What is the current behavior?** I'm using the `totalCount` attribute of the [`PullRequest`](https://pygithub.readthedocs.io/en/latest/github_objects/PullRequest.html) class, and I noticed that sometimes the count is wrong. Here's some very simple example code I'm using:
Code for my org ```python import github import os gh = github.Github(os.environ["GITHUB_TOKEN"]) org = gh.get_organization("my-company-org") # PR count is currently at 2119 repo = org.get_repo("some-large-repo") prs_all = repo.get_pulls(state="all") prs_open = repo.get_pulls(state="open") prs_closed = repo.get_pulls(state="closed") print(prs_all.totalCount) # Returns '2018' print(prs_open.totalCount) # Returns '10' print(prs_closed.totalCount) # Returns '2008' ```
Code for PyGitHub ```python import github import os gh = github.Github(os.environ["GITHUB_TOKEN"]) org = gh.get_organization("PyGithub") # PR count is currently at 1909 repo = org.get_repo("PyGithub") prs_all = repo.get_pulls(state="all") prs_open = repo.get_pulls(state="open") prs_closed = repo.get_pulls(state="closed") print(prs_all.totalCount) # Returns '795' print(prs_open.totalCount) # Returns '25' print(prs_closed.totalCount) # Returns '770' ```
That's off by 101 pull requests. * **What is the expected behavior?** The `totalCount` _should_ be `2119` as seen above and by checking it manually in the browser. * **Please tell us about your environment:** - `PyGithub==1.54.1` - `Python 3.9.2` - macOS Catalina 10.15.7 * **Other information** (e.g. detailed explanation, stacktraces, related issues, suggestions how to fix, links for us to have context, eg. stackoverflow, gitter, etc) I noticed that this `PyGithub` repo has the same issue. Is this about how the underlying GitHub API counts PR numbers? Here are some screenshots that show the current pull request numbers on the repo in question.
PR with the largest number 2119

comments.body: Issues and Pull Requests share numbers, as in as much that every pull request is an issue, but not every issue is a pull request. Have you factored that into your counts at least for this repository?

> Issues and Pull Requests share numbers, as in as much that every pull request is an issue, but not every issue is a pull request. Have you factored that into your counts at least for this repository?

So how can I  know which is an Issue or a Pull Request?

There is a `pull_request` method that is not None if it's a PR, like so:

```
>>> repo = g.get_repo("PyGithub/PyGithub")
>>> issues = repo.get_issues(state="open")
>>> for i in issues[:5]:
...     kind = "Issue"
...     if i.pull_request:
...             kind = "PR"
...     print(f"{kind}: {i.title}")
... 
PR: Add comment on issue example
PR: github/MainClass: Fix GitHubException instantiation
PR: Move lint and docs to Python 3.8
PR: ADD code scanning results
Issue: Provide a way to make a "raw" request
```

I want to read out the information from the IssueEvent.
Not all IssueEvents have an Assignee/Assigner.

Minimum Code:
```{python}
import cProfile

def test(event):
    if event.assignee is not None:
        return
issues = repo.get_issues(state='all')
for issue in issues:
    for event in issue.get_events():
        cProfile.run("test(event)")
        cProfile.run("test(event)")
```

Results

1.  **event.assignee is None:**
      First Run:
      6182 function calls (6158 primitive calls) in 0.236 seconds
      Second Run:
      7 function calls in 0.000 seconds
2. **event.assignee is not None:**
      First Run:
      7 function calls in 0.000 seconds
      Second Run:
      7 function calls in 0.000 seconds

Is there a faster way to check if IssueEvent has an Assignee?

comments.body: So the issue as I can see it is you're only interested in a subclass of IssueEvents, and you need to enumerate all of them, is this correct? Sadly, we are the mercy of whatever the GitHub API provides, and I can't see a way to request a subset of events.

Well i need some other informations of the Issue and IssueEvent too. I have to check if there is an assignee or not. Otherwise i will get an exception when there is no assignee. When there is now assignee it takes around 0.2 seconds and when i itterate all issues and Events then it takes al long time to gather the informations about the repository.

I guess the problem is when there is no Assignee the it needs to initiallize first a None NamedUser with the 6000 function calls.

The problem is the completeIfNotSet call. So there is no way to check if the value is set without calling the completeIfNotSet Method

```(python)
@property
    def assignee(self):
        """
        :type: :class:`github.NamedUser.NamedUser`
        """
        self._completeIfNotSet(self._assignee)
        return self._assignee.value
```
Then short-circuit it if you wish by getting the value, but you get to keep both pieces if it breaks.
We have absolutely no way of knowing if what GitHub returned populated all fields, so we need to check.
How should short-circuit help me here?

Found a solution:

changed:
```(python)
if event.assignee is None:
```
to:

```(python)
if event._assignee == github.GithubObject.NotSet:
```

then i get around the _completeIfNotSet. 

Maybe you want to document this in readsthedocs.
Lovely! I'm going to close this issue, but I would welcome a PR adding an example.

    def get_public_key(self):

```python
from github import Github

g = Github("access_token")

# All these urls have the same problem
# get_stats_commit_activity() returns 202 and the operation gets into an infinite loop
url = "chromium/chromium"
# url = "WebKit/WebKit-http"
# url = "JetBrains/MPS"
# url = "mozilla/gecko-dev"
# url = "Asoul/tsec"
