# url = "Katee/git-bomb"
# url = "mandatoryprogrammer/TLDR"
# url = "stevenliuyi/covid19"
# url = "zapret-info/z-i"

repo = g.get_repo(url)
activity = repo.get_stats_commit_activity()
print(activity)
```

The problem is related to the following block in the `Requester.py` file.

```python
if status == 202 and (
	verb == "GET" or verb == "HEAD"
):  # only for requests that are considered 'safe' in RFC 2616
	time.sleep(Consts.PROCESSING_202_WAIT_TIME)
	return self.__requestRaw(original_cnx, verb, url, requestHeaders, input)
```

If you want to check the issue in unit tests, there are two mock responses defined for `testStatisticsCommitActivity` method:

```
https
GET
api.github.com
None
/repos/jacquev6/PyGithub/stats/commit_activity
{'Authorization': 'Basic login_and_password_removed', 'User-Agent': 'PyGithub/Python'}
None
202
[('status', '202 Accepted'), ('x-ratelimit-remaining', '4964'), ('x-github-media-type', 'github.beta; format=json'), ('x-content-type-options', 'nosniff'), ('access-control-expose-headers', 'ETag, Link, X-RateLimit-Limit, X-RateLimit-Remaining, X-RateLimit-Reset, X-OAuth-Scopes, X-Accepted-OAuth-Scopes'), ('x-github-request-id', '4C79374B:3448:429A229:528030EA'), ('content-length', '2'), ('server', 'GitHub.com'), ('x-ratelimit-limit', '5000'), ('access-control-allow-credentials', 'true'), ('date', 'Mon, 11 Nov 2013 01:20:42 GMT'), ('access-control-allow-origin', '*'), ('content-type', 'application/json; charset=utf-8'), ('x-ratelimit-reset', '1384134844')]
{}

https
GET
api.github.com
None
/repos/jacquev6/PyGithub/stats/commit_activity
{'Authorization': 'Basic login_and_password_removed', 'User-Agent': 'PyGithub/Python'}

[...]
```

If you remove the second response with 200 code and only keep the 202 response, you can see that the unit test fails.

If you could let me know how to solve the problem, I could try to send you a PR, together with its unit test.

Thank you! üôè

It would be helpful if there was a mechanism in `Github` objects to update the token used by the requester and to reset its `__authorizationHeader`.

This looks like it would be straight-forward enough and I'd be happy to contribute, but I'd want to make sure I consider any other use cases and how they ought to be included.

For example, is it enough to include something along the following lines?

```py
# Requester.py
class Requester:
    def update_login_or_token(self, login_or_token):
        self.__authorizationHeader = "token " + login_or_token


# MainClass.py
class Github:

```

Personally, as long as the code is documented, and tested sounds fine to include to me if you want to put up a PR. `Requester.update_login_or_token` probably won't be quite that simple, but it looks like a good start.

title: Update token used by requester

body:
The following code in unit test throws ResourceWarning for open connections and I cannot see a method to use to close these down. Am I missing something, or is this a possible memory/connection leak oversight?

```
repository = "someuser\somerepository"
connection = Github (self.token)
connection.get_repo (repository).get_latest_release ().get_assets () [0]
del connection
```

comments.body: I haven't been able to dive in the code right now. I think it might have something to do with the design decision to keep connections open so they can be reused. Is there a specific reason for you to delete the connection object?

Hi @jobveldhuis, that sounds a reasonable conclusion and therefore sounds like the connection leak warning may be a "by design" thing in this library.
The reason I'm deleting the connection object in my unit test is because each unit test is instantiating a new connection as some settings potentially change between unit tests as a result of me unit testing input validation into my app. It's highly unlikely this will cause me an issue in the real-world use of the code as in real-world use I would only ever open and use the 1 connection to GitHub and therefore the "leaked connection" would close with the app. It's more me trying to ensure my ResourceWarning in unit testing isn't surfacing my incorrect use of the library.
Thanks

You're welcome. What library are you using for unit testing? Because I think you could pull these tests off without the ResourceWarning by using some sort of 'setup' function that is ran before every individual test.

I'm using unittest natively in Python. I can suppress with a warnings.simplefilter ("ignore", ResourceWarning) call immediately before the call that orphans a connection. I am only using this where I call the method that orphans the connection though, so I can catch any other programming issues I may have elsewhere in my code.

Yes, it's a design decision to persist connections -- HTTPS is a heavy weight protocol, given it requires client and server to exchange keys and agree on SSL ciphers to use, so anything we can do to cut down on that negotiation is a big win. There is an internal variable inside the Requester class that you can reach in and set to False if you really want to experiment (called `__persist`).

We are using `PyGithub` in a dynamic way, create different `Github` object on demand, we found there are multiple session connection pools exist at the same time, those connections are not closed until GC. After digging into `PyGithub` code, I found several issues:

1. misleading class attribute `__connection` in [Requester.py](https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/bcca758d13ef466a7ae13f4d9d99689ba0043640/github/Requester.py#L233C1-L233C1), all [usages](https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/bcca758d13ef466a7ae13f4d9d99689ba0043640/github/Requester.py#L809C10-L809C10) are supposed to be instance attribute.
2. `Requester` is not thread safe, when there are multiple usages from different threads, `__connection` can be overwritten.
3. there is no easy way to close session in [HTTPSRequestsConnectionClass](https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/bcca758d13ef466a7ae13f4d9d99689ba0043640/github/Requester.py#L101) or [HTTPRequestsConnectionClass](https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/bcca758d13ef466a7ae13f4d9d99689ba0043640/github/Requester.py#L168).
4. connections created by [__customConnection](https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/bcca758d13ef466a7ae13f4d9d99689ba0043640/github/Requester.py#L468) are not collected, there is no way to close them afterwards.

Proposals:
1. change class attribute `__connection` to instance attribute explicitly.
2. guard `__connection` with a lock when write to it.
3. add a `close` method to `Requester` and used in MainClass like:
    ```python
       with Github(auth=auth) as g:
         # do something
    ```
    and can call it explicitly
    ```python
        g = Github(auth=auth)
        # do something
        g.close()
    ```
4. collect all connections created by `__customConnection` and close them in `close`

If above proposals sound good, I can prepare a PR for it.

title: GitHub Class Doesn't Clean-up Connections After Use

body:
I am writing a project that should be able to allow specific users to automatically perform some actions on some file contents after logging in. I tried to alter some of the code and I'm getting some strange behaviour.

I have scoured the internet and I am literally using the exact documented code as copy and pasted, yet it always returns: github.GithubException.GithubException: 401 {"message": "Requires authentication", "documentation_url": "https://docs.github.com/rest/reference/users#get-the-authenticated-user"}. 

My username and password are correct before you ask. I have run my code with PATkey tokens to ensure the rest of it works, but I obviously cannot distribute those publicly. The passwordbox function will return the string password put into this, so this isn't the issue either. From what I gather, this code should run perfectly fine, but it doesn't for me: 
https://pygithub.readthedocs.io/en/latest/introduction.html
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/46524697/login-problems-using-pygithub

I can't find _any_ working examples of logging in with username and password, only tokens. Is it possible my code is not the issue?

Here is my code which causes the error: 
```python
from github import Github
from easygui import passwordbox  # This works similarly to getpass, but works for pycharm without going to terminal. 

def login():
    # Ask for login details
    username = input("Username? ")
    _password = passwordbox("Please enter your password for user: {} ".format(username))

    # Login
    g = Github(username, _password)
    del _password 
    user = g.get_user()
    
    login = user.login
    print("Login Successful!")

login()
```
I hope that I'm an idiot and that the solution is simple. I understand that the initial github instance is unauthorised, but that error message tells that I am required to login before I login?! Surely

comments.body: Nevermind, you NEED to update your main page documentation. Github deprecated the use of username/password login for anything besides direct website login https://hackaday.com/2020/09/15/githubs-move-away-from-passwords-a-sign-of-things-to-come/. Update this: https://pygithub.readthedocs.io/en/latest/introduction.html, please. The code above would have worked half a year ago.

For the record it unfortunately isn't exactly as simple as this. For github.com username/password is no longer possible with the API as noted. However, for GitHub Enterprise Server (the self hosted on premise server) username and password is still an option: https://docs.github.com/en/enterprise-server@3.1/rest/overview/other-authentication-methods for 99% of users they won't ever care and as such the docs being as they are are fine. But I just wanted to note this here for the other 1%.

In the web interface I can easily retrieve/access all issues directly from the issues subsection, simply by setting `user:ORGANIZATION`  in the filtered search. 

The url for this is also simple:
 - https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aopen+is%3Aissue+user%3AORGANIZATION+archived%3Afalse

and if I set `ORGANIZATION` to the organization I manage the results populate.  There are multiple linked repositories so it is important to be able to get _all_ issues to manage a new release and accompanying notes.

I cannot for the life of me figure out how to achieve this either via PyGithub or directly via the API, as both appear to restrict the returned issues list to the `authenticated user` and provide no means to 'set' this to the organization in the request params the way you can from the web interface.

The web interface also appears to return a full webpage rather than a concise JSON object suitable for parsing, so using that directly also appears to be a no-go. 

Is there any way to achieve this other than scraping the html response from the web url?

comments.body:
I just needed to use the [search_issues](https://pygithub.readthedocs.io/en/latest/github.html?highlight=search_issues#github.MainClass.Github.search_issues) API.  This worked exactly as expected, once I figured it out:
```python
from github import Github

g = Github(MY_TOKEN)
for issue in g.search_issues("is:open is:issue org:MY_ORGANIZATION archived:false"):
    print(issue)
```

There is a little typing issue with the library, specifically with the `contents.decoded_content` attribute.

```py
from github import Github
github_client = Github(token)
repo = github_client.get_repo(repo_name)
contents = repo.get_contents(file_path, ref="master")

comments.body: Sorry, I missed this bug! This is your issue, you're calling decoded_content on a list, not on a ContentFile object directly -- if GitHub returns a list, we do as well, so you need to check for that and iterate over it if required.

body:
I'm trying to fetch all the repositories of a user but this seems to give an error:

```
>>> print([i.name for i in g.get_user(login='Divkix').get_repos(visibility='all')])
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
TypeError: get_repos() got an unexpected keyword argument 'visibility'
```

Version: 1.54.1

comments.body: Sadly, that is not supported by GitHub. The endpoint we're using for that method is https://docs.github.com/en/rest/reference/repos#list-repositories-for-a-user , and it has no support for visibility.

I did run into this today as well and found a way to archive this.
When [`get_user()`](https://pygithub.readthedocs.io/en/latest/github.html#github.MainClass.Github.get_user) is invoked without parameters it returns an `AuthenticatedUser` object and [`get_repos()`](https://pygithub.readthedocs.io/en/latest/github_objects/AuthenticatedUser.html#github.AuthenticatedUser.AuthenticatedUser.get_repos) on that uses the `user/repos` endpoint allowing for listing of private repos as well. When `get_user("Shegox")` is invoked with a login a `NamedUser` is returned and invoking [`get_repos()`](https://pygithub.readthedocs.io/en/latest/github_objects/NamedUser.html#github.NamedUser.NamedUser.get_repos) on a NamedUser uses the `users/{user}/repos` endpoint, returning only public repos.

Following works to list all repositories for the authenticated user (and you can only see the repos for the authenticated user):
```py
>>> print(*g.get_user().get_repos(affiliation="owner", visibility="all"), sep="\n")
Repository(full_name="Shegox/go-private-test")
Repository(full_name="Shegox/shegox.github.io")
...
```

body: Hey :wave: I noticed that while calling the following: ``` ... branch = repository.get_branch("master") review_count = branch.get_required_pull_request_reviews().required_approving_review_count ``` The `review_count` or `required_approving_review_count` attribute will always return a number >= 1, which is not accurate especially when the `Require pull request reviews before merging` option is not checked / disabled, but in that case, it should return either Null or another value that translate for the "disabled" status. Similarly, there is no way to check whether `Require pull request reviews before merging` is checked / enabled or not, so somehow you may want to rely on the `required_approving_review_count` but that's also not accurate. Much appreciated. Thanks!

Simply a question about the PyGitHub API; Why does the Repository.contents_url attribute return a valid contents URL with `{+path}` appended to the end? I would almost understand `{path}`, but `{+path}` seems odd to me, and I can't find anything about this online.

It is not special python formatting to use a plus sign here (and only with `str.format_map` can you easily format it). Nothing online talks about a GitHub API URL containing `{+path}` in it's API responses (unless that's exactly what's going on here and my googling failed).

Sorry for the stupid question, but this is very odd to me, and with a lack of source code for `contents_url` attribute (i.e. I can't find it, or it's returned from the API), I'm unable to answer why there is a plus sign in the formatting field.

I'm trying to update a file in one of my repositories. My code works for a while, but then `PyGithub` gives the following traceback:

    Traceback (most recent call last):
      File "main.py", line 30, in <module>
        repo.update_file("example.txt", "Updated".format(author), update(), file.sha)
      File "/home/dio/.local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/github/Repository.py", line 2124, in update_file
        input=put_parameters,
     File "/home/dio/.local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/github/Requester.py", line 317, in requestJsonAndCheck
        verb, url, parameters, headers, input, self.__customConnection(url)
      File "/home/dio/.local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/github/Requester.py", line 340, in __check
        raise self.__createException(status, responseHeaders, output)
    github.GithubException.GithubException: 409 {"message": "example.txt does not match <string of very long numbers>", "documentation_url": "https://docs.github.com/rest/reference/repos#create-or-update-file-contents"}
    
 The token that I'm using has full `repo` scope permissions, so why is this happening? How do I prevent it?

comments.body: I got the same error when running my app concurrently, but each run updates their different files at same github branch.

409 is Conflict, I'm guessing GitHub is hashing the file in question (hence <string of very long numbers>), and get back something different from it expects. My theory here is GitHub hasn't updated the storage from your last update before you send another one, leading to this explosion. My suggestions are to not update so fast using the API, or switch to a library that works on a git repository directly, such as GitPython.

Is there a way to find out the wait time required when updating using the API? Currently experiencing the same issue in the following code and getting the same error.

```
contents_json["plugins"][0][plugin_name] = plugin_version
print(contents_json)
print(wordpress_sha.sha)
repo.update_file("wordpress.json", "Second test of the update", str(contents_json), wordpress_sha.sha, branch=open_pr.get("branch_name"))

body:
### Problem Statement

```bash
$ python scripts/add_attribute.py Permissions triage bool
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<...>\PyGithub\scripts\add_attribute.py", line 124, in <module>
    line = lines[i].rstrip()
IndexError: list index out of range
```
--> Adding a new attribute at the end of the existing list of attributes in class `Permissions` fails.
--> In this case the last attribute name was "push", so "triage" comes last.
https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/34d097ce473601624722b90fc5d0396011dd3acb/github/Permissions.py#L63-L72

### Solution Approach

In case the new attribute name will result in adding it at the end of the list of attributes, then the processing within the script at https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/master/scripts/add_attribute.py#L89 was already processing the next source code line which already contains the `_initAttributes` function.
Subsequently at https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/master/scripts/add_attribute.py#L122 `inInit` is set to `False`, but only checked again after reading already the next line. This means the following code block will never again notice the place of the `_initAttributes` and fails at the end of the file due to endless loop.

Problem can be fixed by conditionally remembering we already reached the `_initAttributes` function, so replace:
https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/34d097ce473601624722b90fc5d0396011dd3acb/scripts/add_attribute.py#L122

with

```python
inInit = True if line == "    def _initAttributes(self):" else False
```

comments.body:
Using the fix on my local repo allowed me to run the problematic statement without errors.
Please advise if some sort of additional unit testing is needed. In case yes, please hint on how to define a proper test condition (basically the assertion would be to not run into an exception?! Not sure if that would be a value adding test case...).

Like @dhruvmanila said in his comment (https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/issues/1803#issuecomment-751656549):

comments.body:
[That method](https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/master/github/PullRequest.py#L463) accepts a list, the documentation does not clearly state what type of elements should it contain but according to GitHub, it should be a list of dictionary objects for Python. Each dictionary represents a comment with the necessary information.

https://docs.github.com/en/free-pro-team@latest/rest/reference/pulls#create-a-review-for-a-pull-request
Fill in the required fields as mentioned. Also, you won't be able to use the `line` field as that is only available with the comfort-fade preview headers. You will have to use the `position` field which is different than the `line` field.

You mean something like

```python
comments = [
   {
       "path": "folder/file.ext",
       "position": 42,
       "body": "My body for the review",
   }
]
```

body:
A thing I found missing in the PullRequest object

https://docs.github.com/en/free-pro-team@latest/rest/reference/pulls#create-a-review-comment-for-a-pull-request

Would it be possible to add it ? Does it already exist ?

comments.body: It already exists although without the comfort-fade preview, so you won't be able to post multi-line comments: https://pygithub.readthedocs.io/en/latest/github_objects/PullRequest.html#github.PullRequest.PullRequest.create_review_comment

Thank you, I was tired so I didn't take a good look at the doc even though I search through it 3 times... I was certain this method was made for something else..  anyway, that's great!

While I'm at it (I'll close the issue afterwards), how can I access the changes ? The idea being I need to run a regex on each line and post a review comment if needed.

Also, is it possible to create review comments inside a review group like you can on github ? Like "start review" then "add to review" and finally submit review ?

Sorry for the poor text quality, sent from my phone :)

> While I'm at it (I'll close the issue afterwards), how can I access the changes ? The idea being I need to run a regex on each line and post a review comment if needed.

You can get the contents of a repository or file from the [contents API](https://docs.github.com/en/free-pro-team@latest/rest/reference/repos#contents).

> Also, is it possible to create review comments inside a review group like you can on github ? Like "start review" then "add to review" and finally submit review ?

Yes, through [this endpoint](https://docs.github.com/en/free-pro-team@latest/rest/reference/pulls#create-a-review-for-a-pull-request) you create a review and in the `comments` field you list all the comments you want to post on the specific lines.

Thanks !

> You can get the contents of a repository or file from the contents API.

About this, is there a way to get the changes of the PR without having to parse the diff url content?

Would https://pygithub.readthedocs.io/en/latest/github_objects/PullRequest.html#github.PullRequest.PullRequest.get_files work ?

Because I only want to parse/regex and comment on the lines that were changed

I'm able to get the changes of the files through `gh.get_repo("python/python-docs-fr").get_pull(1035).get_files()[0].patch`. Any idea how I can parse it/get the correct line number for the review comment that goes with it ?

Alright then me again resolving my own issue:

`print(gh.get_repo("pydocteur/fake-docs").get_pull(15).get_files()[0].patch)` has 6 lines.

using `gh.get_repo("pydocteur/fake-docs").get_pull(15).create_review_comment("Position 4", lat_commit, "contents.po", 4)` will place a comment on the 5th line (4th position because arrays ;) )

so it seems I have everything I need, back to coding, thank you so mucb @dhruvmanila for the help and all the other maintainers of pygithub <3

PyGithub 1.54 is the last version that supports Python 3.5, however the broken pyjwt dependency makes it unusable in Python 3.5.
We unfortunately are not able to upgrade Python in the production system, could you kindly release a 1.54 hotfix (sth like 1.54_2) that pins pyjwt to < 2.0.0 without dropping Python 3.5 support?

Thank you!

By the way, version 1.54.1 is confusing in terms of pyjwt because it's pyjwt 2.0.0 works for Python >=3.6 (you may be noticed https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/issues/1796 is using py3.5). If PyGithub decides to drop py3.5, pinning pyjwt to <2.0.0 does not bring benefit.

comments.body: So this is actually difficult due to 1.54.1 being out. The only option I can see is releasing a 1.54.2 that does not include the changes from 1.54.1 and then releasing those as 1.55, but that makes me sad. @sfdye What are your thoughts here?

> PyGithub 1.54 is the last version that supports Python 3.5, however the broken pyjwt dependency makes it unusable in Python 3.5.

We could fix the `pyjwt` dependency issue and backport the fix to say `1.53.1`. PR welcome

However our publish pipeline failed, so you can currently install it via git tags, but not pypi.
Publish pipeline issue filed as https://github.com/pypa/warehouse/issues/9361
v1.54.0.1 has been released -- https://pypi.org/project/PyGithub/1.54.0.1/

comments.body: I mean, it seems like you're iterating over all github users that exists, make sense it would break

I think changing the get_users function to use loops instead of recursion would make it lighter and it would stop breaking. 

Logically there is no reason why function should break just because there are several thousand users.

It's a tiny bit more complicated than that.

`get_users()` does not use recursion -- it returns a `PaginatedList`, which then knows how to keep track of which page it is on, and so on. I suspect what is going on is you were getting rate limited. If you're going to iterate over every single user, perhaps do it per page? (IE, use the `get_page()` function, iterate over those.

body: Removed in https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/pull/1738/ but we've got an application which uses it and inheriting the base class and adding this method results it lots of boilerplate code due to using `self.__requester` attribute which isn't available in the inherited class.

comments.body: Are you able to switch the application to using the other get_installation() method?

> Are you able to switch the application to using the other get_installation() method?

IDK really. At the top of my head I think no. The use case is that we have the application ID and using that and the removed method we get an `Installation` object and then iterate on `inst.get_repos()` to find all of the authorized repositories for this installation.

I have taken a look at the installation object and the `GithubIntegration` class and I propose the following changes:

`GithubIntegration` should only be used to generate the JWT or installation access token for the app/installation. No endpoints should be provided in that class. Once the user has generated the appropriate credentials, they should be passed to the main `Github` class and make all the API calls through the instance. The current `GithubIntegration.get_installation()` function [should actually be in the `Repository` class.](https://docs.github.com/en/free-pro-team@latest/rest/reference/apps#get-a-repository-installation-for-the-authenticated-app)

The function `Github.get_installation()` is indeed a [valid endpoint](https://docs.github.com/en/free-pro-team@latest/rest/reference/apps#get-an-installation-for-the-authenticated-app) which should be provided with the `installation_id` parameter and the `Github` object should be initialized with the installation access token. As I mentioned before, the `installation` object is missing a lot of attributes.

@s-t-e-v-e-n-k I can implement this change but I need a go/no-go.
@dhruvmanila Absolutely, please go for it. If you do re-add get_installation() it needs a docstring and tests, of which it had neither before.

@s-t-e-v-e-n-k I want to discuss something: As per [my comment here](https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/issues/1730#issuecomment-723556956), I have been using the class to programmatically get the installation ID for a specific installation in the repository (`GithubIntegration.get_installation(owner, repo)`) and using that I generate the installation access token and then make all the API calls as an installation. Now, with the proposed change of moving the method to `Repository` object, the process will become like so:
1. Instantiate a `GithubIntegration` object and get the JWT.
2. Use the JWT to instantiate the `Github` object.
4. Get the specific installation for the repository using `get_installation_by_repo()`
5. Get the ID of the installation.
6. Generate the installation access token using that ID.
7. Use the installation access token to instantiate the `Github` object and now we will be able to act as an installation.

This seems cumbersome but this is the way the library has been set up to access different objects from the main `Github` object. The [same function from the comment](https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/issues/1730#issuecomment-723556956) will become something like this:

```python
def _get_access_token():
    private_key = pathlib.Path(PRIVATE_KEY_FILEPATH).read_text(encoding="utf-8")
    github_integration = github.GithubIntegration(APP_ID, private_key)
    jwt = github_integration.create_jwt()
    github_api = github.Github(jwt=jwt)
    installation = github_api.get_installation_by_repo(OWNER, REPO)
    access_token = github_integration.get_access_token(installation.id)
    return access_token.token

token = _get_access_token()
github_api = github.Github(login_or_token=token)

# make all the API calls as an installation ...
```
This will need to be documented properly in the examples section which will be done in a separate PR.

~**EDIT:** This is actually incorrect. We cannot request to get a repository using a JWT which means the method to get a repository installation should be in the main class.~ ***Updated the code and steps***
If you want to also create convenience functions to make this less cumbersome, I'm all ears.

JWT and installation access token cannot be provided together and also they have an expiration time so a user will need to generate another one. It seems cumbersome as this is being done only for testing purposes. If the user is accessing the API as an installation, the app will most likely be working with webhooks in which they receive the installation ID in each payload.

Not sure the status here, but I'm facing something similar. In Github Actions you're given an app installation token but not the installation ID. What I want to do is determine what permissions the installation token has on current repository. To do that, you'd get the [/installation/repositories](https://docs.github.com/en/rest/reference/apps#list-repositories-accessible-to-the-app-installation) endpoint and look at the `permissions` object.

However, there's currently no way to go straight from an installation token to an `Installation` to use the `get_repos()` method. @dhruvmanila's comment at https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/pull/1791/files#r545713464 makes sense to me, but I wanted to see how you all thought these concepts fit together.

body:
The link, https://pygithub.readthedocs.io/en/latest/examples/MainClass.html#search-repositories-based-on-number-of-issues-with-good-first-issue, says that it can search  issues with good-first-issue.

However, the result seems wrong.

For example, there is project whose number of good first issue larger than 400, such as elastic/kibana.

And when I search using the following code : 
     query = 'good-first-issue:>0' or query = 'good-first-issue:>1'
    repositories = g.search_repositories(query=query)

the number of project ">0" is less than the number of project ">1"


**Therefore, is there some query that can search projects whose issues with different labels?**

comments.body: Hello, a group of student developers I am a part of are claiming this issue, and currently working toward a solution to which handles different issue labels that have the same purpose.

We have tested several different queries, including "good-first-issue". We discovered that the query "good-first-issues:>x" where "issues" is plural and x is some number (such as 3 in the[ PyGithub example](https://pygithub.readthedocs.io/en/latest/examples/MainClass.html#search-repositories-based-on-number-of-issues-with-good-first-issue)), seems to behave differently than other queries. The other queries we tested seemed to only return results which exactly matched the issue label in the query string. 

When we tested "good-first-issues:>3" as a Github search online, we discovered that unlike other queries, which returned both issues and repositories, "good-first-issues" returns no issues and many repositories. Unlike the other queries, which returned only repositories with issue labels which exactly match the query string, "good-first-issues" was returning repositories with issue labels that both did and did not match exactly, such as "good-first-issues" and "good first issue". 

Is a reasonable exception that "good-first-issues:>x" is a special query?

title: The query run error results

body:
Recently it looks like you pinned requests to <2.25 (https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/commit/d159425f36dc7f68766cc980e262e9287e5f111c) which is incompatible with urllib3>=1.26 (https://github.com/gabrielfalcao/HTTPretty/issues/409). But it looks like pip is not downgrading urllib3 if it is already installed, so perhaps it makes sense to also pin urllib3? We ran into this here: https://github.com/pangeo-data/pangeo-cloud-federation/issues/893:
```
requests 2.24.0 has requirement urllib3!=1.25.0,!=1.25.1,<1.26,>=1.21.1, but you'll have urllib3 1.26.2 which is incompatible.
```
We will pin on our side but I thought it would be worthwhile to let you know. Thanks.

comments.body: Closing because I see that this pin is in the process of being reverted (https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/pull/1763). Thank you!

comments.body:
You need an installation access token to act as an app and do things with an app. Also, you do not need to create the JWT manually, we provide methods for that.

```python
# Fill the required information
APP_ID = 
PRIVATE_TOKEN =  
INSTALLATION_ID = 

github_integration = github.GithubIntegration(APP_ID, PRIVATE_TOKEN)
# Note that installation access tokens last only for 1 hour, you will need to regenerate them after they expire.
access_token = github_integration.get_access_token(INSTALLATION_ID)

login = github.Github(access_token)
# Pass in the parameters as necessary
repo = login.get_repo()                # get the repository
check_run = repo.create_check_run()    # create the check run
check_run.edit()                       # update the check run
Thanks, I will try this. But I am curious to know how you found this. Is this documented?

I created a bot for the repo I am currently maintaining, so I did some research into it and that's how I know all this.

Installation access token: https://docs.github.com/en/free-pro-team@latest/rest/reference/apps#create-an-installation-access-token-for-an-app
Permissions required for an app: https://docs.github.com/en/free-pro-team@latest/rest/reference/permissions-required-for-github-apps
Building GitHub apps: https://docs.github.com/en/free-pro-team@latest/developers/apps/building-github-apps

Hope this helps! You can explore more through the documentation.

body:
While there are some examples on how to work with [Pull Requests](https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/tree/master/doc/examples) there is effectually nothing documented around how to obtain information about the **review status** from a PR object.

As I have a specific PR, I do want to findout the CI check report on it and the current review status: if anyone approved it or requested changes, so I would figure out how far is from being ready to merge.

So far all I got was the `pull_request.url` property but how do I endup instantiating a PullRequestReview out of it? I was not able to see any example, doc or even tests doing it. After half and hour of googling and being unable to find any example, I decided that maybe we need a simple example.

comments.body:
> I do want to findout the CI check report on it 

This can be found out using the Checks API on the latest commit pushed to the PR. The API is quite new and the CheckRun object and endpoints were [added](https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/pull/1727) just a few days back. Once that is published in the next version, you will be able to use it. Note that some CI uses the Status API to send the status of the tests.

> but how do I endup instantiating a PullRequestReview out of it?

All objects contain either a `create_` or `get_` methods which are used to either do something or get something. In your case, as you want to create a review, look for `create_` prefixed methods in the PullRequest object: `create_comment(), create_review_comment(), create_review, ...`

For reference always look at the GitHub provided documentation: https://docs.github.com/en/free-pro-team@latest/rest/reference/pulls
This issue has been automatically marked as stale because it has not had recent activity. It will be closed if no further activity occurs. Thank you for your contributions.

body: I'm running 1.53, and the `stargazers_count`, `watchers_count`, `forks_count`, and `network_count` seem to be mixed up.  Running against a repo with 3 watchers, 20 stars, and 94 forks, `stargazers_count` returns 20, `watchers_count` returns 20, `forks_count` returns 3, and `network_count` returns 94.  Seems like `watchers_count` is returning the number of stargazers, `forks_count` is returning the number of watchers, and `networks_count` is returning the number of forks.  I'm also not sure what `networks_count` is supposed to return.

comments.body: I just checked on another repo that has 59 watchers, 500 stars and 94 forks (previous one was a fork of this repo) and pygithub `stargazers_count` returns 500, `watchers_count` returns 500, `forks_count` returns 94, and `networks_count` returns 94.  Seems inconsistent, whatever is going on.
We are at the mercy of whatever data GitHub returns here, sadly -- we have no transparency into how GitHub calculates those numbers.
I see.  So the problem is the data from github being incorrect.  Is there an alternative way to get that information?  Perhaps `get_stargazers().totalCount` would be more reliable?

Ah, maybe I am misunderstanding what some of the fields mean.  `forks_count` seems to be forks of the repo directly, while `network_count` is the total number of forks across from the original repo.  So those numbers actually make sense, and the stargazers count is correct.  However, `watchers_count` still appears to be wrong, and `get_watchers` appears to return the same thing as `get_stargazers`.
Ah, it seems I need the subscriber count (why does the terminology need to be so different between the user interface and the API???)

body:
According to this https://github.blog/2012-09-21-easier-builds-and-deployments-using-git-over-https-and-oauth/,
 tokens are exposed:

> Note: Tokens should be treated as passwords. Putting the token in the clone URL will result in Git writing it to the .git/config file in plain text. Unfortunately, this happens for HTTP passwords, too. We decided to use the token as the HTTP username to avoid colliding with credential helpers available for OS X, Windows, and Linux.

Does this library also expose tokens if used to authenticate?

Like:

```python
g = Github(os.environ["DEV_BOT_TOKEN"])
```

We use this lib in our GH actions setup and don't want to leak tokens.

comments.body:
No, encapsulation prevents anyone to access the token or any other authorization details from outside the object. Also, even if you enable logging for debugging purposes, the tokens and other authorization details are removed before it gets logged.

Here is where the authorization details are stored: https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/master/github/Requester.py#L279 and here is the function which logs on debug: https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/master/github/Requester.py#L588
Correct, we don't log tokens, or write them to disk, they are in memory only.

Something is not working well here. I've been trying to use PyGithub with a new token, it has every permission it needs, works properly for the same query in curl, yet it fails with PyGithub.

edit: After some debugging into the library, it seems that the `__authorizationHeader` originally set and the actually sent request's `Authorization` headers are different. The first uses a `token <token>` value with the token value I've supplied, but the second one uses a `Basic` auth with a value I haven't recognized after decoding. But after reading [this answer on SO](https://stackoverflow.com/a/60451840/238845), I realized that the same header dropping might be happening here, and indeed, the token is what I had specified in my `.netrc` file. Once I've updated that, things started to work.

Hey folks!! I figured it out; at least in my instance. 
For those of you still getting this error, React to this if your org is private.

It looks like it has to do with a minor change with how the python requests library handles auth headers. You can't specify the header manually as there's a special location that needs to be updated.

https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/001970d4a828017f704f6744a5775b4207a6523c/github/Requester.py#L122
For a test I inserted this below that line:
```
        for header in self.headers:
            if str(self.headers[header]).startswith('token'):
                self.session.auth=(tuple(self.headers[header].split(' ')))
```

This is based on how auth is set here for sessions: https://requests.readthedocs.io/en/latest/user/advanced/
and here for non sessions: https://requests.readthedocs.io/en/latest/user/authentication/

I'm not sure why the auth header is overwritten when auth is unset BUT it's got me working right now. Going to see if I can work on a patch

Edit 1:
While I don't have a netrc file; the cause may be related : https://requests.readthedocs.io/en/latest/user/authentication/#netrc-authentication


Edit 2:
This is where it started checking directories OUTside the script for netrc
https://github.com/psf/requests/commit/ba543713d35067866d68b09f644042c0c021a8ba#diff-b4b6ac4e508ec3e142b8b8a3cf33b9ab925e3bdd03dbbe859384760746b1ac76R172

Which time wise matches when this issue started

For me, the issue was the `~/.netrc` file. Contents in the file were being picked up even when the token is passed to the `Gitthub` constructor.

Solution:
- Try deleting or updating `~/.netrc` accordlingly

BasicAuth or a custom authenication class can be used if you have no controll over .netrc file:

```python
import requests

GITHUB_KEY = "ghp_***"

class BearerAuthToken(requests.auth.AuthBase):
    def __call__(self, r):

        "https://api.github.com/graphql",
        json={"query": "query { viewer { login }}"}},
        auth=BearerAuthToken() ,
)
```

body:
Good morning, I'm working on a python script to check repos and migrating them and I found myself needing to query open issues on Github and I notice that when doing:
```
g = Github(args.gitHubToken)
repo = g.get_repo("<orgname>/<reponame>)
open_issues = repo.get_issues(state='open')
```
This is returning both the **open issues** and **open PRs**... is this the correct behavior? is my query wrong?/ is the response incorrect?

I'll appreciate your comments.

Regards
Hvithval

comments.body:
From https://docs.github.com/en/free-pro-team@latest/rest/reference/issues#list-repository-issues :

Note: GitHub's REST API v3 considers every pull request an issue, but not every issue is a pull request. For this reason, "Issues" endpoints may return both issues and pull requests in the response. You can identify pull requests by the pull_request key. Be aware that the id of a pull request returned from "Issues" endpoints will be an issue id. To find out the pull request id, use the "List pull requests" endpoint.

I wouldn't call it correct behaviour, but it the existing GitHub behaviour.

title: Search for Issues also brings PRs

comments.body: Do you mean the search query run via curl or the search function on the website? Because they are very different.
I've tried search via curl and compared the result with the paginated list. Some queries returned little to none duplicates but other returned many duplicates while iterating the paginated list.

I'm seeing the same issue using `search_repositoies`. I run the same search twice in a row and I git a different set of results. Sometimes I get the expected result set. Other times, I get a result where one item is missing and another exists twice.

Setting `sort='updated'` in the serach_repositories call appears to help.

Maybe the default search order produces undeterministic paging. So as the PagianatedList retrieves the individual page results, things slide back and forth between pages and are missed or duplicated.

body:
commit.files result has a limit of 300 files.
I have a large commit that has 926 changed files and I need to list the changes.
when I use         
files = commit.files
print(len(commit.files))
I got 300.
Can I get all the files?

comments.body: We are at the mercy of whatever data GitHub returns here. Files is populated directly from the JSON returned. If you need to do something like that, I would suggest a local clone and using a library to work with the git data directly, such as https://www.pygit2.org/

@s-t-e-v-e-n-k @jessieyanl sorry for reopening an old issue, but - [`/commits/{ref}` endpoint](https://docs.github.com/en/rest/commits/commits?apiVersion=2022-11-28#get-a-commit) is (at least now) paginated, meaning you can get up to 3000  files per commit:

> Note: If there are more than 300 files in the commit diff and the default JSON media type is requested, the response will include pagination link headers for the remaining files, up to a limit of 3000 files. Each page contains the static commit information, and the only changes are to the file listing.

That might be the same kind of pagination that had recently been supported for `Repository.compare().commits`: #2882

Happy to review fixes for `Commit.files`.

That's a limit of the Github API though, right?

> Note: GitHub's REST API v3 **considers every pull request an issue**, but not every issue is a pull request. For this reason, "Issues" endpoints **may return both issues and pull requests** in the response. You can **identify pull requests by the pull_request key**. Be aware that the id of a pull request returned from "Issues" endpoints will be an issue id. To find out the pull request id, use the "List pull requests" endpoint.

https://docs.github.com/en/free-pro-team@latest/rest/reference/issues#list-repository-issues

I see. Then, it's basically what I am already doing in the `is_pull_request` conditional.

Not sure if this is something worth adding to the API or if you folks want to strictly follow what it provides. 
Feel free to close the issue if it's not an adequate request.
We will only implement what GitHub does to save the amount of code we have to carry around, thank you for the large amount of information you gave!

should be an int according to the Github docs

def id(self) -> int: ...

title: Guest auth

body:
Hi,

I'm a big fan of this project, and it has made our lives easier and better for a while now.

One of the things I'm looking at right now is to improve some of the workflows we have when working with forks. 
There's a couple of different things we do, where we want to make changes to directories via PRs, rather than directly in the repos. 

It has not been immediately obvious to me how to ensure appropriately synced forks over time without spinning out subprocess and git CLI with local repo clone, but I've just realized after coming across this stackoverflow: https://stackoverflow.com/a/27762278/5438386 that there is a neat API centric way of doing it.
Specifically
```
Get upstream ref /repos/upstream/repo/git/refs/heads/master, and get the hash from it
Update your fork PATCH /repos/my/repo/git/refs/heads/master with the same hash.
```
From that it's easy to create a `branch_from_upstream` type function that is so central to many of our workflows.

As I'm starting to look at building out a more fork workflow centric class I wonder whether some of this would make sense to contribute upstream to this project, or if these higher level flows make most sense to keep out of this?

comments.body:
I've been digging for a while for this exact thing, it was either using CLI or Gitpython but will have to use local file system to store the files, and with the number of repos that we're maintaining it gets messy sometimes.
I also tried deleting forks and re-forking but for some reason it's not updating the master.

I made a quick stab at what a wrapper project may look like: https://github.com/multicloud-ops/PyGithubFork

I'll be using this for the time being...
This issue has been automatically marked as stale because it has not had recent activity. It will be closed if no further activity occurs. Thank you for your contributions.

Hello,

We use PyGithub to create PR, and sometimes get error with "base_tree is not a valid tree oid", and once this happens, the call will be constantly failing for a period of time (minutes to hours), however, the call could get back to work sometime later.
Stack trace:
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "gitpr3.py", line 138, in <module>
    update_pvc_name("amp-app-processing", "us-west-1a", "new_pvc", "new_ast_versions", "new_sdkdb_versions")
  File "gitpr3.py", line 54, in update_pvc_name
    tree = repo.create_git_tree(elements, base_tree=upstream.get_git_tree(upstream_master.object.sha))
  File "/Users/xuegecao/Workplace/Python/.virtualenvs/operator-with-latest/lib/python3.7/site-packages/github/Repository.py", line 1113, in create_git_tree
    "POST", self.url + "/git/trees", input=post_parameters
  File "/Users/xuegecao/Workplace/Python/.virtualenvs/operator-with-latest/lib/python3.7/site-packages/github/Requester.py", line 319, in requestJsonAndCheck
    verb, url, parameters, headers, input, self.__customConnection(url)
  File "/Users/xuegecao/Workplace/Python/.virtualenvs/operator-with-latest/lib/python3.7/site-packages/github/Requester.py", line 342, in __check
    raise self.__createException(status, responseHeaders, output)
github.GithubException.GithubException: 422 {"message": "base_tree is not a valid tree oid", "documentation_url": "https://developer.github.com/enterprise/2.19/v3/git/trees/#create-a-tree"}
```

Our code snippet, the code always fails on the last line `repo.create_git_tree`:
```
    github = Github(base_url=GITHUB_PIE, login_or_token=GAT)

    # Get upstream/master
    upstream = github.get_repo(REPO_NAME)
    upstream_master = upstream.get_git_ref("heads/master")

    repo = github.get_repo(USER_REPO)

    # We need to deal with trees and tree elements because the
    # Github repo update_file API creates one commit per-file
    # and that clutters up our Git history. This approach lets
    # us batch all the changes into a single commit.

    elements: List[InputGitTreeElement] = get_updated_elements(

* the repo we're handling is big and contributed by multiple teams, so I really don't know what could be the trigger of it

Could you suggest us an alternative way for PR creation? Thank!

body:
While trying to use PyGithub in my project, I've run into a bit of a dilemma. It appears that the `get_installations()` method is not present on the `Organization` object as described here: https://pygithub.readthedocs.io/en/latest/github_objects/Organization.html#github.Organization.Organization.get_installations

Perhaps there's a better way to achieve what I'm trying to do, so let me try to add a bit of context.

I've created a Github application and installed it into a Github Org that I own. Now, I'm trying to use PyGithub to clone a repo from that org using a JWT as described here: https://docs.github.com/en/free-pro-team@latest/developers/apps/authenticating-with-github-apps#generating-a-private-key

The trouble is, I seem to be in need of an `installation_id`, which I cannot figure out how to get programmatically using PyGithub.

Besides trying to use `Organization().get_installations()`, I have also explored the `GithubApplication` interface, yet that doesn't seem to include any method for calling https://docs.github.com/en/free-pro-team@latest/rest/reference/apps#list-installations-for-the-authenticated-app

Please advise!

comments.body: Sadly, it is because the docs on readthedocs are generated from master, and not the latest release, so you've found a method that was recently added. I'll be making a release over the next week or so.

@s-t-e-v-e-n-k, thanks for the quick reply! Do you have any other recommendations for me, I'm having a particularly hard time trying to figure out how to access this endpoint: https://docs.github.com/en/free-pro-team@latest/rest/reference/apps#list-repositories-accessible-to-the-app-installation using PyGithub, is that something that should be currently possible?
Our documentation should always contain the URL that is called, allowing you to search for which method calls a certain endpoint. `Installation.get_repos()` calls that endpoint.
@s-t-e-v-e-n-k, I did happen to notice that, what I can't seem to put my finger on is how to properly get the installations using PyGithub. Do you happen to know of any examples?
There seems to be a method conflict in MainClass around fetching an Installation.
https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/pull/1738 may help here -- @thoward27 are you able to test with that branch if `Github.get_installation(repo, owner)` works for you?

I used this in `GithubCredentials.py` to test `CheckRun` feature using an app I created:
```python
def __get_access_token():
    with open("path/to/private_key.pem") as file:
        private_key = file.read()
    app_id = APP_ID
    github_integration = github.GithubIntegration(app_id, private_key)
    installation = github_integration.get_installation(OWNER, REPO)
    access_token = github_integration.get_access_token(installation.id)
    return access_token.token
```
Also, I don't think you can clone a repository from the API.

I will note that is calling GithubIntegration.get_installation() not MainClass.get_installation().

However, does the posted example help @thoward27 ?

Yes, this is using `github.GithubIntegration.get_installation()` to access the installed app in the repository but the ***app needs to be installed in the repository*** and not in an organization to access this endpoint. 

> The trouble is, I seem to be in need of an installation_id, which I cannot figure out how to get programmatically using PyGithub.

To access information regarding an organization installation `Organization.get_installations()` needs to be released first, `installation_id` will be present in this endpoint for an organization. Also, it seems that the `installation` object is missing a lot of attributes according to [this](https://docs.github.com/en/free-pro-team@latest/rest/reference/orgs#list-app-installations-for-an-organization).

The `app_id` and `private_key` information will be in the application settings. This information will not change so it can be stored as an environment variable wherever your app is being hosted.

> Do you have any other recommendations for me, I'm having a particularly hard time trying to figure out how to access this endpoint: https://docs.github.com/en/free-pro-team@latest/rest/reference/apps#list-repositories-accessible-to-the-app-installation using PyGithub, is that something that should be currently possible?

To access this endpoint, the app needs to be installed in the required repositories. [This endpoint](https://docs.github.com/en/free-pro-team@latest/developers/apps/authenticating-with-github-apps#authenticating-as-an-installation) is used to get an access token for an installation without the need for the app to be in any repository or organization but this is not implemented in this library yet. 

@s-t-e-v-e-n-k The `installation` object is missing a lot of properties and methods. If you want I can take a look at that.

@thoward27 I'm going to close this issue since I'll be making a release that exports that method.

@dhruvmanila I would welcome any PR/issue at improving any part of this library, of course.

Is the [endpoint](https://docs.github.com/en/free-pro-team@latest/rest/reference/apps#get-an-organization-installation-for-the-authenticated-app) `GET /orgs/{org}/installation` available through the library? I _think_ it's what I need so that an application installed in an organization can create repositories that still don't exist... but I cannot find a way to do this (this == either the endpoint I mentioned, or being able to create repositories as an app, without that endpoint).

body:
In the file PullRequest.py

```
    def create_review_comment(self, body, commit_id, path, position):
        """
        :calls: `POST /repos/:owner/:repo/pulls/:number/comments <http://developer.github.com/v3/pulls/comments>`_
        :param body: string
        :param commit_id: :class:`github.Commit.Commit`
        :param path: string
        :param position: integer
        :rtype: :class:`github.PullRequestComment.PullRequestComment`
        """
        assert isinstance(body, str), body
        assert isinstance(commit_id, github.Commit.Commit), commit_id
        assert isinstance(path, str), path
        assert isinstance(position, int), position
        post_parameters = {
            "body": body,
            "commit_id": commit_id._identity,
            "path": path,
            "position": position,
        }
        headers, data = self._requester.requestJsonAndCheck(
            "POST", self.url + "/comments", input=post_parameters
        )
        return github.PullRequestComment.PullRequestComment(
            self._requester, headers, data, completed=True
        )
```

the code use "position" as the parameters for github pull request review comment api.

but in the docs of github api, the "position" is for

> Required without comfort-fade preview. The position in the diff where you want to add a review comment. Note this value is not the same as the line number in the file. For help finding the position value, read the note above. 

When we want to comment at the comfort-fate line, will get 

```
github.GithubException.GithubException: 422 {"message": "Validation Failed", "errors": [{"resource": "PullRequestReviewComment", "code": "invalid", "field": "position"}]
```

I think that if we want to create a review comment, we will create on comfort-fate line more.

The rate limit is 15000, to show that my login is valid.

But I don't Know How to user PyGithub to get the same effect.

I tried this, but it didn't work.
```pyhton 
>>> from github import Github
>>> g = Github(client_id='my_client_id', client_secret='my_client_secret')

>>> g.get_rate_limit()

# limit is 60 not 15000
```

comments.body:
@a523 To avoid the `FutureWarning` (which is to avoid sending `client_id` and `client_secret` in query strings which is deprecated) pass them as the first and second arguments. This will send them in the `Authorization` header as curl does (which is NOT deprecated):

```python
g = Github('my_client_id', 'my_client_secret')
```

However, I think that you may be getting a lower rate limit for another reason. Are you are using a "GitHub App" not an "Oauth App"? I found that I get a rate limit of 60 when I use the credentials for our org's Github App, but get a rate limit of 5000 when I use our Oauth App (on github.com)
@a523 Hi, I'm having the same issue. Did you figure it out?

The approach I described above (i.e. not using the `client_id` and `client_secret` kwargs) seems to work fine for us. See https://github.com/stencila/hub/blob/master/worker/util/github_api.py for reference.

@Chelsea-Z

> Did you figure it out

Yes,  that two methods can work for me.

Method 1Ôºö
```python
from github import Github
g = Github('my_client_id', 'my_client_secret')

# It works
``` 
Not like this !!!
```python 
g = Github(client_id='my_client_id', client_secret='my_client_secret')

# This code doesn't work
```
Method 2Ôºö
You can generate a token by emulating the client
1. Access the url https://github.com/login/oauth/authorize?client_id=your_client_id in your browser
2. The may ask you to login to githubÔºå and then the browser will go to another domain that you have specified, like this: 
`http://jiebaby.com/?code=a2f205a1f9643f2fe5c8`
This code `a2f205a1f9643f2fe5c8`  is what you need for the next step
3. Use a tool like 'postman' request url with POST method.
```shell
url: https://github.com/login/oauth/access_token
method: POST
args: client_id  client_secret  code
```
The can return access_token
![post_github](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/21216466/102756905-7ec15480-43ab-11eb-8e73-243ed44d2b8c.jpg)

4. Now, you can use this access_token like this
```python
g = Github(access_token,  retry=9)
```
Here is the  oauth docsÔºöhttps://docs.github.com/en/free-pro-team@latest/developers/apps/authorizing-oauth-apps

How can we gather this information?

comments.body:
The query can include "draft:true" or "draft:false" according to https://docs.github.com/en/free-pro-team@latest/github/searching-for-information-on-github/searching-issues-and-pull-requests . Further more, the returned PullRequest object should have a draft attribute, for example:

```
>>> repo = g.get_repo("PyGithub/PyGithub")
>>> pr = repo.get_pull(1727)
>>> pr.draft
False
```

GitHub API v3 considers every pull request an issue but not every issue is a pull request. 

This means that whenever you search using the `/search/issues` endpoint what you get is the Issue object. If you searched for PR using `is:pr` or `type:pr` you will still get the issue object but there will be a `pull_request` attribute which will contain only the URL information which you can use to get the pull request object and then check for draft status.

```
...
      "closed_at": null,
      "pull_request": {
        "url": "https://api/github.com/repos/octocat/Hello-World/pull/1347",
        "html_url": "https://github.com/octocat/Hello-World/pull/1347",
        "diff_url": "https://github.com/octocat/Hello-World/pull/1347.diff",
        "patch_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/octocat/Hello-World/pulls/1347"
      },
      "body": "...",
      "score": 1,
...
```

So, this is not an issue, it is just how GitHub API v3 works.

@s-t-e-v-e-n-k I think you can close this one.

For reference, the code returns an Issue obejct: https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/master/github/MainClass.py#L550
@dhruvmanila Thank you for your brilliant explanation, doing so.

Yeah, that is what I was doing for a good number of months but is damn slow as for each returned result I need to make another query in order to figure it out if is draft or not. I guess there is no way to bulk get this information yet, which is bit weird because in the web interface they display the draft status and I doubt they make an extra request for each listed PR.

title: search_issues does not expose draft status

body:
Module information:
```
Deprecated==1.2.10
PyGithub==1.53
PyJWT==1.7.1
```

Using an access token with full rights:
```
from github import Github
g = Github('my-token-here')
org = g.get_organization('my-org')
org.login
```

> 'my-org'

Attempting to create a new repository in the organization fails with a 403.
```
r = org.create_repo('test-repo', private=True)
```

> Traceback (most recent call last):
>   File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
>   File ".../lib/python3.7/site-packages/github/Organization.py", line 581, in create_repo
>     "POST", self.url + "/repos", input=post_parameters
>   File ".../lib/python3.7/site-packages/github/Requester.py", line 319, in requestJsonAndCheck
>     verb, url, parameters, headers, input, self.__customConnection(url)
>   File ".../lib/python3.7/site-packages/github/Requester.py", line 342, in __check
>     raise self.__createException(status, responseHeaders, output)
> github.GithubException.GithubException: 403 {"message": "You'll need a different OAuth scope to create a private repository. Please see the documentation for full details.", "documentation_url": "https://docs.github.com/rest/reference/repos#create-a-repository-for-the-authenticated-user"}

If I remove `private=True` I get a 403 with a different message:
```
r = org.create_repo('test-repo')
```

> Traceback (most recent call last):
>   File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
>   File ".../lib/python3.7/site-packages/github/Organization.py", line 581, in create_repo
>     "POST", self.url + "/repos", input=post_parameters
>   File ".../lib/python3.7/site-packages/github/Requester.py", line 319, in requestJsonAndCheck
>     verb, url, parameters, headers, input, self.__customConnection(url)
>   File ".../lib/python3.7/site-packages/github/Requester.py", line 342, in __check
>     raise self.__createException(status, responseHeaders, output)
> github.GithubException.GithubException: 403 {"message": "You need admin access to the organization before adding a repository to it.", "documentation_url": "https://docs.github.com/rest/reference/repos#create-an-organization-repository"}

I'm able to create the repository from the web UI (same user account) and retrieve that repo configuration via PyGithub.

comments.body:
A colleague of mine did some further research and this issue seems to be a combination of limitations in the current stable GH API and our organization setup.

Our organization has both "public" and "private" repositories disabled (we use "internal" repos).  In the v3 API if you don't say `private=True` it tries to create a "public" repository (vs just using the organization default).  The v3 API also does not support "internal" repos.

In order to create "internal" repositories you have to change your `Accept` header to `application/vnd.github.nebula-preview+json` and include `visibility=internal` in the body.

So it would seem that the answer here is to update the `Accept` header and data and that this is really an RFE to support Nebula and the "visibility" parameter in `create_repo()`.
Thanks for the investigation! This is a duplicate of #1446

title: Organization Repository Creation Attempt Yields 403

body:
Using the following code example,`get_organization_membership` used to work in August 2020. Looks like between Aug and Sept there was either a change to the API or the code itself so that this method no longer works


Code Example for fetching members from an org and their membership

```py
import os
from github import Github

def fetch_org(access_token, org_name):
    """ create an instance of the github api """
    gh_instance = Github(login_or_token=access_token, verify=False)
    org_instance = gh_instance.get_organization(login=org_name)

    return org_instance

def fetch_members(org_instance):
    """ Fetches all members for a given org """

    return [member for member in org_instance.get_members()]

access_token = os.getenv("ACCESS_TOKEN")
org_instance = fetch_org(access_token=access_token, org_name="org-name")

members = fetch_members(org_instance)

for member in members:
    # Now throws an exception
    member.get_organization_membership('org-name')
```


Throws the following exception

```sh
github.GithubException.UnknownObjectException: 404 {"message": "Not Found", "documentation_url": "https://docs.github.com/rest/reference/orgs#get-organization-membership-for-a-user"}
```

comments.body:
Update: turns out it's a bug in the GitHub API. I have filed a bug report with GitHub and they are now aware of the issue.

The bug is that the "member" role can now only read organization membership of themselves. You need to be an owner to read membership information of other organization users
@AJHenry I'm closing this issue, since it is a bug in the GitHub API. Please give me a shout if you think something needs to be changed for this in PyGithub.

body:
The following fails on my machine:

```python
import json
from github import Github

with open("./token.json", "r") as f:
    auth_token = json.load(f)["token"]

g = Github(auth_token)

repo = next(iter(g.get_user().get_repos()))
# this fails with a 403
print(repo.get_views_traffic())
```

```
{'message': 'Must have push access to repository', 'documentation_url': 'https://docs.github.com/rest/reference/repos#get-repository-clones'}
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "./requests_fails.py", line 13, in <module>
    r.raise_for_status()
  File "/home/sean/.local/share/virtualenvs/pygithub_requests_error-nXm25YLC-/home/sean/.local/share/pyenv/shims/python/lib/python3.8/site-packages/requests/models.py", line 941, in raise_for_status
    raise HTTPError(http_error_msg, response=self)
requests.exceptions.HTTPError: 403 Client Error: Forbidden for url: https://api.github.com/repos/seanbreckenridge/albums/traffic/clones
```

The token has the `repo` scope, and if I request the same using `curl`, it works fine.

![](https://camo.githubusercontent.com/7eff8b96b08c3576dd21f49fbb215c57f719f80b/68747470733a2f2f692e696d6775722e636f6d2f4f4d46724e6e4b2e706e67)

This was working fine at one point, and then just stopped. I originally found this while using <https://github.com/karlicoss/ghexport/issues/4>, you can see the process of debugging it in that issue.

I've debugged this quite a bit in the above issue, created <https://github.com/seanbreckenridge/pygithub_requests_error> which has code that runs in a virtualenv which causes the error *on my machine*. Strangely, @karlicoss, who I debugged this with doesn't have the same error.

See the [log file with errrors](https://github.com/seanbreckenridge/pygithub_requests_error/blob/master/log.txt), for [this script](https://github.com/seanbreckenridge/pygithub_requests_error/blob/master/run), which runs:

- a basic `curl` with the token, which succeeds ([link](https://github.com/seanbreckenridge/pygithub_requests_error/blob/master/curl_test.sh))
-  `PyGithub` which fails ([link](https://github.com/seanbreckenridge/pygithub_requests_error/blob/master/pygithub_requests_fails.py))
- `requests` which fails ([link](https://github.com/seanbreckenridge/pygithub_requests_error/blob/master/requests_fails.py))
- subclassed `PyGithub` with `httpx` [which succeeds](https://github.com/seanbreckenridge/pygithub_requests_error/blob/a9df0bcbf91b321e068ca591e5e6b91b804fca16/log.txt#L283-L296). ([link](https://github.com/seanbreckenridge/pygithub_requests_error/blob/master/httpx_subclass_succeeds.py))

This seems to be a `requests` error, since even just requesting something basic to github with the python `requests` module (without `PyGithub` at all) fails (see [`./requests_fails.py`](https://github.com/seanbreckenridge/pygithub_requests_error/blob/master/requests_fails.py)), when the analogous `curl` command works fine.

So I'm not sure if this should be classified as a `PyGithub` error, or a `requests` error.

See <https://github.com/karlicoss/ghexport/issues/4#issuecomment-693694338>; in which I use `pdb` to step into right before the request is made (in `PyGithub.Requester`). If I make the request with the `requests` module, it fails. If I make it with `httpx`, it succeeds.

Similarly, I can subclass the `PyGithub.Requester` `HTTPSRequestsConnectionClass` to use [`httpx`](https://github.com/encode/httpx), and then `PyGithub` works fine. (See [`httpx_subclass_succeeds.py`](https://github.com/seanbreckenridge/pygithub_requests_error/blob/master/httpx_subclass_succeeds.py) and the output [here](https://github.com/seanbreckenridge/pygithub_requests_error/blob/a9df0bcbf91b321e068ca591e5e6b91b804fca16/log.txt#L283-L296)).

I suspect this is an issue with `requests`, though I'm not sure how no one else has had this issue. Apologies if this should have been posted to the `requests` module instead, but I'm not sure how to debug this any further.

comments.body: I would also file an issue with requests, since we are dependant on them.
Will do so
Sorry for the delay, submitted a minimal example to [psf/requests](https://github.com/psf/requests/issues/5801)

This has been resolved; the cause was a `.netrc` file interfering with the login/[`trust_env`](https://docs.python-requests.org/en/latest/api/#requests.Session.trust_env) - see [here](https://github.com/psf/requests/issues/5801#issuecomment-901610012)

Something like this should do the job:


```python
        status = -1
        responseHeaders = None
        output = None

        try:
            response = cnx.getresponse()

            status = response.status
            responseHeaders = dict((k.lower(), v) for k, v in response.getheaders())
            output = response.read()

            cnx.close()
            if input:

                    input.close()

```

body:
### Description

Setting `all` and `participating` filters don't filters doesn't do anything.

`all=True` and `participating=True` should filter notifications, but instead `get_notifications` always returns the full list of notifications.

### Steps to reproduce

```
from github import Github
g = Github("secret")
user = g.get_user()

# all=False is broken
notifications = user.get_notifications(all=False)

# returns 371
print(notifications.totalCount)

notifications = user.get_notifications(all=True)

# returns 371
print(notifications.totalCount)
```

comments.body: Based on the GitHub API docs and the code, we're sending the correct parameters, so we're entirely at the mercy of whatever GitHub sends back.

I am running into this problem with `participating` and with `all`. I believe @newswangerd is correct in that the api does not assume `False == false` in the url params.

Am willing to put together a PR if you're interested in having this fixed.
Sounds like we need to say `"true" if all else "false"`. I would welcome a PR! Make sure to include "Fixes #1671" in the commit message.

title: Incorrect typing of get_user() method.

body:
I happened to use `https://git.mycompany.com/` to init github.Github other than `https://git.mycompany.com/api/v3/`.
However, seems not validation is invoked and an object is well returned `<github.MainClass.Github object at 0x7fd61c9c0d68>`
Then its method will perform strangely. for example any `get_repo('whateverrepo')` will return `Repository(full_name=None)` other than an exception `github.GithubException.UnknownObjectException: 404 {"message": "Not Found", "documentation_url": "https://developer.github.com/enterprise/2.21/v3/repos/#get"}`

comments.body: Yes, we don't attempt any URL validation when creating the Github() instance, but only on the first fetch, such as your get_repo() call. Are you able to try again with debugging on? I'm curious what response get_repo() is getting.

> Yes, we don't attempt any URL validation when creating the Github() instance, but only on the first fetch, such as your get_repo() call. Are you able to try again with debugging on? I'm curious what response get_repo() is getting.

Ok below is the debugging script:
```python
class Issue1644(unittest.TestCase):

    def testInvalidateInitURLThenGetRepo(self):
        g = Github(base_url="https://git.mygheurlwithoutapiv3suffix.com/", login_or_token="whateverrightorwrong")
        repo = g.get_repo("myorg/myrepo")  # Debug goes into steps here
        print(repo.full_name)
        assert repo.full_name == 'myorg/myrepo'
```
Then the raw request finally goes to [`Requester.py Line 513` ](https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/master/github/Requester.py#L513) while the response is as below:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2903719/89769814-68b7a380-db30-11ea-9f7d-8b36618181d7.png)
So obviously the url is not correct but no so wrong which leads to `302`
Next into the return phase: The data of 302 content response is passing to `Repository` initialzation.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2903719/89770457-61dd6080-db31-11ea-9e99-19047048a285.png)
Then the Repository with all `None` is generated
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2903719/89770308-2a6eb400-db31-11ea-8783-d3c49aea853e.png)

So after some other test, if your `base_url` is responing something you will get an all `None` repo after your then invoke `get_repo('xxxx')`.
if your `base_url` is totally wrong and not reachable, you will get connection exception.

Thank you for the debugging -- so I think there's something else running at the root of that website, since it redirects with a 302 to a login page. Due to some other fun and games with GitHub's responses, we can't assume everything is JSON, so we try our best to deal with odd responses, and that is what is causing this odd behaviour. If it gave a 404 or something other 4xx error code, then you would get an exception, but only first method call, not initialisation, since we don't make any requests at that point.

> Thank you for the debugging -- so I think there's something else running at the root of that website, since it redirects with a 302 to a login page. Due to some other fun and games with GitHub's responses, we can't assume everything is JSON, so we try our best to deal with odd responses, and that is what is causing this odd behaviour. If it gave a 404 or something other 4xx error code, then you would get an exception, but only first method call, not initialisation, since we don't make any requests at that point.

That is very resaonable. Just quick mind if add a parameter in the initilaztion to flag whether do validation, e.g. `Github(base_url='xxx', login_or_token='ttt', validate=True)` and maybe default to False. And to validate, just check if a `g.get_user()` returning non None object.

title: Repository.create_pull typing regression

body:
7b20b13d0b853e813b201edf1daf159ca8bc983f set the type of all kwargs to `Dict[str, Any]`. This is incorrect, as `repo` is `str`.

My assumption is that the author of #1517 didn't understand the the way typed **kwargs work, and meant to simply assign it to `Any`.

Mypy error message: `error: Argument "repo" to "search_issues" of "Github" has incompatible type "str"; expected "Dict[str, Any]"  [arg-type]`

comments.body: That was me, and I thought it was how kwargs typing worked. :-( I was expecting typing to parse the remaining args as a dictionary -- shall I set it to Any, or something else?

Yeah, **kwargs are always `Dict[str, T]`, so you only give it the `T`.

Probably Any, as qualifiers vary in what they accept.
