body:
I am having a hard time to get a good solution for type-checking when I have GithubException given this interface:

https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/6eba4506d4d44892c5e224054b809003fc3326f6/github/GithubException.pyi

Let me use give a practical use example to reproduce:

```
import github # PyGithub
g = github.Github("access_token")
github_repo = "staticdev/git-portfolio"
repo = g.get_repo(github_repo)
try:
    created_pr = repo.create_pull(
        title="title", body="body", head="head", base="base", draft=False,
    )
except github.GithubException as github_exception:
    extra = ""
    for error in github_exception.data["errors"]:
        if "message" in error:
            extra += f"{error['message']} "
        else:
            extra += f"Invalid field {error['field']}. "
```

When I check this code with mypy for example I get the errors:

```
src/git_portfolio/mypy.py:13:31: error: Invalid index type "str" for "Union[str, Dict[str, str]]"; expected type "Union[int, slice]"  [index]
                extra += f"{error['message']} "
                                  ^
src/git_portfolio/mypy.py:15:45: error: Invalid index type "str" for "Union[str, Dict[str, str]]"; expected type "Union[int, slice]"  [index]
                extra += f"Invalid field {error['field']}. "
```

Proposed solution: after opening an [issue on Mypy](https://github.com/python/mypy/issues/9221), @Akuli suggested using [TypedDict](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0589/) which I found great.

comments.body: This seems to include ``error`` is still a list inside the loop based on my reading? Are you able to perform a little more debugging on what variables are what types?

@s-t-e-v-e-n-k the problem is that `github.GithubException.data` is defined as a `Dict` of `Union[str, List[str]]` but the `errors` field in `data` is always going to be a List never a string. That is why you can use `TypedDict` to define data and say that specifically `errors` is a `List`. Since you support Python 3.5 and 3.6 you need the [backport](https://pypi.org/project/typing-extensions/) to make use of TypedDict. Then you can declare on `GithubException.pyi` a class `Data` for solve this.

 What else do you need me to debug?

From my reading of the code, ``data`` is defined as ``Dict[str, Union[str, List[str], List[Dict[str, str]]]]`` which to my reading is a dictionary with str keys, and the value being either a str, a list of str or a list of dictionaries of str, str ... I'm going to dig into this more.
I think the type checking is correct -- errors is a list, and message is not contained underneath it. For example: https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/master/tests/Branch.py#L87

@s-t-e-v-e-n-k errors IS a list, the problem is that from your interface "errors" is not a list, but a Union[str, List[str]]. It can't assume it is a list because type-checking will give errors when considering it may also be a string.

@staticdev That was exactly my point. It is a list, but your code is treating it like a dictionary, so of course type validation fails.errors is either a string, or a list of strings, it doesn't contain members like your code has.
``extra += f"{error['message']} "`` which is in fact the line that type checking is erroring on.

Here is a full example abstracted from my real usage:
I get a lot hints from this https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/issues/863#issuecomment-517927446

To commit to master branch
```python
import github
g = github.Github(base_url="https://git.mycompany.com/api/v3",login_or_token="mytoken")
repo = g.get_repo('myorg/myrepo')
# you can read file content into blob, here just use str for example
blob1 = repo.create_git_blob("file-content", "utf-8")
element1 = github.InputGitTreeElement(path="path-in-repo.ext", mode='100644', type='blob', sha=blob1.sha)
blob2 = repo.create_git_blob("file-content2", "utf-8")
element2 = github.InputGitTreeElement(path="folder/path-in-repo.ext", mode='100644', type='blob', sha=blob2.sha)
head_sha = repo.get_branch('master').commit.sha
base_tree = repo.get_git_tree(sha=head_sha)
tree = repo.create_git_tree([element1, element2], base_tree)
parent = repo.get_git_commit(sha=head_sha)
commit = repo.create_git_commit("commit_message", tree, [parent])
master_refs = self.github_repo.get_git_ref('heads/master')
master_ref.edit(sha=commit.sha)
```

I wanted to do something similar (i.e. commit multiple files at once), but this time in a branch. Below is working code (let me know if it can be optimised though)

```
import github
g = github.Github("mytoken")
repo = g.get_repo('myorg/myrepo')

blob1 = repo.create_git_blob("file-content", "utf-8")
element1 = github.InputGitTreeElement(path="path-in-repo.ext", mode='100644', type='blob', sha=blob1.sha)
blob2 = repo.create_git_blob("file-content2", "utf-8")
element2 = github.InputGitTreeElement(path="folder/path-in-repo.ext", mode='100644', type='blob', sha=blob2.sha)

head_sha = repo.get_branch('master').commit.sha

# everything above is identical to @xpdable 
# but here I create the branch
branch = repo.create_git_ref(ref=f"refs/heads/branch-name", sha=head_sha)
branch_sha = repo.get_branch("branch-name").commit.sha

# similar to @xpdable but replacing head_sha with branch_sha
base_tree = repo.get_git_tree(sha=branch_sha)
tree = repo.create_git_tree([element1, element2], base_tree)
parent = repo.get_git_commit(sha=branch_sha)
commit = repo.create_git_commit("commit_message", tree, [parent])
branch_refs = repo.get_git_ref("heads/branch-name")
branch_refs.edit(sha=commit.sha)

# optional : open a PR with the new branch
repo.create_pull(title="PR title", body="PR body", base="master", head="branch-name")
```

Any advice on how to delete files as part of such multiple file commits? 

Some posts talk about creating new trees with references to paths with null sha's, or modifying existing trees incl. ideas about looping and finding all references to the deleted blobs?

I think the line:
```
tree = repo.create_git_tree([configuration_element, stats_element], base_tree)
```
should be replaced by:
```
tree = repo.create_git_tree([element1, element2], base_tree)
```

I have created a full example here: https://github.com/josecelano/pygithub/blob/main/src/04_sign_commit_with_multiple_files_using_github_api.py
Thanks for the heads up @josecelano , i fixed my example :ok_hand:
Hi, do sombody know how it works with git-lfs?

Hi! I had the same question as @abulka (how to delete a file in a commit with multiple changes), and I found the solution. To delete a file you have to create an `InputGitTreeElement` with `sha` param with value `None`.

Here is an example of deleting a file:
```python
from github import Github, InputGitTreeElement

github_repository_name='org/repo-name'
branch_name='branch-name'
commit_message='delete file'

g = Github('GITHUB_ACCESS_TOKEN')

repo_obj = g.get_repo(github_repository_name)

head_sha = repo_obj.get_branch(branch_name).commit.sha
base_tree = repo_obj.get_git_tree(sha=head_sha)
changes = []

element = InputGitTreeElement(path='path/to/file/in/repo', mode='100644', type='blob', sha=None) # here is the magic
changes.append(element)

new_tree = repo_obj.create_git_tree(changes, base_tree)
parent = repo_obj.get_git_commit(sha=head_sha)

commit = repo_obj.create_git_commit(commit_message, new_tree, [parent])
branch_refs = repo_obj.get_git_ref('heads/{0}'.format(branch_name))
branch_refs.edit(sha=commit.sha)
```

I hope this can be useful!

>>> for a in cs:
...      print(a)
...
CheckSuite(url="https://api.github.com/repos/apache/incubator-mxnet/check-suites/1063117829", id=1063117829)
CheckSuite(url="https://api.github.com/repos/apache/incubator-mxnet/check-suites/1064967098", id=1064967098)
```

body:
I'm writing a script that interfaces with both ZenHub and GitHub (using PyGithub). ZenHub only identifies users by their user id (databaseId), so if I want to find the name of the user associated with an id, I have to query GitHub's API. There's an 
[undocumented endpoint](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/11976393/get-github-username-by-id) for this (`/user/:id`). 

A quick example. (My user id is 23219746.) I'm on `PyGithub==1.43.5` but I can see this is still the case on v1.51.

```pycon
>>> import github
>>> g = github.Github("...")
>>> g.get_user(g.get_user().id)
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/Users/natan/DataBiosphere/azul/.venv/lib/python3.8/site-packages/github/MainClass.py", line 226, in get_user
    assert login is github.GithubObject.NotSet or isinstance(login, str), login
AssertionError: 23219746
```

Does PyGithub support undocumented endpoints? If so, it seems trivial to add support for this:

```diff
diff --git a/github/MainClass.py b/github/MainClass.py
index cadd1ff5..b450492a 100644
--- a/github/MainClass.py
+++ b/github/MainClass.py
@@ -261,18 +261,25 @@ class Github(object):
         :param login: string
         :rtype: :class:`github.NamedUser.NamedUser` or :class:`github.AuthenticatedUser.AuthenticatedUser`
         """
-        assert login is github.GithubObject.NotSet or isinstance(login, str), login
+        assert login is github.GithubObject.NotSet or isinstance(login, str) or isinstance(login, int), login
         if login is github.GithubObject.NotSet:
             return AuthenticatedUser.AuthenticatedUser(
                 self.__requester, {}, {"url": "/user"}, completed=False
             )
-        else:
+        elif isinstance(login, str):
             headers, data = self.__requester.requestJsonAndCheck(
                 "GET", "/users/" + login
             )
             return github.NamedUser.NamedUser(
                 self.__requester, headers, data, completed=True
             )
+        else:
+            headers, data = self.__requester.requestJsonAndCheck(
+                "GET", "/user/" + login
+            )
+            return github.NamedUser.NamedUser(
+                self.__requester, headers, data, completed=True
+            )
 
     def get_users(self, since=github.GithubObject.NotSet):
         """
```

comments.body: If we were to do this, it would be via another method, MainClass.get_user_by_id() or such -- are you certain the endpoint is undocumented?

> are you certain the endpoint is undocumented?

If there is documentation, I have not been able to find it. The closest is [`GET /users/{username}`](https://docs.github.com/en/rest/reference/users#get-a-user). There are endpoints of the form `GET /user/...` but none as described in this issue.

@natanlao Github now allows numerical usernames, so the `/user/:id` will return unpredictable results if there exists a username that is the same as the `:id` you are querying for. For e.g I just went ahead and created a github account with username `23219746`. 
`curl https://api.github.com/users/23219746`

@wrecker The endpoint seems to work as expected. The `GET /users/{username}` endpoint queries by username and the `GET /user/{userid}` endpoint (note the dropped `s`) queries by user id.

```console
$ http get https://api.github.com/user/23219746 | jq .login
"natanlao"
$ http get https://api.github.com/users/23219746 | jq .login
"23219746"
```
@natanlao Good point. I completely missed the 's' in the API endpoints!

I'm using PyGithub to write some automation around org-level Github projects.

However, I'm running into a problem when I try and fetch a project associated with an organization. See below as an example:

```python
github = Github(token)
repo = github.get_repo(repo_name)

body: Use  Formatted String Literals when parsing the username

comments.body: Can you paste a traceback?

```python
‚ú¶ ‚ùØ python                         
Python 3.7.6 (default, Dec 30 2019, 19:38:28) 
[Clang 11.0.0 (clang-1100.0.33.16)] on darwin
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import github
>>> gh = github.Github()

>>> maintainer = '0x00b1'
>>> gh.get_user(maintainer)
NamedUser(login="0x00b1")

>>> maintainer = 0x00b1
>>> gh.get_user(maintainer)
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/Users/henrykironde/Documents/GitHub/Environments/py37/lib/python3.7/site-packages/github/MainClass.py", line 256, in get_user
    assert login is github.GithubObject.NotSet or isinstance(login, str), login
AssertionError: 177
```
So this isn't a bug, this is how we do type checking -- that assertion is saying if login is passed in, it must be a string, and 0x00b1 isn't.

And that is true @s-t-e-v-e-n-k. but there are some projects using this tool and the data is in form of json or yaml, like Travis files.  where you could find something like 
```j
users:
    - henrykironde
    - 0x00000
```
These are both allowed user names on Github. 
But it will work only if we quote the usernames.
0x00000 can be a string and a hex rep. We could change the way the send requests to the api but also if you could handle it at a lower lever, that could be great so that we don't have to tell these edge case users to quote their names.

```md
users:
    - henrykironde
    - '0x00000'
```
If we open our application, the user name will not point to the GitHub user by default.

```
if not isintance(user, str):
    user = str(user)
```

in your application? I don't feel its our job to avoid an assertion error we added to make sure the type of the data is correct.

body:
When I constructed an `Issue` object, I was expecting time-related fields (eg: `created_at` and `closed_at`) would return the same data type: `datetime.datetime`. However, `last_modified` did not. It returned in a string format representing date and time, like the following:
```
ipdb> issue.last_modified
'Sat, 20 Jun 2020 00:43:01 GMT'
```

It is not a blocker as there are workarounds. But it would be a better experience if the data type is consistent for those fields.

comments.body: Duplicate of #512
Actually, no it isn't, my bad.

The reasons are from an implementation detail -- ``created_at`` and ``closed_at`` are attributes on Issue, ``last_modified`` comes from the superclass, and is passed as-is to further requests if it's set. We should probably move it to a _ attribute. Since it's useful, we can then a real last_modified that is datetime.datetime.

body:
I wonder if it was possible to reduce boilerplate... something like this:

```
class Artifact(
    github.GithubObject.CompletableGithubObject,
    metaclass=github.GithubObject.CompletableGithubObjectMeta
):
    """
    This class represents Artifacts.
    The reference can be found here https://developer.github.com/v3/actions/artifacts/
    """
    _ATTRIBUTES = {
        "id": "Int",
        "node_id": "String",
        "name": "String",
        "size_in_bytes": "Int",
        "url": "String",
        "archive_download_url": "String",
        "expired": "Bool",
        "created_at": "Datetime",
        "expires_at": "Datetime"
    }
```
Then
```
class CompletableGithubObjectMeta(type):
    def __new__(cls, name, bases, dct):
        instance = super().__new__(cls, name, bases, dct)
        for attr in dct.get('_ATTRIBUTES') or []:
            def fget(self, attr_=attr):
                _attr = getattr(self, '_' + attr_)
                self._completeIfNotSet(_attr)
                return _attr.value
            setattr(instance, attr, property(fget))
        return instance
```
and
```
class GithubObject(object):
    def _initAttributes(self):
        for attribute in self._ATTRIBUTES:
            setattr(self, '_' + attribute, NotSet)

    def _useAttributes(self, attributes):
        for attribute, type_ in self._ATTRIBUTES.items():
            if attribute in attributes: # pragma no branch
                make_method = getattr(self, f'_make{type_}Attribute')
                setattr(self, '_' + attribute, make_method(attributes[attribute]))
```

And some form of .pyi autogeneration.

What do you think?

comments.body:
this is Artifacts implementation 

https://github.com/JacekPliszka/PyGithub/pull/1
The boilerplate reduction is an interesting idea, but I think it also loses us the docstrings mentioning type of the attributes, which is important.

docstring is not a problem as you can modify it in meta.

```
    _ATTRIBUTES = {
        "id": ("Int", "doctring for id"),
        "node_id": ("String","docstring for node_id"),
        "name": ("String", "docstring for name"),
...
    }
```
The only difference is that you need to import the class for it to work (sphinx does import).
But there is pyi which can be generated.

So the question is if there is any use of the .py file that is not importing it?

docstring is not a problem as you can modify it in meta.

```
    _ATTRIBUTES = {
        "id": ("Int", "doctring for id"),
        "node_id": ("String","docstring for node_id"),
        "name": ("String", "docstring for name"),
...
    }
```

And then
```
func_wrapper.__doc__ = f'some text ``{name}`` \n{docstring}'
```

The only difference is that you need to import the class for it to work (sphinx does import).
But there is pyi which can be generated.

So the question is if there is any use of the .py file that is not importing it?

body:
I've been using this library to help us automate some processes flawlessly. But lately, I faced the issue described in #1461 which seems to require the v4 API.

So, what is your view on migrating to the v4 API? Do you think...
1. It should be somewhere else? Because you think this library should be limited to REST?
1. It should be a new major version and new branch rewriting everything in GraphQL 
1. It should be done progressively by starting to implement the features that are only in the v4 API (like #1461) and progressively switch everything else to v4 (or not)?

I prefer this third approach but I'm opened to anything and will be happy to contribute to it.

comments.body: Sadly, It should be somewhere else, this library is 100% limited to REST. (So the first option)
Yup, PyGithub will remain as a V3 REST library, if you need V4 I am pretty sure there are great libraries for GraphQL.

It seems somebody changed their mind about that with [v2.2.0](https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/releases/v2.2.0) and switched towards the third option. 

And that's great !

body:
So we are using topics for our GH Enterprise repositories and would like to access from this api.
When retrieving a repository: expecting the topics property, but it is returned as None.

Topics is a 3+ year old "preview" v3 feature, well documented that when getting a repository, need to add this to request header:
   Accept: **application/vnd.github.mercy-preview+json**

**DIRECT REST CALL WORKS**
When I retrieve via direct REST request via IntelliJ REST testing, it works:

**Request:**
```shell
    GET https://github.gaig.com/api/v3/repos/some_org/some_repo
    Authorization: token ***************************************
    User-Agent: PyGithub/Python
    Accept: **application/vnd.github.mercy-preview+json**
```

**Response:**
```json
   ...
  "license": null,
  **"topics": [
    "documentation"
  ],**
  "forks": 27,
 ...
```

**Python github call does not work**
But when I get a repository using the **github/MainClass.py**, topics is returned as **None**:

```python
def get_repo(self, full_name_or_id, lazy=False):
```

After going deeper and forcing the header to contain the Accept, __requestRaw does not return topics at all in the output.  I'm puzzled as to why even with the forced add it isn't working.  See:

```python
   def __requestEncode(
        self, cnx, verb, url, parameters, requestHeaders, input, encode
    ):
        assert verb in ["HEAD", "GET", "POST", "PATCH", "PUT", "DELETE"]
        if parameters is None:
            parameters = dict()
        if requestHeaders is None:
            requestHeaders = dict()

        self.__authenticate(url, requestHeaders, parameters)
        requestHeaders["User-Agent"] = self.__userAgent
        requestHeaders["Accept"] = 'application/vnd.github.mercy-preview+json'

        url = self.__makeAbsoluteUrl(url)
        url = self.__addParametersToUrl(url, parameters)

        encoded_input = None
        if input is not None:
            requestHeaders["Content-Type"], encoded_input = encode(input)

        self.NEW_DEBUG_FRAME(requestHeaders)

        status, responseHeaders, output = self.__requestRaw(
            cnx, verb, url, requestHeaders, encoded_input
        )
```

**Musings**
Is this functionality supported in the api?  Is there some configuration step I missed?

I noticed that the get_topics call adds the preview to the header, seems like the intent was there to support this at least partially.  I starting thinking that maybe our GitHub eprise version is lagging, but this preview is 3 years old AND I already demonstrated that a simple REST call to retrieve repo works.  Also wonder if any of the characters in the header I added needed to be encoded, but tried that, no difference.

Willing to help modify/test getting Topics working what am I missing?

body:
Hello,

The current API for PR comments contains a lot of fields that can be checked. But sometimes I need to check whether the comment is outdated or not. How can it be done using `PyGithub`?

If there is any way to do that, then this is a question. If not, this is a feature request :smile:

Thanks in advance!

comments.body: I'm sorry for missing this issue being filed. Can you define what makes a comment outdated? If it's been edited?

> I'm sorry for missing this issue being filed. Can you define what makes a comment outdated? If it's been edited?

Thanks for response!

I meant the "Outdated" mark that appears when the code being commented was edited and the comment is not applicable to it anymore:
![outdated-and-resolved-comments](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8101418/82791265-65edd080-9ea8-11ea-8fb6-20bda4734c8e.png)
The "Resolved" mark (which is made by developers manually) is also interesting.

This feature could help to distinguish comments that were addressed and that were not.

I'm not certain about the resolved mark, I think that is a UI behaviour only, however, from some quick testing, I think you can check for the outdatedness of a comment by comparing the ``original_position`` to the ``position`` property, like so:

```
>>> g = Github(TOKEN)
>>> repo = g.get_repo("PyGithub/PyGithub")
>>> pr = repo.get_pull(1395)
>>> for c in pr.get_comments():
...     line = str(c.id)
...     if c.original_position != c.position:
...         line += " is outdated"
...     else:
...         line += " is not outdated"
...     print(line)
... 
378599711 is outdated
378600370 is outdated
378600453 is outdated
378600571 is outdated
378600862 is not outdated
378601708 is outdated
378601899 is not outdated
378603197 is outdated
378824865 is not outdated
```

> I'm not certain about the resolved mark, I think that is a UI behaviour only, however, from some quick testing, I think you can check for the outdatedness of a comment by comparing the `original_position` to the `position` property, like so:
> 
> ```
> >>> g = Github(TOKEN)
> >>> repo = g.get_repo("PyGithub/PyGithub")
> >>> pr = repo.get_pull(1395)
> >>> for c in pr.get_comments():
> ...     line = str(c.id)
> ...     if c.original_position != c.position:
> ...         line += " is outdated"
> ...     else:
> ...         line += " is not outdated"
> ...     print(line)
> ... 
> 378599711 is outdated
> 378600370 is outdated
> 378600453 is outdated
> 378600571 is outdated
> 378600862 is not outdated
> 378601708 is outdated
> 378601899 is not outdated
> 378603197 is outdated
> 378824865 is not outdated
> ```

Thanks! It looks working like intended. However, sometimes `position` is `None`. How should I interpret such case?

Moreover, this method is not very evident (without your comment I would not even get this). To make it more useful, it would be great to add some comments about what `position` and `original_position` are. The current comments don't contain this information:
https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/69bfc3251148ef4ac119f0ab2a11a734ddf63ee0/github/PullRequestComment.py#L107-L113
and
https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/69bfc3251148ef4ac119f0ab2a11a734ddf63ee0/github/PullRequestComment.py#L115-L121

Maybe it would be good to provide the method for outdated comments:
```python
@property
def is_outdated(self):
    return self.position != self.original_position
```

position is the code position, so position as None is I think are comments on PR itself, not made on any part of the diff. WRT adding the property, we sadly don't export anything that GitHub does not.

Given the API docs we're working from on developer.github.com, the fields aren't documented at all, so all of this is just guesswork in the dark anyway. :-)
OK, thanks! Then I think it's enough and we can close this issue.

title: Check of outdated PR comments

comments.body: If you're actually using ``Github()`` then you're making the query anonymously, which is likely why you're getting back an exception. Generate a token and pass it in as the first argument.

@s-t-e-v-e-n-k 

The repository that I'm using is a public one apache/beam, even with the token (a personal one for this github account) I keep getting the same error.

Isn't supposed to return the same result as this call :
https://api.github.com/search/issues?q=repo:apache/beam+is:pr+is:merged+merged:2020-04-22..2020-05-06+sort:updated&sort=created&order=asc

Have a similar issue I think. Looks to me like `search_issues` escapes `+` to `%2B`, which triggers the error. If curl the exact URL that the verbose logging says it's trying, I get the same error. If I replace `%2B` with `+` it works fine.
Ahhh, that's a wonderful hint. I've been scratching my head over this, but that gives me a direction to dig when I get some time.

I think it's because it's basically double encoding the +. @marouni I think in your example, you might be able to get it to work by just removeing the + signs. Spaces get urlencoded to +, and then it should make it to the API endpoint in the correct form.
@paulgessinger Thanks for the hint, I'll give it a try !
@marouni Did the hint help? If so, I think we can solve this by replacing the +'s with spaces.

@s-t-e-v-e-n-k 
yup :

from github import Github

g = Github()

print(g.search_issues(query="repo:apache/beam is:pr is:merged merged:2020-04-22..2020-05-06 sort:updated").totalCount)
```
```

```

body:
The method [github.Team.Team.set_repo_permission](https://pygithub.readthedocs.io/en/stable/github_objects/Team.html#github.Team.Team.set_repo_permission) calls an old API-Endpoint:
https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/219bde53d31845ae147e14382ceeed07153dcbda/github/Team.py#L237

It calls
```python
headers, data = self._requester.requestJsonAndCheck(
   "PUT", self.url + "/repos/" + repo._identity, input=put_parameters
)
```

This endpoint is linked to [Teams: Add or update team repository (Legacy)](https://developer.github.com/v3/teams/#add-or-update-team-repository-legacy).
The new API endpoint for this is [Teams: Add or update team repository](https://developer.github.com/v3/teams/#add-or-update-team-repository): `PUT /orgs/:org/teams/:team_slug/repos/:owner/:repo`

comments.body:
Additional note:

body:
For a repository with topics, `Repository.topics` is returning `None` whereas `Repository.get_topics()` properly returns a list of string (my topics). The latter is correct.

This occurred for a private org repo.

```
Python Version: 3.7.4
      PyGithub: 1.51
```

comments.body: I suspect topics is no longer populated because it isn't being sent by GitHub. I'll push up a PR to remove it.

Just a heads up that this change looks like it was made in error.

`https://api.github.com/orgs/org-name/repos` is properly returning `topics` in the JSON response and is documented at https://docs.github.com/en/rest/reference/repos

Removing the topics from the Repository entry creates unnecessary load - previously topics could be processed in "bulk" without any additional API requests; now it's an O(n) operation that scales with the number of repositories.

Would it be better to restore the old behavior of loading the topics if they exist from the payload, but add some intelligence to `Repository.get_topics()` so that it falls back to making the request if the 'stored' topics is `None`?

On May 1st, 2020 at 16:31 (UTC) your personal access token using python-requests/2.22.0 was used as part of a query parameter to access an endpoint through the GitHub API:

[removed]

Please use the Authorization HTTP header instead, as using the `access_token` query parameter is deprecated. If this token is being used by an app you don't have control over, be aware that it may stop working as a result of this deprecation.

Depending on your API usage, we'll be sending you this email reminder on a monthly basis for each token and User-Agent used in API calls made on your behalf.

+1 here I just received the following email

Hi @crawfobw,

On May 3rd, 2020 at 13:34 (UTC) your application (DocumentGuardian) used its `client_id` and client_secret` (with the User-Agent PyGithub/Python) as part of a set of query parameters to access an endpoint through the GitHub API:

https://api.github.com/user/repos

Please use Basic Authentication instead as using OAuth credentials in query parameters has been deprecated.

Depending on your API usage, we'll be sending you this email reminder on a monthly basis.

Visit https://developer.github.com/changes/2020-02-10-deprecating-auth-through-query-param for more information about suggested workarounds and removal dates.

The GitHub Team

This was in response to attempting the following code 
```
from github import Github

g = Github(client_id="redacted", client_secret="redacted")

```

https://developer.github.com/changes/2020-02-10-deprecating-auth-through-query-param

The `assert` statements are duplicates, especially for types, since we have static type checking now. 

Removing them to gain some speed üòÑ

comments.body: @s-t-e-v-e-n-k this one too

Do we have static type checking? I'd argue we don't since the asserts are run time, and mypy checking happens at check in. I suspect we'd need to move the annotations into the .py files and lose the .pyi files -- however, in general I approve of the idea if we don't lose the safety that the asserts gives us at run time.

Yes we have, only not 100%. (I am working on this)

The `pyi` type stub is less intrusive and easier for community contribution. It works the same as inline type hint. 

Because we don't expect the type to change during runtime (if they do, it's a serious problem), all the asserts statements (for type) are basically the same as static type hints.

body: PaginatedList has a totalCount attribute that is useful, but it should support __len__() as a more Pythonic way. Currently this breaks the test suite in interesting ways.

comments.body: This issue has been automatically marked as stale because it has not had recent activity. It will be closed if no further activity occurs. Thank you for your contributions.
still valid

Regarding the test suite - would it be reasonable to create one (or more?) repositories under the PyGithub organization, for use in testing? It might not be possible to cover every usage but I imagine having dedicated repositories for testing would make it easier to update tests

@s-t-e-v-e-n-k I've taken a look at this with my initial fix being implemented len (as below), then fix the test fallout.
```python
class PaginatedList:
      def __len__(self) -> int:
        return self.totalCount
```

The immediate issue I've noticed whilst investigating the test fallout is that where anyone would do something like this
```python
issues = list(repo.get_issues())
```
With `__len__` implemented, this would result in an extra API call because of how list initialisation works.
For those that don't know, the gist is: check sequence length (len call), create list, extend list (len call).
Fortunately, totalCount caches the length which is good.
I was also looking into other ways to reduce the number of API requests.

The first was to see if the `PaginatedList` could grow, if not, return the length of the elements in `PaginatedListBase`. However this required changing the access modifiers for `PaginatedListBase` (not sure what the rational behind that logic is since `PaginatedListBase` seems to only be used/extended by `PaginatedList`).

The second was some awful hacking whereby fetching the totalCount would cache the last element so we wouldn't have to re-fetch it if/when we iterated through the items later. However, I've already decided that it isn't worth pursuing since it would end up with an overly complicated, unmaintainable mess.


TL;DR: implementing `__len__` would mean an extra API call in most cases.



Any suggestions/advice on how to tackle this issue?
Is it worth tackling?
This issue has been automatically marked as stale because it has not had recent activity. It will be closed if no further activity occurs. Thank you for your contributions.
Still having issue. Please reopen.
What kind of issues precisely?

title: PaginatedList should support __len__()

body:
When calling `get_teams()` on an object of type `github.Repository.Repository`, it returns only those teams that have access to the repo (correct), but the permissions shown for those teams do not reflect the permission granted to those teams for that particular repository (incorrect).

Steps to replicate:

1. Create a team with a default permission of "pull"
2. Add that team to a repository's access with a permission of "admin"
3. Call that repository object's `get_teams()` method and inspect the results.

The returned teams are regular `github.Team.Team` objects, and the `permission` attribute for that object indicates that team's default permission setting. However, when retrieving the teams that have access to a repository, the permission those teams have for that specific repository is implied to match the context (hence, why only teams with access are returned).

body:
Let's say you wanted to retrieve the reactions for this issue. You'd code something like this:

```python
github = Github()

for reaction in github.get_repo("PyGithub/PyGithub").get_issue(1474).get_reactions():
    print(reaction)
```

The problem is that this makes at least 3 requests:

* http://developer.github.com/v3/repos ‚Äî `GitHub.get_repo()`
* http://developer.github.com/v3/issues ‚Äî `Repository.get_issue()`
* https://developer.github.com/v3/reactions/#list-reactions-for-an-issue ‚Äî `Issue.get_reactions()`

Where only the last one will be sufficient to get the job done:

```
GET /repos/:owner/:repo/issues/:issue_number/reactions
```

It would be nice if one could do this instead:

```python
github = Github()

for reaction in github.get_reactions("PyGithub/PyGithub", 1474):
    print(reaction)
```

See Octokit example: https://octokit.github.io/octokit.rb/Octokit/Client/Reactions.html#issue_reactions-instance_method

comments.body: You want GraphQL :trollface:
We could make a new shortcut method `github.get_reactions`, but it is simply impossible to make it for all the APIs we have, due to how the API is designed.

>You want GraphQL

Thought about this too, but GraphQL is somewhat more burdensome to use, compared to this library.

>but it is simply impossible to make it for all the APIs we have, due to how the API is designed

Can you provide a more concrete example of a method for which making such a shortcut would be inconvenient?

> Can you provide a more concrete example of a method for which making such a shortcut would be inconvenient?

Our main class is already 854 lines. Adding a ``get_reactions`` endpoint is easily at least 15 lines, it just does not scale, both in terms of code size and in terms of testing.

>Our main class is already 854 lines. Adding a `get_reactions` endpoint is easily at least 15 lines, it just does not scale, both in terms of code size and in terms of testing.

What if the library would provide a way to instantiate `Issue` like this:

```python
issue = Issue("PyGithub/PyGithub", 1474)
```

...and then one could just call `issue.get_reactions()` to retrieve reactions.

Quickly looking [at the code](https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/a9f174bd1d6da6cf4053e09349e7e22b0d8fee09/github/Issue.py#L64) it seems that `self._completeIfNotSet(...)` guards should account for the missing internal state, but I haven't tested this yet.

>but I haven't tested this yet

This seems to work, however it's very hacky:

```
>>> requester = Github()._Github__requester
>>> Issue.Issue(requester, None, {"url": "https://api.github.com/repos/PyGithub/PyGithub/issues/1474"}, False).title
'Provide a less wasteful way to retrieve some resources'
```

To make it more clean, we can:

* move defaults pased to `Requester` from `Github.__init__()` to `Requester.__init__()` to facilitate easier re-use of this class
* implement `Issue.from_number()` class method that instantiates an issue object by calling `super.__init__()` (which is `CompletableGithubObject`) with the right parameters

So the example above could be reproduced by doing:

```
>>> Issue.from_number("PyGithub/PyGithub", 1474).title
'Provide a less wasteful way to retrieve some resources'
```

```python
def edit(
        self,

Bummer.

Maybe need some custom headers?
Nope, custom headers won't help, the docs don't list it at all for the PATCH call. :-(

body:
I'm working on some kind of a crawler that needs to fetch the file `a` or, if doesn't exist, the file `b` and so on. This is performed on large number of repos. My current code utilizes `repo.get_contents("a")` but the exceptions that occur when `a` doesn't exist are very costly.

I believe this a common problem, but I haven't found anything on it neither in this repo nor in the docs.

Any help is appreciated.

comments.body:
As a suggestion call ``get_contents()`` with the directory, not the full path. / (as in the root of the repository) can be specified as empty string. For example:

```
>>> repo = g.get_repo("PyGithub/PyGithub")
>>> files = repo.get_contents('')
>>> 'setup.py' in [f.name for f in files]
True
```
This solution works fine, at least in my use case. Thanks!

title: How to check whether a specific file exists avoiding any exceptions?

body:
Looks like you're checking the error message string for "Not Found", but the API is returning "Branch not found":

https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/393bd21bd168769d8ecf4b23f4b32e9a4de5f17a/github/Requester.py#L387

Are there other reasons that the API would return a 404? Seems like just using the status code would be sufficient here. If not, then perhaps something like `"not found" in output.get("message").lower()`. Happy to submit a PR.

comments.body: Yes, the API returns 404 for things like membership of organizations and one or two other things that escape me. I'm not against the change, but if you do put up a PR, then please include a test.

Hey, I'm trying to list all the private repos from another user. I'm kind of new to this, but would like some help. I have python installed along with sublime. I'm stuck with how to run the script and what the script should contain. Here's what I have so far in my sublime text. 

> 
> def get_repos(type=private, sort=full_name):

>         assert isinstance(login, str), login
>         headers, data = self.__requester.requestJsonAndCheck(

>         )
>         return data
> 

I'm lost after this. Do I need a header? How do I run it in SSH? Any help please? Sorry, fairly new to API and python >_>.

comments.body:
Generally, you want to save the script to a text file, and then run it with <path to python or python.exe> <script name>, in this case, you're conflating code you should write versus what you should call.

This module does require a modicum of understanding of Python (but not APIs, we handle all that for you). I'd suggest a resource like https://learnpythonthehardway.org/python3/ to help with your Python knowledge.

But to answer your original question, https://pygithub.readthedocs.io/en/latest/github_objects/NamedUser.html#github.NamedUser.NamedUser.get_repos is the method you should look at. Currently we don't support searching by visibility, but there is another issue open for that.

body:
Do we have any way to get into a branch and make changes using pygithub
I'm running this code I want to make changes in baseline branch of uditgaurav/litmuschaos repo suppose:
```
github_token = Github(token)
repo = github_token.get_repo("uditgaurav/litmuschaos").get_branch("baseline")
contents = repo.get_contents("README.md", ref="baseline")
file = repo.get_contents(contents.path)
file_path = contents.path
file_content=str(file.decoded_content)
content_list = file_content.split('\n')
```
But this is throwing an error:
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "result_update.py", line 38, in <module>
    contents = repo.get_contents("README.md", ref="baseline")
AttributeError: 'Branch' object has no attribute 'get_contents'
```
Can anyone help me in this?
How to get the content of a branch?

comments.body:
``get_ontents()`` is a method for a ``Repository`` object, you're calling it on a ``Branch`` object.

Drop the ``.get_branch("baseline")``, since you're passing the branch using the ref parameter of get_contents already.

Thanks @s-t-e-v-e-n-k 
This seems to work for me:
```
github_token = Github(token)
repo = github_token.get_repo("uditgaurav/litmuschaos")
b= repo.get_branch(branch="baseline")
print(repo)
contents = repo.get_contents("README.md", ref=b.commit.sha)
file = repo.get_contents(contents.path)
file_path = contents.path
file_content=str(file.decoded_content)
```
and
```
repo.update_file(file_path, commit_message, updated_file_content, file.sha, branch="baseline")
```
closing the issue with this Thanks!!!

Due to branch protection being enabled for master, this happens when a new release is attempted to be made:

[master afb1259<https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/commit/afb1259a4e52d7bbee8415a523d78c3a428968a8>] Publish version 1.47

! [remote rejected] master -> master (protected branch hook declined)
error: failed to push some refs to 'git@github.com<mailto:git@github.com>:PyGithub/PyGithub.git'

@sfdye<https://github.com/sfdye> What do you think we should do? 1.47 is up on PyPi, it looks like the tag is up on Github, we're just missing the commit with the release notes, but that means the tag will have to move as well.

‚Äî
You are receiving this because you were mentioned.
Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub<https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/issues/1436>, or unsubscribe<https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AAHYERREFNXBAFOJBA4HC4DRHQZ7HANCNFSM4LKGWVZQ>.

> remote: error: Required status check "continuous-integration/travis-ci" is expected. At least 1 approving review is required by reviewers with write access.

I've disabled required travis check. Can you create a patch version 1.47.1 and try to publish it again?

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1016390/76695538-c6e47580-66bb-11ea-9307-60f78bd4bd51.png)
manage.sh breaks when there are no changes between the old tag and the new tag. :-(

ü§¶‚Äç‚ôÇ Let's fix it 
what's the error?
There's 2 intertwined things -- the CI needs to pass, and 1 approving review is required. Without both of those, you can't push non-tags.

Sprinkling set -x into manage.sh:

```
++ grep -v Merge
++ git log v1.47.. --oneline '--pretty=format:* %s (%h)'
+ gitlog=
zsh: exit 1     REMOTE=pygithub ./manage.sh publish
```
Perhaps we should also make publishing new releases go through the PR process ü§î
I'm missing what OpenStack did, where you created a signed tag, pushed that, and the merge machinery created the tarball, release notes and the pypi release. :-)
The only thing about the PR process is we can't squash and merge since that will change the sha of the HEAD commit

Pull requests are merged using the --no-ff option, except for pull requests with squashed or rebased commits, which are merged using the fast-forward option.

Dear GitHub, why you so hard to work with :-( A ff merge is exactly what we want! *perhaps* a rebased commit of only one commit without HEAD changing out from under it would work, but I'm not sure if I'm wrong.
Okay, I've temporarily disable branch protection on `master`, until we can figure out a way to strike the balance between auditing every change and being able to push tags for release.
I've pushed the Publish 1.47 commit, comment when you re-enable the branch protection just for my piece of mind.

body:
When calling get_teams() from an organization object, it results in an error.
This is due to the organization's url attribute being in the format 
https://api.github.com/users/:org
This results in a call to GitHub at https://api.github.com/users/:org/teams when calling get_teams() 
 
The GitHub API specifies that call should be made to https://api.github.com/orgs/:org/teams for this operation.  https://developer.github.com/v3/teams/#list-teams


If it makes any difference the program will first fetch a repository from it's full name then the organization object is found from repo's attribute and from there we are trying to fetch the teams via get_teams() resulting in this error

Unfortunately as I am using this functionality in a job related capacity I cannot provide any code or logs but I hope that this information helps.

comments.body:
What version are you using?

I can see we call /user/orgs in AuthenicatedUser.get_orgs(), and every Organization object I've looked at has the URL in the correct form:

```
>>> org = g.get_organization("PyGithub")
>>> org.url
'https://api.github.com/orgs/PyGithub'
```

 Are you able to give us redacted output of what you're seeing?

body:
GitHub Developer API announcement:
https://developer.github.com/changes/2020-02-26-new-delete-reactions-endpoints/

These new endpoints need to be supported:

- [ ] Delete a commit comment reaction
  - `DELETE /repos/:owner/:repo/comments/:comment_id/reactions/:reaction_id`
  - Docs: https://developer.github.com/v3/reactions/#delete-a-commit-comment-reaction

- [ ] Delete an issue reaction
   - `DELETE /repos/:owner/:repo/issues/:issue_number/reactions/:reaction_id`
   - Docs: https://developer.github.com/v3/reactions/#delete-an-issue-reaction

- [ ] Delete a reaction to a commit comment
  - `DELETE /repos/:owner/:repo/issues/comments/:comment_id/reactions/:reaction_id`
  - Docs: https://developer.github.com/v3/reactions/#delete-an-issue-comment-reaction

- [ ] Delete a pull request comment reaction
  - `DELETE /repos/:owner/:repo/pulls/comments/:comment_id/reactions/:reaction_id`
  - Docs: https://developer.github.com/v3/reactions/#delete-a-pull-request-comment-reaction

- [ ] Delete team discussion reaction
  - `DELETE /orgs/:org/teams/:team_slug/discussions/:discussion_number/reactions/:reaction_id`
  - Docs: https://developer.github.com/v3/reactions/#delete-team-discussion-reaction

- [ ] Delete team discussion comment reaction
  - `DELETE /orgs/:org/teams/:team_slug/discussions/:discussion_number/comments/:comment_number/reactions/:reaction_id`

body:
Hello, 

I seem to be hitting Github search rate limits. I have written a utility to keep track of API calls but still seem to be hitting the search_code rate limit with basic authentication (30 per minute). 

Currently what I am doing is searching my entire Github organization's projects for a particular set of keywords. There are about 40-50 repos within the organization so I would expect I could make all necessary searches within 2 minutes. Is my logic correct? 

Here is some example code where I am using pypi package 'ratelimit' to limit my API requests to 29 per minute: 


```
@sleep_and_retry
@limits(calls=29, period=60)
def search_code(githubClient, query_string):
    search_results = []
    search = githubClient.search_code(query=query_string)
    for item in search:
        search_results.append(item)
    return search_results
```

Are there any examples that anyone has written where you are successfully able to avoid rate limits for searching? 

Thanks in advance.

comments.body: The search API has a different limit, as shown in https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/425280cee77b5542d0cdfaa6fea488fe9d61894a/github/RateLimit.py#L71 , have you tried to inspect the object to see what your limits are as you step through the repos?
Eh I just severely dropped it down to like 20 requests per minute keeping track of count. Not ideal but whatever. Thanks for response @s-t-e-v-e-n-k

body:
There's a functionality on the Github API that is apparently not supported on PyGithub -- https://developer.github.com/v3/repos/commits/#list-pull-requests-associated-with-commit

## Motivation

I'm doing an auto-versioning type of thing on my repo, and I need to walk through all the pull requests searching for labels. I can get all the commits since the last release using `<repo>.get_commits(since=date_from_last_release)`. It would be incredibly useful if those commits came with their associated pull requests - that way I could simply check for each label on those.

I couldn't find this functionality on the documentation or reading the code, and I couldn't find another decent way to do this on the current PyGithub implementation.

## Caveats

This feature seems to be in preview period and the API might change, so it's probably not worth doing this right now (if ever).

comments.body: I can probably try to submit a pull request for this if there's interest. On my project I prefer not to rely on a preview API with a reasonable chance of having to re-do this.
I think it's probably fine, we currently support a fair amount of preview endpoints anyway. I look forward to reviewing your PR.

title: List pull requests based on commit

body:
Basically what it says on the tin. The Github API [allows you to delete a card from a project](https://developer.github.com/v3/projects/cards/#delete-a-project-card) by card ID, but this functionality isn't exposed in PyGithub. Based on looking briefly at the documentation, the implementation might be something like:

```
    def delete(self):
        """
        :calls: `DELETE /projects/columns/cards/:card_id <https://developer.github.com/v3/projects/cards>`_
        :rtype: bool
        """
        status, _, _ = self._requester.requestJson(
            "DELETE",
            self.url,
            headers={"Accept": Consts.mediaTypeProjectsPreview},
        )
        return status == 204
```

comments.body: That looks pretty close for a PR -- are you comfortable also writing a test, or would I prefer I do the heavy lifting?
I'm happy writing a test and submitting a PR, thanks! Will do.
@s-t-e-v-e-n-k I'm afraid I bit off a bit more than I can chew with the testing; if I could hand it off to you, I'd be grateful. TIA.
Fixed in https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/pull/1417 since I missed up the commit message.

body:
When using PullRequest.set_labels() or PullRequest.add_to_assignees(), and passing a list of strings as a parameter to either of them, I get 
```
Traceback (most recent call last):  File ".\standardize.py", line 133, in <module>    st = Standardize('fae925c6fa18ed6f026931019c644712ac2af0fa', 'config.example.json')  File ".\standardize.py", line 25, in __init__
    self.standardize()  File ".\standardize.py", line 44, in standardize
    PRCONFIG=self.config.config['PR']  File "C:\src\gh-standardize\gh-standardize\repository.py", line 80, in createChangesPR    self.assignChangesPR(PR, PRCONFIG)
  File "C:\src\gh-standardize\gh-standardize\repository.py", line 98, in assignChangesPR
    PR.add_to_assignees(PRCONFIG['AUTOASSIGN'])  File "C:\Users\Ari\.virtualenvs\gh-standardize-TV0O1TPc\lib\site-packages\github\PullRequest.py", line 836, in add_to_assignees        
    ), assigneesAssertionError: (['akmadian'],)
```
where ['akmadian'] is the list of assignees, or for labels, it could be ['bug', 'help wanted'], etc. AFAIK, this is valid syntax because the documentation for both [add_to_assignees()](https://pygithub.readthedocs.io/en/latest/github_object/PullRequest.html#github.PullRequest.PullRequest.add_to_assignees), and [set_labels()](https://pygithub.readthedocs.io/en/latest/github_objects/PullRequest.html#github.PullRequest.PullRequest.set_labels) both say that a list of strings is a valid parameter. I am loading the lists of strings from a JSON file via json.loads(), but I don't think that should make a difference since the JSON array is converted to a python list anyways. When I take the first index of the list and pass a single string, it works alright. This may also happen with other similar methods, but these are the only two I've tested.

Is this a bug, or am I missing something syntax-wise here? Thanks :)

comments.body:
The docstring could be a little clearer, but you just pass as many parameters as you want, and that is the list. If you want to pass a constructed array, use *.  IE:

``PR.add_to_assignees(*PRCONFIG['AUTOASSIGN'])``
Ah I see, so it was a small syntax thing :) Will give it a try tomorrow. Thanks!

This caught me as well on `PullRequest.set_labels()`. It feels more pythonic to accept a python list as the arguments.

A backward-compatible way to address this would be to check if the first element is a list and, if so, expand that.

title: AssertionError when passing valid(?) parameter

body:
Given a PullRequest object `pull`, the following sequence of operations leads to a 404 error:

1. `pull.add_to_assignees("fpoli")`
2. `pull.create_review_request(reviewers=["some-user"])`

However, the following works fine:

1. `deepclone(pull).add_to_assignees("fpoli")`
2. `pull.create_review_request(reviewers=["some-user"])`

Possible reason: internally, `add_to_assignees` calls the `_useAttributes` defined in the `Issue` class, which replaces the `self._url` of the pull request with the url of an _issue_. Then, the `create_review_request` call fails because it sends a POST request to a non-existing endpoint like <https://api.github.com/repos/viperproject/viperserver/issues/10/requested_reviewers>, which should be <https://api.github.com/repos/viperproject/viperserver/pulls/10/requested_reviewers>.

comments.body: I've failed to reproduce this. Are you able to give me a short example that fails reproducibly?

Version: `PyGithub==1.46`

Code:
```
github = Github(os.environ["GITHUB_ACCESS_TOKEN"])
repo = github.get_repo("fpoli/test")
pull = repo.create_pull(
    title="PR title",
    body="PR body",
    base="master",
    head="new-feature",
)

print("Before:", pull._url.value)
pull.add_to_assignees("fpoli")
print("After:", pull._url.value)

pull.create_review_request(reviewers=["fpoli"])
```

body:
Hello and thanks for providing this neat library :-)

Out of a [discussion over in `probot/ideas`](https://github.com/probot/ideas/issues/26#issuecomment-578270124) came an idea that I'd be happy to receive input from around here: A tool to help maintainers observe the fork network around their project, in order to review interesting branches, which were never included in PRs (thus not easily reviewable by maintainers).

Would this be more fruitful to attempt via:

a) [`get_network_events()`](https://pygithub.readthedocs.io/en/latest/github_objects/Repository.html#github.Repository.Repository.get_network_events) (plus extracting the branch from `payload.ref` and creator from `repo.name`, if the event is a `PushEvent`), or 

b) getting [all branches](https://pygithub.readthedocs.io/en/latest/github_objects/Repository.html#github.Repository.Repository.get_branches), [all forks](https://pygithub.readthedocs.io/en/latest/github_objects/Repository.html#github.Repository.Repository.get_forks) and [all PRs](https://pygithub.readthedocs.io/en/latest/github_objects/Repository.html#github.Repository.Repository.get_pulls),

to create a list of branches that did diverge from the origin(al), but are not in a PR already? Thanks for any hints on how to use PyGitHub for this purpose, or for pointers to existing tools that do that :-)

If none are known, would you welcome a PR with such a high-level functionality, or should it be a different tool?

comments.body: Never mind. Such tools seem to accumulate [under the topic `forks-insight`](https://github.com/topics/forks-insight) :-)

title: Creating a project without body argument leads to exception

body:
Hi I found below parameter in documentation
    retry ‚Äì int or urllib3.util.retry.Retry object
so this int(retry) is the number of times to retry ??
can you please let me know how to use and what is the timeout ??
I can see the default read timeout=15.

github.Github(GITHUB_AUTH_TOKEN,retry=3)

comments.body:
They are two disparate concepts:

* Timeout is how long we wait for a reply before giving up. The default is 15 seconds.

* Retry is how many times we will re-send the request if we get a temporary error or the request times out. The default is to not retry.

Your example that you've included at the bottom is the correct way to use retry.
Thanks for the INFO.

title: how to use retry parameter github.Github(GITHUB_AUTH_TOKEN,retry=3)

body:
Currently there is support for **creating** a label for use in a repository.  https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/fc7109eab750b52ce3c96ad447c3e9011419c952/github/Repository.py#L1194-L1219

However, there is no support for **updating** nor **deleting** a label from a repository.  This issue requests an enhancement for updating and deleting repository labels.

References:

### Updating

```
PATCH /repos/:owner/:repo/labels/:name
```
https://developer.github.com/v3/issues/labels/#update-a-label

### Deleting

```
DELETE /repos/:owner/:repo/labels/:name
```
https://developer.github.com/v3/issues/labels/#delete-a-label

comments.body:
I did a "monkey-patch" in my code to add the missing methods.  It can serve as an example of what is being requested.

https://github.com/docktermj/python-github-tasks/blob/7fd9f3735583df724bc4c51266fcd13a63160e3d/github-tasks.py#L742-L790

Actually, both of those operations are supported! They act on the ``Label`` object, not ``Repository``.

https://pygithub.readthedocs.io/en/latest/github_objects/Label.html

But I do note that Label.edit needs to be fixed...

May I suggest that from a symmetry perspective, the Create, Update, and Delete be from the same level of abstraction?   

When Label.delete() occurs,  one could assume equally that the label is deleted from the repository default or that the label is deleted from an issue.  ...or could be deleted from an unknown set, such as the account "default" labels used to instantiated default labels on repository creation.   Net: the behavior of Label.delete() is ambiguous.

By having Repository.create_label(),  Repository.update_label(), Repository.delete_label() there is no ambiguity from which "set" the label is being deleted.

Labels as a first-class object are on the Repository. If you want to remove them from an Issue or a PR, there are a bunch of functions to add/remove/replace labels.

I'm tempted to write a Labels mix-in to homogenise it across Repo/Issue/PR, but in any case the functions you are asking about are implemented.
However, I think Label.edit() is the correct way to do that, since you're modify the label itself, not which labels are on a PR/issue.

One way of determining if an object is a "first class object" is to determine that it is independent of other objects.  The current architecture has Label as an object dependent on a Repository object.  

A Label as a first-class object could be added to an Account, Repository, or Issue equally.  Once that is understood, you may want to reconsider your design.

The asymmetry of CREATE and DELETE seems very odd to me.

**Repository.py** has create.
```
POST /repos/:owner/:repo/labels
```

But **Label.py** has delete.
```
DELETE /repos/:owner/:repo/labels/:name
```

Yet **Issue.py** has both create and delete labels.
```
POST /repos/:owner/:repo/issues/:number/labels
DELETE /repos/:owner/:repo/issues/:number/labels/:name
```

Based on the URIs, it appears that it's an architectural choice in PyGithub, rather than the GitHub architecture. 

All I'm asking is that as a Software architect, you make a good choice.

This is a separate issue. This API pre-dates my involvement in the project, but we can talk about deprecation and how to address it there. Further, it's unclear if DELETE /repos/:owner/:repo/issues/:number/labels/:name actually deletes the label or deletes the link from the issue to the label ...

title: Support for update and delete repository labels

    repo = client.get_repo(GIT_REPO)

comments.body: There are two methods, -- first, just use ``file_content.content`` which is the contents, which you can write to a file. Secondly, there's ``file_content.download_url`` to grab it.

So you can do it like this:
```python
from github import Github
import urllib

def github_file_to_bytes(repo, path, git_token, branch="main") -> bytes:
    g = Github(git_token)
    repo = g.get_repo(repo)
    return repo.get_contents(urllib.parse.quote(path), ref=branch).decoded_content
```

Example:
```python
github_file_to_bytes(repo="pandas-dev/pandas", path="/doc/.gitignore", git_token=git_token, branch="master")
```

Can someone here explain why we have to import base64 and decode a file ourselves? Why is this not built into the `get_contents` function? How can we know what the proper decoding is for a given file?

body:
There is an issue when using create_git_tag_and_release function to create a release in Repository.py.

`   def create_git_tag_and_release(
        self,
        tag,
        tag_message,
        release_name,
        release_message,
        object,
        type,
        tagger=github.GithubObject.NotSet,
        draft=False,
        prerelease=False,
    ):
        self.create_git_tag(tag, tag_message, object, type, tagger)
        return self.create_git_release(
            tag, release_name, release_message, draft, prerelease
        )`

The code cannot create a correct commit id from the created tag. please help to fix it. thanks.

comments.body: So let's break it down further. Since Repository.create_git_tag_and_release() fails to create a tag pointing to the correct commit, does Repository.create_git_tag() also show the same behaviour? Do you have an example you can show us?

Repository.create_git_tag()  works fine, instead I use the Repository.create_git_release() which can can create both a correct release and tag for me with a correct commit id. 

From the source code, I found there is no passing a parameter pointing to the commit info:
        return self.create_git_release(tag, release_name, release_message, draft, prerelease)
it should provide target_commitish parameter.

Not sure my idea is correct.
It's a good theory, worth checking out. Thanks for your explanation, that helps me work out what is going on. I'll investigate this based on your information.

+1, noticed following:
`create_git_tag_and_release(tag="v1.2", object="commit_sha", ...)`
Expected behaviour:
  1) created tag with name "v1.2"
  2) this tag points to commit "commit_sha"
  3) created release associated with tag "v1.2"

Real behaviour
  1) tag is probably created via `create_git_tag`, but
  2) tag IS NOT referencing commit "commit_sha"
  3) `create_git_release` creates another tag pointing to another (wrong) commit

Did following to fix behaviour:
  1) manually creating tag via `tag = create_git_tag(object=commit_sha, ...)`
  2) manually creating reference to the tag via `create_git_ref("refs/tags/v1.2", tag.sha)`
  3) making release via `create_git_release(tag.tag, ...)`

You could check, that create_git_tag doesn't creates reference via:
  - `create_git_tag(...)`
  - `git pull`
  - `git tag -v "tag_name"`
And without reference `create_git_release` doesn't take the tag into account when creating release.
Passing `target_commitish` probably will fix the issue
At least based on the code, the tag should reference the correct sha, since the object parameter is passed into create_git_tag() ...

yep, created tag is pointing to the correct revision, but the problem is that for some reason `create_git_tag` doesn't create reference (`refs/tags/...`) to the tag object sha and `create_git_release` ignores passed tag and creates new with the same name and according to the API that tag is pointing to the head of the default repository branch (for the case when `target_commitish` is not passed) (in our case it is the latest commit in the `develop` branch)

From https://developer.github.com/v3/git/tags/:

Note that creating a tag object does not create the reference that makes a tag in Git. If you want to create an annotated tag in Git, you have to do this call to create the tag object, and then create the refs/tags/[tag] reference.


Please don't conflate this bug with a different (and documented upstream!) issue.

OK, haven't read docs till the end.
Was a little bit confused with the sentence "The Git tags API only supports annotated tag objects, not lightweight tags."
But in fact in order to fix subject behaviour you need do one of the following (though i'm not sure, it's subject to test):
1) don't call `create_git_tag` and call `create_git_release` with `tag="tag_name", target_commitish="commit sha"`
2) call `create_git_tag`, create reference, call `create_git_release` as expected
3) call `create_git_tag`, call `create_git_release` with `tag=tag.name` and `target_commitish=tag.sha`

title: cannot create a correct release from tag when using create_git_tag_and_release

body:
Branch protection for organization repos allow for the inclusion of dismissal restrictions for who should be able to dismiss reviews. To disable this feature, you must pass an empty object when editing branch protection. The current function `edit_protection` in `Branch.py` excludes the field if no users or teams are provided, which is the same as setting both to an empty list. This has the effect of limiting who can dismiss a review to admin users.

Unfortunately, the fix is not as simple as including the field with an empty dict when neither users nor teams are provided, as this causes a validation error when used to edit branch protection for user owned repos.

```
422 {'message': 'Validation Failed', 'errors': ['Only organization repositories can have users and team restrictions'], 'documentation_url': 'https://developer.github.com/v3/repos/branches/#update-branch-protection'} 
```

I am happy to PR a fix, but am unsure what direction the maintainers would like to go.

1. Add org context to the Branch object when calling `get_branch` from a Repository object. This has the benefit of not introducing an API breaking change or additional arguments to `edit_protection`.

2. Add an option to the `edit_protection` function that allows the user to specify whether it is a branch or an org repo. This will require a default that will either need to be defaulted to true or false. Default of user repo would maintain current behavior and leave org repos misconfigured. Default to org repo would cause validation errors for user repos, thus introducing an API breaking change.

3. Something else.

comments.body:
I'm still unhappy with parts of the branch protection API, but mostly at how brittle it is exported by GitHub.

Could we look at the Branch object and if it has users and teams dismissal restrictions set, then pass those if NotSet, otherwise ignore them, would that work?

The Branch object itself wouldn't have any branch protection attributes to check; that data is retrieved by the `get_protection` call, which returns a BranchProtection object. Given just the Branch object, there is currently no way that I know of to determine whether the call should or should not include the dismissal restrictions.

Some of the attributes are populated when calling get_branch():

```
>>> repo = g.get_repo('PyGithub/PyGithub')
>>> b = repo.get_branch('master')
>>> b._rawData['protection']
{'enabled': True, 'required_status_checks': {'enforcement_level': 'off', 'contexts': []}}
```

It looks like the only protection data provided when getting branch info is whether protection is enabled and what status checks are required. The rest of the data is only provided when queried from the protection API.
Drat, GitHub ruining my good plans. I think an is_organization attribute on Branch (or a better name, suggestions welcome) would work. Do you want to get started on a PR for that?
Yep, I can do that. And you are comfortable with that being an extra argument passed in to the Branch init?
This issue has been automatically marked as stale because it has not had recent activity. It will be closed if no further activity occurs. Thank you for your contributions.

title: Dismissal Restrictions Enabled When no Users/Teams Provided

I mean, that is the crux of the problem, there is no way to compare them since they don't share a common ancestor -- IE, they have no history in common.

You can make an empty Comparison object by cheating a little:
```
>>> c = github.Comparison.Comparison(None, {}, {}, True)
>>> c
<github.Comparison.Comparison object at 0x7f79c8b4fa58>
>>> c._rawData
{}
```
alright , got it . thanks a lot.

We are getting this error a lot: 

```
GithubException: 403 {u'documentation_url': u'https://developer.github.com/v3/#rate-limiting', u'message': u'API rate limit exceeded for user.'}
```

According to their documentation on https://developer.github.com/v3/#rate-limiting, they send the `X-RateLimit-Reset` header in the response from which we can figure out when to make the api call again. Is it possible to get the value of that header in PyGithub? If not, how much is the minimum time we should wait before making the api call again?

comments.body:
Hello

to get the value you need to wait for rate limit reset (in case you get close to the limit):
```
core_rate_limit = <github_object>.get_rate_limit().core
reset_timestamp = calendar.timegm(core_rate_limit.reset.timetuple())
sleep_time = reset_timestamp - calendar.timegm(time.gmtime())
                    + 5  # add 5 seconds to be sure the rate limit has been reset
time.sleep(sleep_time)
```

we are seeing since this week-end some strange behavior of the Github API /rate_limit endpoint, which always return "5000" for the core counter remaining calls...
Anybody having the same problem?

> Hello
> 
> to get the value you need to wait for rate limit reset (in case you get close to the limit):
> 
> ```
> core_rate_limit = <github_object>.get_rate_limit().core
> reset_timestamp = calendar.timegm(core_rate_limit.reset.timetuple())
> sleep_time = reset_timestamp - calendar.timegm(time.gmtime())
>                     + 5  # add 5 seconds to be sure the rate limit has been reset
> time.sleep(sleep_time)
> ```
> 
> we are seeing since this week-end some strange behavior of the Github API /rate_limit endpoint, which always return "5000" for the core counter remaining calls...
> Anybody having the same problem?

I think it is because we consume the search remain rather than the core remain.

[The definition of `core` is here](https://developer.github.com/v3/rate_limit/)

> For these reasons, the Rate Limit API response categorizes your rate limit. Under resources, you'll see four objects:
> The core object provides your rate limit status for all **non-search-related** resources in the REST API.
> The search object provides your rate limit status for the Search API.


I obtained the value of `g.get_rate_limit().search.remaining` and found it would decrease.

```python
for pr in g.search_issues(query=keyword, **{'repo': repo, 'type': 'pr'}):
    rl = g.get_rate_limit()
    rl_core = rl.core
    rl_search = rl.search
    # print the info here
```

The output is 

```sh
core | Limit: 5000, Remaining: 5000, Reset: 2020-01-08 14:09:16.
search | Limit: 30, Remaining: 29, Reset: 2020-01-08 13:10:16.
core | Limit: 5000, Remaining: 5000, Reset: 2020-01-08 14:09:16.
search | Limit: 30, Remaining: 29, Reset: 2020-01-08 13:10:16.
...
core | Limit: 5000, Remaining: 5000, Reset: 2020-01-08 14:09:16.
search | Limit: 30, Remaining: 28, Reset: 2020-01-08 13:10:16.
core | Limit: 5000, Remaining: 5000, Reset: 2020-01-08 14:09:16.
search | Limit: 30, Remaining: 28, Reset: 2020-01-08 13:10:16.
...
core | Limit: 5000, Remaining: 5000, Reset: 2020-01-08 14:09:16.
search | Limit: 30, Remaining: 27, Reset: 2020-01-08 13:10:16.
core | Limit: 5000, Remaining: 5000, Reset: 2020-01-08 14:09:16.
search | Limit: 30, Remaining: 27, Reset: 2020-01-08 13:10:16.
```

While iterating, it will send new requests to get next pages. The code is in `PaginatedListBase.__iter__(self)`.

```python
    def __iter__(self):
        for element in self.__elements:
            yield element
        while self._couldGrow():
            newElements = self._grow()  # the _grow function will send new request
            for element in newElements:
                yield element
```

----------- update -----------------------
I ran it again and this time, I found the search remaining never be less than 2 to sleep.

```

2020/01/08 21:50:33 PM - INFO - search remaining: 17

Hello
yes you should indeed adapt my proposal to the right rate limit counter (core, search, graphql). For search counter, we usually stop when remaining calls are 5 (but we don't use a lot /search api)
For timeouts, i would suggest to enable Retry() mechanism (if not already done), see #1103 , maybe it  can help

body:
Github's [Tree creation api](https://developer.github.com/v3/git/trees/#create-a-tree) allows us to pass `sha = null` to indicate that the specified blob needs to be deleted.

However, I don't have a way to pass this info to my `InputGitTreeElement`. I can either give it a str or a `github.GithubObject.NotSet`. This means I have no way of deleting files from a tree using PyGithub (I'd like to delete multiple files in a single commit so tree creation is the ideal choice for me).

The current design is to only pass the `sha` if it is actually set:
https://github.com/PyGithub/PyGithub/blob/540a085001/github/InputGitTreeElement.py#L81

I can understand that passing a `None` goes against the design. I think something like `github.GithubObject.Null` could be introduced to explicitly say that this field is `null`. It can be used everywhere the GH API accepts a null value.

Example
```python
new_tree = repo.create_git_tree(
    [
        InputGitTreeElement(
            path="my/dir/my_file.txt", mode="100644", type="blob", sha=github.GithubObject.Null
        ),
   ],
    base_tree=head_commit.tree
)
```
This will delete `my/dir/my_file.txt`

---

My current workaround is to directly hit the api to create tree (using requests, setting `sha=None`), get the tree sha & use it with pygithub for my remaining workflow (committing, etc).

Please let me know in case I misunderstood some aspect or if anything needs to be elaborated upon.

comments.body: Actually NotSet is an class in it's own right that has nothing to do with None, so if you pass in None, it *should* work fine.
Oh, wait, I see. We assert it's a str! Right, okay, so I think loosening to allow None is perfectly fine then, nice catch.

I'm having a lot of trouble with this change. I've made the necessary changes, but the create_git_tree() API either returns 422 GitRPC::BadObjectState or a generic 404 Not Found error.  Are you able to provide a working example against a public repo so I can grab the replay data for the unit test?

My code is for a private repo, so I just created a stripped-down version of it for you here:

```python
import json
import requests
from http import HTTPStatus
from github import Github

TOKEN = "<GITHUB TOKEN>"
gh_client = Github(TOKEN)

repo = gh_client.get_repo("duaraghav8/test")
my_branch = "tree-test"

# paths is list of files to delete
paths = ["pods/raghav/network/resources.tf", "abc"]

sha = repo.get_branch(my_branch).commit.sha
head_commit = repo.get_git_commit(sha)

tree_objects = [
    {"path": path, "mode": "100644", "type": "blob", "sha": None}
    for path in paths
]
payload = {
    "base_tree": head_commit.tree.sha,
    "tree": tree_objects,
}
headers = {"Authorization": f"token {TOKEN}"}
url = f"{repo.url}/git/trees"

response = requests.post(url, headers=headers, data=json.dumps(payload))
if response.status_code != HTTPStatus.CREATED:
    raise RuntimeError("Failed")

new_tree_sha = response.json()["sha"]
tree = repo.get_git_tree(new_tree_sha)
```

1 reason I too received `422 GitRPC::BadObjectState` was because I was supplying filenames in `paths` that didn't exist in the base tree. For eg, try corrupting 1 of the filenames above.

```
abc

```

body:
When using the search_issues API a PaginatedList of Issues is returned. When you iterate through the list and try to check whether the issue is a pull request or not you test the Issue.pull_request field for Null test. 

Problem is that if the Issue item is not a PR, this field has not been "completed" so the library makes an API call to GitHub to grab the individual issue being processed causing an unnecessary API call (and using up your rate limits). We already have all the issue data from the search. But this time when the object is updated with the issue data, object is considered "completed".

If the issue object actually is a PR this field will have already been "completed" so no extra API call is performed.

All the fields in the Issue object should have been considered "completed" when building the PaginatedList from the search_issues.

comments.body: As a test, I modified the calls to self.__contentClass() to pass in 'completed=True' when building the list of objects.  This stops the extra API call but not sure what this might expose.

We can't do that generically, because we can not be certain that GitHub has returned a complete object. I can think of two cases off the top of my head where they aren't complete. You can use _pull_request if that is all you need to check.

@s-t-e-v-e-n-k, I dug into the code and was using the _pull_request as another work around. For my benefit and future google searchers, could you elaborate on the two cases where complete results are not returned? It seems like doing it the way it is done pretty much defeats the purpose of using the search API to load on Github?

We are at the mercy of what GitHub returns. There isn't a field GitHub populates saying "Okay, you have all the data we know about", so we need to be naive and marked the object as incomplete. Repository.get_branches() and NamedUser.get_repos() are the two off the top of my head that do not return complete objects.
